PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:PRIVACY BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with order of the day No. 2. That being the case, the Chair will allow that course of action.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988. The Opposition will not be opposing the Bill. However, this Bill and the related privacy legislation are not the same Bills that the Government originally drafted. We are supporting what is now, in effect, a voluntary tax file number system which is swathed in privacy safeguards. What the Government originally drafted was totally inadequate. However, after consultation, the Opposition has forced the Government to adopt our recommendations on the two Bills. What we have convinced the Government to accept is that the tax file number system has to be voluntary. It cannot be some sort of licence to exist.

SPEECH.PARA: In June this year the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), Senator Stone and I met with the Commissioner of Taxation on the Government's tax file number proposals. We stated the Opposition's unequivocal rejection of the Government's originally stated intention of freezing bank accounts and the threatened cessation of the purchase and sale of shares where the tax file number was not quoted. The Government accepted our arguments and opted instead for the application of a withholding tax as an alternative to its then draconian proposals. This alternative set up the mechanism whereby we could and did advocate and achieve a situation in which it will not be compulsory to quote the tax file number as it applies to dividends, interest and terms of employment.

Our further amendments, accepted by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on Monday, put beyond doubt that the scheme is completely voluntary, while at the same time retaining the essence of a withholding tax in those circumstances where the taxpayer chooses not to quote his or her tax file number. We have excised from the Bill any obligation implied or expressed on the part of the taxpayer to quote the tax file number and on financial institutions or employers to require the tax file number.

We have also gained agreement from the Government to rewrite substantially its original draft privacy legislation. That began with a letter from the Opposition to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) detailing 10 points of obvious inadequacy in the privacy legislation. A number of lengthy meetings between the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), in his position as shadow Attorney-General, and Senator Tate, in his capacity as Acting Attorney-General, resulted in the Government acceding to our requests. The honourable member for Menzies will want to give a fuller description of the concessions made on privacy. But I just want to note some key points.

First, the original Privacy Bill provided that the Privacy Commissioner, to be set up under that Bill, `may' issue guidelines on the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information. `May' is obviously not the same as `shall'. Under that provision the Privacy Commissioner may or may not have issued guidelines. If he did not, there would have been virtually no privacy safeguards at all. This was a critical defect of the Bill. So far as the tax file number was concerned, it did not ensure privacy at all. So we sought and subsequently obtained an effective change from `may' to `shall'.

The Bill as introduced contains specified interim guidelines. They will have effect until the Privacy Commissioner issues his own guidelines. Those guidelines specifically restrict the use of the tax file number and stipulate that the number system is not to be used, by whatever means, as a national identification system. Additionally, the Bill ensures that the tax file number recipients shall not collect, record, use or disclose tax file number information in an unauthorised manner and, in particular, shall not act in an unauthorised manner to use tax file number information as a means of matching personal information about a taxpayer.

Furthermore, the original Bill as proffered by the Government enabled the Privacy Commissioner to enter premises and inspect documents while pursuing a claim. However, that could be done only by arrangement with the government agency or tax file number recipient concerned. That virtually meant that the Commissioner would have to get the agency's consent before inspection. We in the Opposition were adamant that it was absolutely unacceptable that a government agency could avoid inspection. We sought an amendment so that the Privacy Commissioner could have instant access to government agencies without an arrangement being made in advance. However, in the case of the private sector, the occupier would need to consent to the visit or a warrant would have to be obtained from a magistrate. The Government again, I am pleased to say, agreed to this.

Another key point is that originally the tax file number legislation was to become effective well before the privacy legislation. Some safeguard! The Government brought in a tax file number Bill and said that it was going to bring in a privacy Bill. The privacy legislation at that time was inadequate in relation to the tax file number but, irrespective of that, the Government was going to put the tax file number legislation into operation before the Privacy Bill was operating. That was yet another key point that we took up with the Government. The tax file numbers Bill was to come into operation upon receiving royal assent; that is, shortly after it was passed by the Parliament. However, the Privacy Bill was to come into operation only on proclamation, which could have been much later. As I have just indicated, it left a gap in that the obligations under the tax file numbers Bill would have been in force without the protection of the Privacy Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a cheek.

—It was a cheek. It was totally unacceptable that the tax file numbers Bill should come into operation either at the same time as or after the Privacy Bill commenced operation. We indicated that unless the tax file numbers Bill came into operation at the same time as or after the Privacy Bill commenced operation it was unacceptable to us. It also happened to be a crucial recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. Again, I am pleased to say, the Government accepted that these amendments were necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has sought and won substantial concessions from the Government. I make it perfectly clear that there would be no support for the tax file numbers legislation from this side had we not obtained agreement to all these measures, ending up in what, as I said before, is essentially a voluntary system. The Government's amended legislation has not quite gone from woeful to wonderful but there has certainly been a vast improvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks to you and Neil.

—Yes. My colleague did most of the work but I was pleased to sit down with the Treasurer and seek to establish in law that the tax file number system was to be essentially a voluntary system. As the honourable member for Menzies would thank Senator Tate for listening with care and interest, I would thank the Treasurer-this is a cherished and rare moment-for his patience in listening to my views, for agreeing that they were plausible and for changing the nature of the legislation.
—He always speaks very highly of you too, Andrew.

—The Minister for Veterans' Affairs could have fooled me. We consider that we have successfully forestalled the tax file number being turned surreptitiously, through the back door, into an ID card. Our views on an ID card are well known. The sloppiness and ill-thought through elements of the original legislation presented to this Parliament could have allowed that to occur. We are satisfied that with the amendments that have been accepted by the Government that will not happen. Very significant amendments would have to be made in future to the legislation by future Acts of Parliament if it were to become a national identification system. People can rest easy that this element of incrementalism-incremental creep into other areas-will not occur because of the constraints that we have written into the legislation. There is no way that on our side of politics we will accept the reintroduction, by any method at all, of the Government's despised and discredited ID card legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: When we were coming to our decision we sought to have regard to any viable alternatives that were around. Again, those alternatives were to be subject to what I could term our three-point check list-our three-point test-that any proposals would need to combat tax fraud successfully; they would need to be cost effective; and they must not jeopardise Australians' civil liberties. No other alternative became obvious to us. Certainly, upgraded computer facilities, as suggested by some people and based on the example of the British experience, did not provide hard evidence that this would effectively combat tax fraud to anywhere near the same extent as the tax file number system. In addition, a significant difference between Britain and the current Australian situation is that the British automatically withhold tax on interest income. Therefore, the United Kingdom does not have the equivalent problem to ours in Australia-it has been identified by the Government as a problem, and we concur-where two-thirds of the money to be recovered by the tax file number is accounted for by evaded interest income.

As it turns out, with all the amendments that we have put in and with a voluntary system, we are satisfied that the legislation now to be so significantly amended meets the Opposition's three-part test mentioned before-namely, first, that it would need to combat tax fraud successfully; second, that it would need to be cost effective and, third, that it must not jeopardise our people's civil liberties. But what of the broader picture? The tax file number is, in reality, just another manifestation of the high levels of taxation in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—Tax bracket creep has ripped into the living standards of average Australians. By saying `nonsense' the honourable member indicates to me that he is on a par with the current Treasurer, who will not spend time with the people of this nation. One has only to talk to anyone in the Australian community who is struggling to cope with the depressed living standards under this Government to understand the veracity of what I am saying. Ipso facto the honourable member must be detached from the mainstream of life in this country if he does not appreciate just how difficult it is today for people to cope not only with high interest rates and high rates of inflation but also with high rates of income tax. Tax bracket creep-edging up into higher and higher brackets-has unquestionably ripped into the living standards of the overwhelming majority of average Australians.
—It has nothing to do with tax avoidance.
—One of the greatest motivations to avoid taxation, you fool, is to have high rates of tax.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that remark.

—It was a very minor provocation, but of course I will withdraw it. In a roundabout way I make the point that it is estimated that between 1985-86 and July 1989, when the much awaited tax cuts are delivered, this Labor Government will have wrenched $10 billion-I will repeat that figure; it is not $10m but $10 billion-out of the pockets of Australian taxpayers through bracket creep. That is $10 billion of taxation by stealth.
—Theft.

—Like a thief in the night. The Government seems to spend too much time thinking of methods for collecting those little bits of revenue that it feels it is constantly missing rather than concentrating on cutting the tax burden. We are still waiting in vain for the promised tax cuts. There has been no relief from taxation in the period that this Government has been in power. The fiddles that have been going on have been termed `tax reforms' but they are not a form of tax relief. If, after this long period of gestation, the tax cuts finally arrive next year, the Government will need to give genuine relief. We are still waiting in vain for the promised tax cuts.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect that the Government may well have loved it had we opposed the tax file number legislation. It would have sought-I emphasise the word `sought'-to use our opposition, wrongly, as an excuse for the paucity of the tax cuts that the people are now promised next year. That excuse will not be there. We will watch the Treasurer like a hawk, so to speak, to ensure that the privacy legislation on the tax file number provides adequate safeguards. In the same way we will be on his back at every opportunity in this Parliament until July next year, and thereafter, to ensure that those Australians who are carrying the burden of this Government's economic policies through their depressed living standards get their tax cuts. They are tax cuts that are not only needed for those individuals but also, as I have said time and again in this Parliament, needed in a macro-economic sense.

We would not use the surplus to shovel back some money to people. We would cut government expenditure as the primary method of providing those tax cuts, therefore reducing public demand, which would offset any increase in private demand for the increased disposable income that Australians would have. By doing that we would be not only doing the right thing for the economy but also restoring incentive to Australians to invest more and to work. These are two significant elements that have been rapidly vanishing from the Australian community. The incentive has gone. People work that extra period, move into a higher tax bracket and pay half their extra money to the Taxation Commissioner.

The Treasurer's recent pronouncement that government expenditure had been pared back enough and that there remain no slack in the Budget for expenditure reduction was patently ludicrous. On the contrary, there always seems to be enough for the Government to shovel out here and there. We had the Government's extraordinary performance of paying for the Governor-General designate's trip. The Prime Minister said he needed a little break. So everyone chipped in and sent Bill away. He had a good break. Honourable members should not tell me that that money did not come from the taxpayers.

In the last couple of days we have been discussing the waste of the Aboriginal Development Commission and its excesses. We have not even started to develop that discussion yet. That is another example of where our Waste Watch Committee has identified enormous areas of waste. It is just not conceivable that the Community Services and Health Department, the Employment, Education and Training Department and the Social Security Department are models of bureaucratic efficiency. We know that they are not. Do not come in here and tell us that there is no place where we can start cutting back, because we have policies and programs that identify areas. Beyond that, there is the element of waste, which those opposite deny even exists.

If we had opposed this legislation, it may well have been that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer would have sought to label us as `friends of the tax cheats' and lashed out at us about being in cahoots with big business! However, rather than touching the rich-this is a fairly important point-the tax file number will be focusing on those Australians already suffering under a crippling tax burden. We agree that tax evasion, particularly through interest earned, has to be dealt with. However, I ask honourable members opposite to bear in mind that they are imposing an additional burden, although it can be exercised voluntarily, on the great majority of Australians, who are already carrying a heavy tax burden. Not only will we keep an eye on the way this legislation goes and make whatever changes will be necessary when we are in government, but every time I have to talk on any element of legislation that touches on taxation I will remind the Government of what it is doing to average Australians today-whether it be in regard to the purchase of their homes, their disposable incomes or the gross distortion of their living standards that the Government has dumped on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the corporate sector and the higher income people have got a cut.

—There is no doubt that in fact some of those people are doing very well. When those opposite talk about tax evasion and march in here and say, `We will deal with this and that element of tax evasion', it is always in regard to the little people. What did the Government do in the May economic statement? The Treasurer came in here and said, `We have identified another area of tax evasion. We are going to get on to it and close it'. He was referring to all those fellows operating tax havens overseas-actually, all the Government's mates. The Treasurer did not name them, but people around the world know where these tax havens are. The Treasurer said, `We are going to close them on 1 July 1989'. Have we ever in the history of this nation known a Treasurer to come in here, identify an area of tax evasion, and give people 15 months to rearrange their affairs and clean it up? Cut it out! Have another look at the contrast between what they do for a few of their mates and what they do not do for the great majority of Australians, who do not get a break like that. It is a stark, staring contrast. If honourable members opposite want to sit in here, interject and yap away at me about how this will get the tax cheats, they should recognise that they are dumping on people an obligation that so frequently they will seek not to dump on those who are their mates.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again, I will draw the contrast. Because I am making these very real points in regard to taxation, those opposite are overlooking the reality that we are supporting the legislation because we want to see tax cheats effectively dealt with. However, I say to honourable members opposite that they should look at what they are doing in government and treat people on the same basis-not on the basis of a deal for those who give donations or services to their party. Sadly, people are evading tax because they have lost respect for a government that shows them no respect in return. Ironically, it is this Government that has seen the incomes of its rich mates grow while, as I said, the disposable income of the average family has fallen. By July next year a person on average weekly earnings with a spouse and two dependent children will require a tax cut of $56 a week to get him or her back to the living standards they enjoyed in March 1983, when the Keating-Hawke Government came to power. This tired Government is on the nose. The Treasurer may think that he has had a good year, but the fact is that through his own egomania he has damaged the Government to its roots.

If more taxes is reform, in the words of the Treasurer, we are reforming ourselves right down the Argentinean road. As for the Treasurer's inflated rhetoric about Australia today, there have in fact been no economic miracles, which is what was pronounced; Australia is not, as is alleged by the Government, the envy of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development; and we are hardly used as a shining beacon to illustrate economic brilliance. Oh, I give him his due: in one extraordinary award a magazine gave him the title of the world's best Treasurer. Within 12 months he and someone from some north African state were considered the last two-for the world's worst. I do not know who these guys are, whether they are schizophrenic or human hiccups, but that is the sort of pendulum that has occurred in this country on those people. They were reasonably confident at the outset of this Government. There was a new government coming in, people were wishing it well and everyone was fairly confident, but look and see it now! This nation compares tragically with so many other countries in our own region, countries which when I came into this Parliament we used to give aid programs to. We used to give aid or development assistance to countries in our region which now look like having a better standard of living than us. It takes a touch of exquisite genius to do that in a generation. It has accelerated and worsened through both periods of a Labor government. The tragedy is, as I touched on before, that the incentive to save and to invest and for productivity to improve is absolutely crucial for Australia's future.

Vague promises oft restated about tax cuts next year do not solve the problem. We cannot go on, as the Prime Minister has been doing, calling people in and setting up committees to try to help the Government. Does the Government not know what Australia requires? Does it not have a vision? Does it not feel what has to be done, quite apart from the intellectual pursuit of it all? The Government has a committee and sets down an agenda: How do we fix what we have created? It is an appalling reflection on a government that a Prime Minister has to produce a few committees to try to work out how he gets out of the mess that his own Government has created.

At root there is the need for restoring incentive, for cutting taxes and for getting out of the rut of trying simply time and again to raise more taxes. Genuine tax cuts financed by cutting government expenditure is the only way to revive the growth of living standards in our country. Genuine tax relief is needed now and it is only the Opposition that is prepared to advocate it.

Returning to the final element, the purpose of the legislation, which we are supporting as a consequence of the amendments that the Government has accepted, is to reduce, as I said, tax evasion by improving the Tax Office's income tax matching system. All social security beneficiaries-apart from the unemployed and those on sickness benefits-and most children will be exempt. Even for people who are registered there will be numerous financial transactions and accounts in respect of which the tax file number quotation will not be needed. For example, it will not be needed for: loan accounts of all descriptions, including mortgages, credit cards and leases; non-interest bearing cheque accounts; and existing interest bearing accounts with banks, building societies and credit unions, where the interest paid or credited each year remains below $120. Of course, it is understood that about 70 per cent of accounts with building societies and credit unions would fall below this level. It will not apply to investments subject to tax file number quotation requirements where the person is prepared to accept deduction of tax at the maximum marginal rate at the time income is paid, and to a range of investments, such as real estate and insurance bonds. Therefore any attempt to use the tax file number as the basis for collating information about a person's financial position-for example, by a credit reference bureau-would be faced with enormous gaps.

In short, I am not boasting that the Opposition is supporting the legislation, but it is thanks to the Opposition that this legislation does not contain an obligation, implied or expressed, on the part of the taxpayer to quote his or her tax file number or on the part of financial institutions or employers to require the tax file number. It is hardly the best piece of legislation to be debated in this Parliament, but it is an immense improvement on the Government's earlier Bill and, together with the privacy legislation, should not now be a threat to our civil liberties-again, thanks to the efforts of the Opposition. If the Government would listen to us on the need for tax cuts and act as readily as it did on our suggestions for amendments to this legislation, it might not be in the dire political trouble that it is in today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite many of the comments made by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), I still welcome the bipartisan approach that has finally been taken by the Opposition towards this legislation. Having served in opposition in another House, I believe it is right and proper that any Opposition under the Westminster system have a special responsibility to seek the finetuning of any legislative measures, especially those measures that would result in some removal of or threat to privacy or any attack on civil liberties, which any type of numbering system must be seen to be. It needs to be stated for the record that this has been the attitude of Government members. We have worked long and hard, we have spent many hours, particularly in the legal administrative committee, working through the provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill.
—What an excellent chairman, too.

—We have many good members who have put a lot of effort into this piece of legislation. This effort was necessary because of the known public concern and the perception in the public arena about any move by government to introduce an upgrading of a numbering system which might challenge a citizen's civil liberties or rights to privacy. It is regrettable-when this is known, when there has been a bipartisan approach and cooperation and when the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, as Acting Attorney-General, has been willing to sit down with the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), and work with all members of this Parliament to try to get it right-that we now have the honourable member for Kooyong getting up and making such statements as he did. It is an important measure. Time will demonstrate its effectiveness. It has to be recognised that all honourable members, irrespective of their political persuasion, have been concerned about the thrust of the legislation. As I said, we have laboured long and hard to get it right. We did not want to go through the unfortunate experience of the Australia Card again. Regrettably, it was misrepresented. That is why we argued long and hard to ensure that the privacy legislation which would underpin the tax file legislation was right.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members raised many concerns. I give special mention to the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) for the hours he spent working through the legislation. I do that because he made a marvellous contribution. Many of the measures now finally brought forward by way of amendment were first signalled by the honourable member for Denison. Our difficulty was that we worked within a very tight time frame. It was the Government's desire to have this in place by 1 November. When we had those inhibitions placed upon us, and when we had those difficulties before us, we had to try to move down the fast track. But the effort was made and the cooperation was given. I was pleased that it was forthcoming from the shadow Attorney as well.

This measure was never meant to be a national identification system. I take exception to the honourable member for Kooyong implying that that was probably the original intention. It was never meant to be that way. It was always meant to address the civil liberties and privacy issues. At all times, at every step we took, we argued through those issues. My personal view is that the Opposition has been looking for an escape route. It has looked long and hard to find some way out of having to support this measure. It has tried to find some way to go public and say that it was opposing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It had some good members but--

—It had some good members. I give credit to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) because he gave the original support-not that this locked his Party in, but he set the parameters of debate; he set the foundation for that support. I am pleased that ultimately the Opposition came to this House with agreement. But for the honourable member for Kooyong to talk about how this Government has had this negative impact on the citizenry of this country is nonsense. Go back and look at the measures that have been taken and the changes in the taxation system. After all, it was the Opposition when in government under Fraser that had a reputation that it has tried to live down, a reputation as the government which supported the bottom of the harbour schemes and the family trusts used by every doctor. Doctors earning $50,000 split the income to give a child of two years of age an income of $25,000 so that the doctors could avoid paying tax. It was the Liberals and Nationals that had that type of legislation in place; it was the Liberals and Nationals that promoted corporate tax trickery; and it was the Liberals and Nationals that allowed billions of dollars to be lost to honest Australians because of the way the system worked under them.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been this Government, the Hawke Labor Government, that has moved to address these problems, first by bringing fairness and equity into the tax system, by bringing the taxation rate from 60c in the dollar down to 49c in the dollar, from 48c to 40c, from 35c to 30c and from 30c to 24c and raising the tax free threshold to $5,100, and at the same time by putting in place measures that were going to help the family. What did the Opposition, when in government, do to help the families with family supplement? A family today earning $17,000, with two children, one aged 15 and one aged nine or 10, can get $50 a week tax free. If it is paying rent, it can get up to $30 as a rent supplement.

Let us see what has happened because of those tax changes. I sat in a meeting this morning and worked out the figures. A person on $300 a week at this moment is $600 a year better off under the tax system. Between 1982 and 1988 he has saved $12 a week because of the changes in the tax system. Add that to the family supplement, the rental assistance and the tax advantages and honourable members will see that we have added to those low income families something like $90 a week in purchasing power, and it is tax free. The honourable member for Kooyong has the audacity to say those things. I suggest he has really been caught. I do not think he wants to be seen as a bedfellow of the tax rorters, as his previous Government was. But I do think he has been caught in the predicament of really wanting to play politics by saying what the Opposition has now done.

I recognise the contribution made by a number of members of the Opposition as they have talked through the guidelines with the Privacy Commissioner, but they need to know that this had already been signalled by Government members. I am pleased we have come to some agreement. But as for them saying that we have to change the rule that the Privacy Commissioner only `may' bring down guidelines, if they had really talked that matter through, they would have found out that the reason why the word `may' was used and not the word `shall' is that the guidelines brought down by the Privacy Commissioner really work for the smaller issues, to help the small business person in the areas of dealing with the tax file number, securing it and posting it.

The real guidelines are as set down in the 11 principles that apply not only to the tax file number but across the board in privacy in this nation. I would have thought the Opposition would have understood that. But still, we have gained something by it, because it was again the honourable member for Denison, on the Government side, who argued for some interim guidelines. As we have considered these proposals I believe that the legislation will be better for them because they do set down some interim rules. It might have been better, as someone said and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) originally wanted, to let the powers lie with the Commissioner. But once this legislation becomes an Act let the Commissioner then go to the interest groups, to business and to the Australian privacy groups and ask, `What should the guidelines be?', because those guidelines were only to embellish those already in place under the privacy legislation.

The case for the tax file number legislation, despite its worth, is going to have to be stated over and over again, because already there are groups in the community who are trying to attack it, to distort it and to confuse people. I went on a radio program in Western Australia only last week and the person representing, unfortunately I believe, the Liberal Party there tried to make out that this was the Australia Card revisited. That is total nonsense. I was pleased with the final comments made by the honourable member for Kooyong when he talked about those people who shall be exempted. The fact is that Australia has had a tax file number system since 1936. It is not something new.

The point is that the previous system was inadequate, and we needed an upgraded tax file number system to allow the Tax Office to improve the effectiveness of its matching of the moneys earned by employees with the declarations made as to money earned. It is a matching between the declared income and the true income earned. This has not always been possible because the Tax Office has had to rely on the names and addresses of the taxpayers. It depends on what they put in their returns. I know you, Mr Deputy Speaker, with your accountancy background, would appreciate the problems that can occur because of people's bad writing and misspelling, because of names which are very similar, and because of people having bank accounts in only their middle name. There is also the problem of different addresses and changes of addresses. It is no wonder there has been a problem and that in Australia we have been able to match up properly something like only 30 per cent of income earned with income declared. That is because of the fact that we have had only the name link and the address link and there have been problems with incorrect spelling, different addresses and false names and addresses-and that has so often been the case. It has not been only errors and discrepancies; it has been avoidance.

This measure will overcome that. It will maximise the opportunity for the Tax Office, on behalf of the people of Australia, to get the tax in. If that happens, we are talking about some $2,000m over a 10-year period-a massive amount of money. It must bring down the tax burden on all Australians. It will be simple and it will be effective, because all the Tax Office will have to do is to match the tax file number assigned to the taxpayer with the tax file number supplied by the institution reporting the income, be it the employer, the banking institution or whatever. There is proof of performance on this matter, because we have seen such a tax file number system operating in the United States of America and there is a 92 per cent match and assessment rate in that country. Our system will not be perfect. We will not have a 100 per cent result, but it will be at least three times what we have now.

This measure will result in a major weapon against tax evasion and avoidance. It will mean increased revenue. It will mean that people will pay their way-and everybody should. If those who work under a pay as you earn system have to pay their way, why should those who work on a part time basis or as casual employees not also pay? It will mean an end, I believe, to a lot of tax avoidance in a number of key industries. I am talking about the industries that employ the part timers, the casual employees and the moonlighters-the people who use the false names and addresses. It will target particularly such industry employment areas as the hotels, the clubs, aged care and nursing homes and the cleaning and security industries-where there has so often been collusion with the employers.

I mention also the building industry, which we addressed in the May statement under the prescribed payments tax measures. Pseudo-subcontractors were taking a prescribed payment tax number and paying 15 per cent in some cases-although in other cases, with an exemption, they paid nothing-and that was the end of it; never again did they pay tax. One assessment held that this country was losing some $200m simply through the prescribed payment tax number arrangements because we did not have a proper system of matching; there was no way of fully matching up the pseudo-subcontractors with their real names. They were using false names and false numbers. One study showed that in one liquor trading firm 83 per cent of all employees had made false declarations as to their names and addresses, the vast majority being paid cash in hand.

I know of another study in the cleaning industry. A survey of almost 2,000 employees showed that almost 1,300 were rorting the tax system. It is not to go on. It means less tax for the community; it means also a double deduction advantage for those who rort the system and use double names. I pulled out some figures to show that a person whose ultimate income was $30,000 would pay $7,000 tax, if he paid tax on that income, but that if he were able to split the income using false names in some way, getting $15,000 from one employer under one name and $15,000 from another employer under another name, the total tax would be $5,000. So such a person could rort the system for $2,000. If we multiply that across the nation we can see that we are talking about a multi-million dollar problem. Others pay no tax at all. They moonlight; they get cash in hand. We need these measures to counter the tax fraud and the welfare cheating. We need to have an upgraded tax file system and this is the best way of doing it. This is the best counter that we have to tax evasion. An employee who does not provide a number will be taxed at the top rate. So there is now an incentive to be honest, because otherwise a person will cop the requirement to pay 49c in the dollar as well as having to pay the Medicare levy.

The scheme will also force employers to obey the law. Cases have been brought to my attention of farmers in small-crop areas who have encouraged workers to stay on the unemployment benefit. Those farmers have then paid these workers in cash in different names at below award wages. A worker says, `Fair enough, I am getting the unemployment benefit. What does it matter? I am getting cash in hand'. It is the old handful of threepences mentality that has operated particularly in some of the dairy industry areas of Queensland. Young people working in the hospitality industry have received cash in hand while often using false names. Allegedly they have been paying their own tax. Regrettably I know of cases of underpaid supporting parents-and I can understand their desire to get extra income-who are working in fast food stores. They are paid in cash but do not pay tax. I know of other cases of people on benefits who are working part time. One woman I came across in central Queensland had been working for 10 years in a firm while her husband was on an invalid pension. When she was finally caught she cried her heart out that her husband had backed her up and that she had rorted the system of tens of thousands of dollars. I know of another case in Queensland of a person in receipt of the unemployment benefit who had been hired to drive a taxi.

It is not going to be possible any more for people to engage in these sorts of activities. It is not going to be possible for part timers-those people who work as bar attendants, nursing home staff and cleaners-to do these things. This legislation will cover areas in which there is a great turnover of employees. It will cover transient workers in the States who are in receipt of the unemployment benefit.

As I have said, the tax file number is not new, but it is going to bring about greater effectiveness and integrity in the system. It will be a one-matching mechanism. I believe that it will overcome the problems. At the same time, it will provide protections which I think are warranted and which certainly have been wanted by members of the Government and, obviously, by the Opposition. The tax file system will be administered solely by the Taxation Office. Everyone needs to know that there is legislation to prohibit any organisation, employer and individual using the tax file number for any purpose other than simply to report to the Tax Office.

The system is so simple yet so strict. It cannot be used as an identity system. There will be severe penalties for misuse or breach of confidentiality. People who start a new job or change jobs will have to use their tax file number. That will be able to be matched with jobs they have had in the past or other jobs which they might hold at that moment. People will be required to quote their tax file number on an employment declaration provided to the employer. As I said before, if they do not do so, tax will be deducted at the highest rate of 49c in the dollar, plus the Medicare levy.

We will also end up stopping a lot of the welfare fraud, because those who apply for the unemployment benefit, the sickness benefit or even the Job Search allowance will also need to quote their tax file number to the Department of Social Security. Again, if they do not, tax will be deducted at the highest rate. More importantly, at the end of the day the Government and the people, through the Tax Office, will be able to get at those who are avoiding their responsibilities in the tax arena. We will be able to recover that tax. I believe that this legislation will be a deterrent to those who try to rort the system.

The important point is that the scheme does not apply to age pensioners or to veterans. As the honourable member for Kooyong said, it does not apply to the under 16-year-olds, to the vast majority of children earning money. But it will apply to those out in the work force. It will ultimately apply to all income earned, be it from dividends or interest earned from a bank account. It will mean that people shall pay their way. It has to be the objective of this Parliament to ensure that there is fairness and equity and at the same time to underpin any such measure with protections through a privacy Act. I believe that that is what this legislation will do.

It is regrettable that we had to have the asides from the honourable member for Kooyong, but I reiterate that I welcome the bipartisan approach. The people of this country need to know that this legislature, this House of Representatives, this Parliament, is really fair dinkum about solving the problems in our economy. That is being done not only by the strong economic measures that this Government has adopted, but also by putting an end to the rorts, the fraud, the misrepresentation, and the misuse and abuse of the taxation system. The measure before this House will do just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 and the Privacy Bill 1988. Although my principal concern is with the Privacy Bill, it may be appropriate if I start off with a few very brief remarks about the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill, which I will refer to as the tax file numbers Bill. The point must be made, as the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) said in his speech, that the tax file number system which the Government proposes to introduce has in fact undergone a number of very substantial changes since the day on which it was conceived in the mind of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). What we have now is a substantially more truncated system than the system he originally proposed to introduce.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose there is no more eloquent testimony to this change than the list of Government amendments which are proposed to be moved during the passage of this legislation. It is not often that Government amendments, particularly to a taxation Bill, have a ring of oddity or almost humour about them. But when one reads between the lines, the exact extent of change which has taken place to this system since the Government promoted it as the answer to all of our taxation problems in this country becomes very clear. We find that a whole host of amendments remove obligations from the tax file numbers Bill and substitute in their place provisions which simply contain statements that, for example, a particular investor is an `investor in relation to an investment to which this part applies'. That is just one example. But if one goes through the tax file numbers Bill, it becomes very clear that virtually all the obligations have now been removed from the Bill and what is left is really very little more than a complicated accounting exercise.

I think the exact operation of the Bill is not clearly understood even at this late stage. For instance, with respect to the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who has just spoken, he does not have a clear understanding of the way in which the Bill operates. For example, we heard him say that the tax file number system does not apply to children. That statement, in its all-embracing nature, is just simply untrue. In many cases it does apply to children. It does not apply to a child who is an investor as defined and who has an investment which is not one of the investments listed in the Bill. But if the child comes under any other description and has income, even although at the end of the day the income might be beneath the threshold, that child is, of course, covered by the tax file number system. In fact, I think the system has a much wider operation than the honourable member for Capricornia would have us believe.

Nevertheless, the tax file number system will now be subjected to substantial amendments in the course of the passage of the legislation. The system is put forward by the Government as a way of at least preventing some of the leakage of potential taxation revenue in this country. The Opposition has decided to support the legislation, and the Government has accepted the amendments which we have put forward. The substance of the amendments is that the scheme will now be, to a very large extent, a voluntary one. The result will be that the tax file number system will enable the Commissioner of Taxation to match numbers and ascertain whether people earning income should pay tax. As far as we are concerned that is a fair enough proposition and, with the safeguards that have been built in, it is a fair enough way of enforcing the proposition that there should be a voluntary-for that is in substance what it is-tax file number system.

As I said at the outset, my principal concern in this matter is the Privacy Bill. That Bill likewise has undergone some fairly substantial sea changes since it was conceived in whichever Minister's mind it was conceived in. I must at this stage acknowledge the work of officers of the Attorney-General's Department, who set forth with their normal professionalism once the Government decided to change its ground and came up with a substantially changed piece of legislation-one which, in my view, is better than the original Privacy Bill which was intended to be introduced.

The Privacy Bill can be seen to be divided into two parts. The first deals with what are known as information privacy principles, which will cover the collection, recording and dissemination of a wide range of information which successive governments, including the current Government, and government instrumentalities and agencies are accumulating on the individual citizen. These, of course, would have been introduced in some legislative form or another sooner or later, irrespective of the tax file number system.

It would be unfortunate if this debate went past without our making it clear that Australia has not had, until the introduction of this Bill, a privacy law. One of the advantages of the debate which has emerged over the tax file number system is that Australia will now have such a law. It will not be a perfect law by any means, but it will be a privacy law and it will be embodied in Federal legislation. That by itself is an achievement which we should not overlook in a debate which has been concentrating essentially on the tax file number and the implications for privacy of that system. As I said, the first section, if one likes to look at it in that way, of the Privacy Bill deals with general information rather than being concerned particularly with tax file number information.

The second area which the Bill deals with is the tax file number information itself; that is, the accumulated information which government instrumentalities, particularly the Commissioner of Taxation, will acquire once the tax file number system is introduced. The Bill therefore, with respect to both those areas, deals with those restrictions which in the Parliament's view it is necessary to have imposed to ensure that there is not an undue interference with the privacy of individuals, particularly those individuals to whom the information that government bodies have relates. So a series of rules is set down-I will look at some of them in a bit more detail later-with respect to general information and with respect particularly to tax file number information.

Having set down those rules and having set out a regime under which privacy is to be guaranteed in both of those areas, the Bill then deals with the question of what can be done if any of those principles are broken. If there is an invasion of privacy, whether it is because of a breach of the information privacy principles or because of a breach of the guidelines for the privacy of tax file number information itself, what will be the consequences of a breach of any of those principles? The Bill sets up a system of complaints which may be made to the Privacy Commissioner. It gives him power to conduct investigations into those complaints, it gives him power to reach conclusions about complaints that he has investigated, and it goes as far as to enable him to award compensation for the invasion of privacy. It gives the Privacy Commissioner power also to make an award of expenses in addition to the compensation which he may award. In addition to that, there is a power, which has been overlooked, for people to go to the Federal Court of Australia to obtain an injunction to prevent a breach of a provision of the Act.

That roughly is the scheme. Principles are laid down which are designed to guarantee privacy. If there are complaints that privacy has been invaded, those complaints may be investigated by the Privacy Commissioner and the Commissioner may award compensation and expenses. That structure, which has been set out in the Privacy Bill, is not a perfect system by any means-there is scope for improvement-but in our view it is a reasonable basis for starting off a privacy regime in Australia and a reasonable basis for supporting the concern for privacy, particularly in the context of a new system-namely, the tax file number system which is being introduced.

As I said, there is scope for improving this Bill by amendment. At this stage I wish to foreshadow two amendments which I will introduce in the committee stage of debate on these Bills. The first relates to the remedies which a citizen may obtain if there has been an invasion of his or her privacy. At the moment, as I have already said, the Bill provides for procedures before the Privacy Commissioner which may result in an award of compensation. It seems to me that there is a case for taking these remedies further, and I will be moving an amendment to the effect that the citizen should have the right to bring an action in the common law courts for interference with privacy and that that right should be expressed in such a way that the citizen may obtain damages as compensation for the invasion of his or her privacy.

The second amendment relates to appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which are already covered to some extent in the Bill, arising from proceedings for breaches of the information privacy principles themselves. As I have said, such appeals may give rise to an award of compensation and there is provision in the Bill for those who would be obliged to pay up to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and to get an award of compensation and expenses set aside. Oddly enough, however, there is no right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for the unsuccessful complainant. The structure is that, if he goes before the Privacy Commissioner and loses, that is the end of the day; but if a government department goes before the Privacy Commissioner and loses, it is not the end of the day for the government, which has a right to appeal. It seems to us that the citizen should have an equal right to appeal, and the amendment which I now foreshadow will incorporate that principle and give rise to that right.

I wish to add something to the proposition that the Bill is not perfect but is a reasonable start. It is now up to the Government to enforce the regime which is set out in the Privacy Bill and to make sure that it works. I say this particularly in the context of the tax file number scheme. We certainly would not be supporting the tax file number system, even with the amendments which have been made, if we had any doubts at all that the Privacy Bill provided a reasonable privacy basis for starting the system off and if we were not satisfied that the system was to be enforced. In that context particular attention should be given to the provisions which are set out in schedule 2 of the Bill and which are known as the interim guidelines concerning the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information.

It has already been said in this debate that these provisions are there, as their heading implies, to provide some privacy in respect of the tax file number information which will be collected when the tax file number Bill becomes an Act. It is important to place on record what some of them are. I think we can start off with the very important proposition that is contained in guideline No. 1: that the tax file number is not to be used as a national identification system by whatever means. I hope that those whose responsibility it is to see that the law is complied with in this field will comply with both the letter and the spirit of that proposition. The Government asserts-and already in this debate Government members have repeated-that it is not the Government's intention to use the tax file number system as a national identity system or as some pale shadow of the Australia Card which the Government attempted to have passed through this Parliament. If that is the case-and it is supported now by this proposition in the interim guidelines-we will expect to see both the letter and the spirit of that guideline enforced. If there is any evidence that comes to our notice to the effect that the tax file number system is being used, or an attempt is being made to use it, as a national identification system, by whatever means, the Government will certainly hear of it, to its regret.

I venture to say that the public will take a very dim view of any attempt by the Australian Labor Party to set up a national identification system, or national numbering system, whether directly and openly as it endeavoured to do with the Australia Card, or by some back door method which some people in the community believe it is attempting to do by means of the tax file number system. It must be said, in fairness, that there is now a guideline in the Bill which has the force of law and contains the proposition that the tax file number is not to be used as a national identification system by whatever means. We simply say that we expect the Government to enforce both the spirit and the letter of that proposition.

The guidelines go on to say that those who receive tax file numbers are not to act in an unauthorised manner so as to use the tax file number information as a means of matching personal information about a person. That is tremendously important because the great community concern is that those who have their hands on tax file numbers and the information that goes with them will use them as a means of matching up information on individuals-not just the tax file information but other information as well-and will then start to build up personal profiles on individual citizens. There is a lot of community concern that that should not happen. Again, we would expect both the law and the spirit of that guideline to be enforced. Rules are set out in the guidelines dealing with the storage and security of tax file number information. There are provisions in respect of the use and disclosure of tax file number information. Among those, the most important is that which says:
Tax file number recipients shall not use tax file number information for other than authorised purposes.

Some specific cases to which an embargo is applied are set out. They apply to employers and investment bodies which are prevented by this guideline from using the tax file number for the purpose of building up databases on individuals and from using the information for the purpose of cross-matching tax file number information with other information held about people to carry out activities which do not relate to obligations under the taxation law.

I simply conclude by saying that the rules are there. They are reasonable rules to start off with. They are not perfect, but we will now expect, having given our concession to support the Government on this legislation, that both the spirit and the letter of the law will be enforced and applied. If not, I can inform the Government at this stage that the full wrath not only of the Opposition but also of the whole Australian community will come down on it like a ton of bricks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We must forgive the Opposition for its preening and parading during the debate so far. Undoubtedly, it has contributed to the quality of the legislation before the House and we are pleased to have its support on this occasion. Its stand on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill and the Privacy Bill has been widely applauded. It is a pity that it does not adopt such a sensible position more often instead of opposing important and necessary legislation in an endeavour to make cheap political points. For instance, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) made an extravagant claim that this legislation will impact on small taxpayers in the community. That is just not true. It is only the tax evaders in this country who will be adversely affected by the legislation. Ordinary salary and wage earners already paying tax will benefit from the additional revenue gained as tax cuts will be funded partly from this source.

SPEECH.PARA: Our record on tax cuts is beyond reproach, despite what the honourable member for Kooyong said. We have progressively closed the net on tax evasion and tax avoidance, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out in his second reading speech. Income derived from capital gains is now taxed on the same basis as income derived from employment. Fringe benefits are now taxed. The deduction for entertainment has been removed and people claiming tax deductions have to maintain proper records to substantiate their claims. The proceeds of these measures have been fully devoted to cutting personal income tax rates in Australia. Tougher enforcement has applied and fewer concessions have been extended to the corporate sector. The Commissioner of Taxation has taken his duties in this area very seriously in an endeavour to maximise compliance. This is especially important, given popular perceptions, or misconceptions, in the community that companies are not paying their fair share of tax.

The Bills we are debating today represent one more link in our Government's chain of policies designed to ensure that tax is paid equally and fairly by all Australians in a position to do so. It does this by giving the Australian Taxation Office a simple and effective means of matching the income reports it receives from employers, companies and interest-paying organisations with the income declared in tax returns. Presently the Tax Office uses people's names to attempt this task. However, this method is clumsy and inefficient. It fails to match a large proportion of reports with names and addresses which are easily duplicated, coincidentally or intentionally. The use of tax file numbers with income reports enables them to be more easily checked against the returns which already exhibit the tax file number. For the bulk of Australians this Bill will have a negligible impact. For the rest, their present attempts to escape paying tax on all or part of their income deserve to be stopped. Where a tax file number is not provided, tax will be withheld at the maximum marginal rate, plus the Medicare levy. No legal penalty will be imposed. Hopefully, the mere fact that it will be withheld at that rate will ensure that people comply with the tax file number requirement.

Many people in Australia want to pay less tax. That point was made, quite rightly, by the Opposition. However, that is not possible unless everybody who should be paying tax is doing so. It is expected that by 1993-94, $337m extra will be collected annually as a consequence of this legislation. In his second reading speech, the Treasurer estimated that over the next 10 years this legislation will return $2,200m to the revenue, all of which will be redistributed in the form of tax cuts. The provisions of this Bill should, therefore, ensure that the honest taxpayer with no easy way to disguise his or her income will feel that all people are sharing the burden of taxation to the extent that they are meant and able to, rather than thinking that some people are taking unfair advantage of the taxes paid by others.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I know that the honourable member for Denison feels very strongly about this.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the extent of the problem? The Australian Taxation Office receives two major types of income reports: details of group certificates and of interest payments. Each year about one million group certificates are not reported in tax returns; nor can they be matched because of wrong addresses and false names. The statistics for interest payments are even worse. About four million, or 30 per cent, cannot be matched to anyone's return. I note that the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) pointed out this percentage in his speech. The difficulty of being able to match reports and claims by name and address is the major factor preventing the Tax Office from collecting the taxes due.

Some people have claimed that this Bill is an imposition, but upon whom does it impose? It imposes upon those who evade tax by using false names and addresses; for instance, someone who has more than one job and does not acknowledge the extra job on his or her return-the moonlighters referred to by the honourable member for Capricornia. It imposes upon someone who has money invested in accounts which are not declared or someone who has no tax file number because he or she has never paid tax on earnings. These are the people who will be affected.

I remind the House of what happened when the prescribed payments system was first proposed and of the concern that appeared to exist in the community of people who refused to accept the system. I was approached by several people at that time even though I was not a member of parliament. They expressed their concern to me. I said, `But if you already have a tax number you will not have to worry'. They were very quiet because they did not have a tax number. If they do not have a tax number they have not been paying tax. I suggest to the House that this Bill will overcome a lot of those problems, as has already occurred in other industries with the prescribed payments system. We all know of cases of people who do not pay tax even though they are working. The honourable member for Capricornia provided some graphic examples of these. The legislation may well be an imposition for those who evade tax but it will be a welcome relief for those who do not. Some people arrange their affairs so that companies receive the fruits of their investments, rather than receive the income themselves. The provisions of this Bill apply to the person who has the right to receive the income, not an in-between nominal company. They will therefore pay tax.

How will the Bill affect ordinary employees, that is, pay as you earn taxpayers? Such people already have a number which they quote on their tax return. They will now be asked to add that number to the form they fill in each year to allow their employer to take deductions from their wages. In this way the number will be sent to the Tax Office twice-once from the employee and once from the employer, enabling the matching. People will have a year from July 1990 to June 1991 in which to notify their bank, building society or investment body of their tax file number. Again, the process is simple and allows the Tax Office to make an easy comparison. For people commencing employment the Tax Office will issue a number upon application. This can be done either at the Tax Office or at any post office where application forms can be acquired. Only two pieces of identification will be needed.

As mentioned earlier, the cost of not providing a number is to have tax withheld at the maximum marginal rate plus the Medicare levy. If this is more than the taxpayer should pay, the money can be recovered when a tax return is submitted. Clearly there are certain types of people who should be exempted from the provisions of this Bill since their income is known and fixed. They were mentioned in passing by the honourable member for Capricornia and the honourable member for Kooyong. For instance, people on pensions-age, invalid, wife's, carer's and widow's pensions, supporting parents and veterans-and most children under 16 are exempted from using a tax file number. If they have any investments such people will only have to submit a declaration of their name, address and category of exemption. I take the point of the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) about children who have substantial earnings or investments having to use the tax file number. I think that is only fair, because they are earning income and ought to be declaring it in a substantive fashion.

At this point it may be useful to remind members of the House and others of the uses to which taxes are put. All too often we concentrate upon how much has been taken by government as taxation without considering what this money is used for. The majority of taxation is returned to the community in the form of pensions, basic services and the infrastructure which we use every day. Without going into the full details of all the government services provided through taxation revenue, it is clear that the people at whom this Bill is aimed are making use of most of those services without paying their share of the cost. They are riding on the back of existing taxpayers. This cannot be allowed to continue.

A major concern which has been expressed about this Bill is that it may infringe upon people's rights of privacy. This concern is mainly the result of a misunderstanding of what the Bill does. I accept the contribution of the Opposition and members of my Party to the debate on the privacy legislation. I believe that the Government has made the correct decisions. Tax file numbers have existed since 1936 as the best means of clearly identifying each taxpayer. Names are one way in which we attempt to distinguish ourselves from other people, but because they are not unique they do not provide the same certainty as a tax file number. The number should help to remove any possibility of people with identical names being mixed up by the Tax Office. We can all cite common names in a fairly common employment area where there could be some confusion.

The tax file number will now be known to employers and investment bodies. They will use it only when conveying payment details to the Tax Office and will have no access to other tax records. Some have likened the strengthened tax file number to the Australia Card in an attempt to create unjustified concern in the community. Tax file numbers already exist and they are not demanded as a form of identification other than by the Tax Office. Furthermore, it will be an offence to require the number's disclosure or its use as identification other than for purposes which are sanctioned by this Bill. People who endeavour to misuse the number in this way will be liable to a fine or two years gaol.

This Bill also strengthens the penalties for unauthorised disclosure of taxpayer information by Tax Office staff. Such provisions already exist to protect information given by taxpayers, but for honest taxpayers that information will now be even more secure. The privacy legislation being introduced into the Parliament also covers the disclosure of information by public services. Unfortunately, information in the hands of private organisations is still not regulated. This is an area of considerable concern to many people in the community. I am hopeful that the Government will look at it in the near future.

Some members of the Opposition apparently did not wish to support this Bill because it represented an extension of the powers of the Tax Commissioner. The fact that the Tax Commissioner was going to have more power and that he has extended his powers in the area of corporate compliance was recently pointed out in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. However, I believe that the Tax Commissioner is to be congratulated for his endeavours in this area. These endeavours may not concern the average Australian who is not cheating the system. The Commissioner is to be admired for his endeavours to administer the taxation laws so assiduously to the benefit of the whole nation. His stand is totally supported by the Government and should also be supported by the Opposition. We have given the Tax Office the necessary resources, staff and equipment to do its job properly and we are prepared to back it to the hilt. This Bill will help ensure that all Australians pay their fair share of tax. The only people who will be adversely affected are those who currently evade tax. The rest of the community will benefit from the availability of a significant amount of additional revenue which will contribute to overall tax cuts. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 and the Privacy Bill 1988. The manner in which these Bills were introduced is an absolute disgrace to the Government. The Privacy Bill, in particular, was introduced only yesterday afternoon. It was compiled in haste. It has not been before this Parliament. There has been no public exposure of that document. Today we are debating that Bill-with the support, I must say, of the Opposition. I want to point out what an absolute disgrace this whole thing has been. I am sure that this legislation was informally introduced and exposed to members of the Opposition by the Government on the basis that it would act as some type of mechanism for a double dissolution-something which in this Parliament helps only the Government and the Australian Democrats-because the Opposition would react on the basis of the three conditions it laid down after the identification card legislation fiasco. Luckily, because of amendments that have been rightfully proposed by the Opposition and accepted by the Government, this proposal will in no way act as an unofficial identification card system, which had been the suspicion of many groups outside. In fact, the way in which we have ensured that the tax file number will not be a de facto identification card is that the tax file number scheme is now voluntary, and not compulsory, as it was originally when it was intended that the tax file number would have to be used in the declaration of interest and dividends. I can understand in every way the suspicion of the public about the way in which these Bills have been introduced and the manner in which the attempt was made to introduce the ID card last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that we now have to recognise the problems facing the Australian Taxation Office and look at the positive consequences of this legislation. When I say that we should recognise the problems facing the Taxation Office, I add, as a practising public accountant for many years-as I think you were, Mr Deputy Speaker-that it has always been a big concern to me that, while such powers were always contained in the Tax Acts, the Taxation Office never took the steps to use those powers as it should have. Even though the Taxation Office made the employer and investor comply with certain instructions about the lodgment of lists of interest and dividend payments and the matching up of wages payments at the end of the year-and there are very many honest taxpayers, employers and investors in the community who complied-it never took the trouble of trying to match that information in the way it should have. In fact, it was acknowledged in evidence, I think to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card which was set up last year or the year before, that only 20 per cent of forms detailing interest and dividend payments lodged with the Taxation Office were ever matched. I can understand how this could have been the case with the primitiveness of the Taxation Office's computer system.

While on this subject of matching of information, it would probably not be understood by taxpayers and the public generally-as was revealed in evidence given by the Tax- ation Office just recently-that it is not possible for it to do more than aggregate the incomes which are listed under the tax file numbers with people's tax returns. It is not possible actually to detail separately the sources of income and to list that. It is possible for the Taxation Office only to aggregate the amounts, which then provides a profile which should then agree with taxpayers' returns.

Before we go any further I think that we should also remove the suspicion that these Bills will have something to do with tax avoidance. We are talking here purely about tax evasion: the tax cheats, the people who earn income and do not declare it, the people who get payment in cash and use that for their own purposes without declaring it. As I think has already been determined by an eminent judge overseas, any taxpayer has the right to arrange his or her affairs, within the legal framework, to minimise personal taxation. There are aspects of the tax Act which allow that minimisation. I believe that we should focus on that aspect of the legislation that deals with tax evasion, and that anyone seeking to minimise tax should have nothing to fear while he or she provides a tax return within the framework of the taxation law at the time.

We are talking about tax cheating. It surprises me that the Taxation Office estimates that tax cheating amounts to just over $2.2 billion over 10 years. I think that the Taxation Office claims that in the tenth year an amount of $330m will be recovered permanently as a result of the introduction of the tax file number. Of course, that amount of $300m in the context of the total amount of some $58 billion of income tax paid by the community is not a large amount. However, I believe, as would any honest taxpayer, that it is only right and fair that this tax should be collected.

I feel that there are two aspects as far as honest taxpayers are concerned: they believe that taxes are too high; they also believe that people who are cheating the system, as some do, should not be allowed to get away with it. The other feeling that honest taxpayers have these days is one of persecution by the Taxation Office in regard to taxation. They feel that the Taxation Office is almost a police department in the manner in which it prosecutes and makes demands of honest taxpayers. Therefore, honest taxpayers are copping it both ways: they are paying too much tax because of the cheats and are being persecuted because they are honest.

Perhaps someone along the line has tried to identify the psychology of tax cheats. I would be surprised if those sitting in the advisers' gallery had not applied their minds to this on many occasions. While I am not in the position of knowing the exact psychological make-up of a tax cheat-some are just thieves taking from the public purse-I suggest that some of their personality make-up is a result of government action. For example, the high rate of taxation, as I have already mentioned, is an incentive for people who might want to do so to cheat the system by non-disclosure of their incomes. Also, the Government's excessive expenditure over five years has created for taxpayers a $25 billion debt which they will have to pay off in the future and on which certainly they will have to pay the interest. I think that taxpayers look at the other side of the Commonwealth balance sheet to see how their money is being spent.

I suggest also that part of the psychological make-up of tax cheats is created by the double standards applied by the Australian Taxation Office. I can give two examples of this. I give as an example a taxpayer who had to pay a late lodgment fee on his return, even though there was a credit due and a tax rebate followed-compared with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who was allowed the same benefit of non-lodgment but did not have to pay the penalty in precisely the same situation. These are the double standards that apply right across this nation. I enunciate another example: the travelling allowance situation in which the Treasurer was involved three or four years ago. People in exactly the same situation but with more justifiable concerns have come to me because the Taxation Office applied the other standard of not allowing the travelling allowance to be tax deductible, although eventually it was allowed. Yet we have the double standard of the Treasurer being treated as a separate case. These are things that tell on the average taxpayers. They are matters of great concern to them, because they are up for the additional costs of compliance in ensuring that their fair share of tax is paid.

Also, there is the aspect of the personality make-up of the tax cheats resulting, year by year, or day by day, from a reduction in their living standards and the quality of life which they would like members of their families and people around them to enjoy. I am in no way condoning the tax cheat, but I think that we have to understand that within this economy there are circumstances which have resulted solely from the action of the Taxation Office and the Government.
