I refer now to the complexity of the taxation law, which makes it quite impossible for not just the average taxpayers but also the legal experts to understand-unless they specialise in a specific branch of the taxation law. With an Act of probably 2,000 pages we can understand the frustration people must feel in saying, `Hang the whole thing; let's get on with more productive business'. However, I want to say again that I do not condone in any way the actions of the tax cheat.

There is also the other case of how government interferes in the lives of all Australians, and certainly taxation is the most intrusive. There is a suspicion, which is natural in these cases, that expenditure is used by a government to control the lives of people in the community who are taxpayers in the normal sense, just ordinary Australians. It controls organisations by partly funding them and then taking control. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, would understand that this is precisely the case with Medicare and the medical fraternity. The more recent example of the rescheduling of the pathology fees is an indication of how the Government was trying to control the activities of pathologists in private practice and in nursing homes. These are examples of areas in which there is complete control over the activities of ordinary Australians. No wonder some of them are screaming.

I believe that this Government has changed Australians from being carers to being survivors. I fear most for the survival of taxpayers in this country. The Government seems to be content to have a survival program in place for others, but the taxpayers in this country have received very little consideration from this Government. So all these natural suspicions have made the acceptance of both these pieces of legislation difficult.

I mentioned that there is already legislation that the Government might have been able to act upon, but in these modern days it is just not possible with the staff available and the complexity of the economy to be able to do this in the form that might have been wanted when that legislation was enacted. The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) mentioned fairness and equity in his address. I say to the honourable member, who has said that he has been instrumental to a large extent in the formation of the Privacy Bill, that there is no fairness and equity in a situation where we have to consider legislation that has not even been introduced, which has not been disclosed for public comment and is then rushed in to us at the eleventh hour. There is no fairness where the set-up date was 1 November and the Privacy Bill was not in front of us. We ask: How fair and equitable was this legislation that made the Opposition amendments so necessary and so acceptable to the government of the day? I also take up the honourable member's comments about the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and his record in this regard. No Treasurer in this country has done more to stop tax evasion and tax avoidance than the former Treasurer did with the raft of legislation that came in in 1982. I recall a comment made by a member of the Opposition and by people who were practising in this industry beforehand. They said, `The tax evasion and avoidance industry is dead. It was killed by the introduction of that division back in 1982 to the tax Act'. I think that the honourable member for Capricornia has been less than fair in his comments on that subject.

Let us talk about the fairness and equity of the scheme that we already have in Australia which has been implemented by this Government. I have already mentioned the lack of fairness and equity and referred to the double standards. I have also referred to the fringe benefits tax. There is nothing fair or equitable about the fringe benefits tax. I can recall when the Treasurer of the day came in here and indicated that a fringe benefits tax would be imposed against the earner of that income-the employee. Within 24 hours the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions said that a fringe benefits tax would not be imposed against the employee. The next day the Treasurer came into this House and said that it would be imposed against the employer. Where is there fairness and equity in that system? We have talked in terms of self-assessment and all the other necessities for a taxpayer to claim a deduction. All this has been at a tremendous cost of compliance for the taxpayer. I will give an indication. Last year I had to spend three times the amount of time I normally devote to the preparation of my tax return just to make sure that the compliance measures that had been built up by the Taxation Office had been enforced.

TALK.START.PARA: —An honest taxpayer.

—A very honest taxpayer, I might add; I cannot afford to be other than that. I just give that as an example of the tremendous cost of compliance for the taxpayer and the tax agent. I mentioned earlier that this tax file number system is not an identification card. While with the identification card system disclosure was voluntary in the original Act as far as the salary and wages content was concerned, it certainly was not voluntary in connection with the interest and dividends. Now it is voluntary and a withholding tax of 50.25 per cent is the price that one pays for non-disclosure. One wonders under those circumstances-unless a person is prepared to save up a credit for eventual refund at the end of June-whether that is really a voluntary system. But at least it does provide an alternative to noting identification.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill provides for exemptions, as outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech. They apply to age pensioners, veterans and most children. They do not apply to those on unemployment or sickness benefits. But in every other respect the exemption is there for the age pensioners and veterans and for children who earn minimal income and would not be taxed. As the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown), mentioned in response to the honourable member for Capricornia, who did not know his own legislation, children can be caught under this Act in certain places. There are exemptions where accounts earn interest of less than $120 a year, which we believe will exempt about 70 per cent of people who have money in credit unions. The Government talks about a universal identification. That cannot be so when so many exemptions exist, and also in view of the voluntary nature of the provisions introduced by the Opposition.

There are still concerns with this legislation. As much as we would have liked to have had access to the legislation to propose amendments, other than the amendments we have already proposed, I think it must be recognised that there will be faults in legislation that has been so hastily introduced into this place without that disclosure. We still do have concerns with this legislation. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has already mentioned function creep and how it should not be allowed by successive regulation or amending legislation to apply in areas other than those it is intended to apply to at the moment. I know that is the concern of people overseas who have used the system-that function creep seems to be a necessary part of change into the future. I also believe that the penalties set up under the Privacy Act should be fully and rigorously applied because, unless they are, there could quite well be deficiencies in the system caused by those who want to apply somebody's tax file number in ways other than the terms of the Act. There is also the aspect of the rate of the withholding tax, which is at the maximum rate, and, of course, that applies the maximum difficulty. Perhaps one should suggest that after the Act has been in place for a while a more realistic assessment might be made of the rate of that withholding tax other than the high rate that is there at the moment.

Finally, let us hope that, as this money is meant to be collected from the people who have been cheating the system, relief will be given, as the Government has promised for next July, to honest taxpayers and that we do see a significant decrease in the rates of tax which currently apply. I believe all these things should be drawn to the notice of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill has, in my view, three major pluses. Firstly, it is endeavouring to crack down on the tax avoidance industry which, despite the assurances from the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) in his contribution, still does exist, unfortunately, notwithstanding anything that the former Liberal Treasurer, the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), may have done in 1982. Secondly, it attacks the problem for the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) of matching incomes from all sources. Thirdly, as has been said by honourable members on both sides of this chamber today in the debate, it is not an identification system-de facto or whatever. I propose to look at each of those issues during my contribution this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I will just make one or two comments about the contributions by the honourable member for Dawson and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). There was some discussion about function creep. They expressed the view that they hoped the tax file number system would not spread to additional functions. The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) also mentioned what happened in the United States. I have some knowledge of this as well. An American friend of mine with whom I recently corresponded on this issue indicated that, for example, in the State in which he lives he is given a social security number. That number is also his tax file number, his motor vehicle drivers licence number and his motor boat licence number. He is an airline pilot by profession and therefore it is his licence number in the aviation industry. It is also the number with which he pays municipal rates and a whole swag of other charges, such as electricity. If we are talking about function creep and problems such as this, I think we have a long way to go to catch up with some of the examples in the United States. Nevertheless, some of the concerns expressed by the honourable member for Kooyong and the honourable member for Dawson, I guess, in some respects, are quite real.

The honourable member for Dawson is stretching the point when he speaks of honest taxpayers being caught in the net, as it were, and being hounded and chased by the police that are the Australian Taxation Office. Quite honestly, the honest taxpayers today-they would basically be those in the pay as you earn system-are caught up in self-assessment. As has been indicated, the compliance function in this case has increased dramatically because of this system's introduction and, indeed, because of the various other measures introduced over the years by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Australian Taxation Office to crack down on all forms of tax evasion and avoidance. I think that is appropriate.

I would like briefly to trace through some examples of work done by this Parliament to strengthen the case for this tax file number issue not being one of controversy but one of universal acceptance by honourable members. It has often been said-indeed the honourable member for Dawson said it-that the legislation on privacy did not come forward in time for people to consider it. We can see from the examples of the workings of this Parliament that this issue of tax file numbers has indeed received considerable debate over a long period through the committee structure. I would like to point to a number of examples of that today. Firstly, I point to the majority report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I accept that the Australia Card legislation was defeated but it is interesting to note that in paragraphs 4.8 and 4.19 the report states:
The present tax file number has very low integrity . . . The majority of the Committee considers as an appropriate option the upgrading of the tax file number . . .

So as far back as when that report was tabled, in May 1986, the majority-that is, both sides of the Parliament; indeed, all political parties in this Parliament-recommended and recognised the need for an upgrading of the tax file number system. In September 1986 a report entitled A Taxing Problem: Review of 5 Auditor-General's Efficiency Audit Reports into the Australian Taxation Office was tabled in this place. That report was compiled by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure which, with the restructuring of committees after 1987, disappeared. It looked at several efficiency audits: the collection of sales tax by the Australian Taxation Office, controls over processing of income tax assessments, processing the assessment of income tax returns, checking of dividends and interest disclosed in income tax returns and, finally, the processing of income tax instalment declarations. Opposition members of that Committee included the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), who was Chairman of the subcommittee that carried out that investigation and was Deputy Chairman of the Committee; the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who is the shadow spokesperson on transport and communications; the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb); the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker); the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith); and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan). All of those Opposition members were members of that Committee and subcommittee that investigated those particular areas and saw fit to put their names on a report to which there were no dissenting views. Recommendation 18 of that report stated:

With or without the adoption of the Australia Card, the Australian Taxation Office take the necessary steps to establish a high integrity identification system which would ensure maximum taxpayer compliance.

That report was dated September 1986. That was after a thorough process of review, conducting public hearings, interviewing people with concerns in the taxation field with those efficiency audits and coming up with that unanimous recommendation.

On the matter of evasion and avoidance, a report entitled Tax Evasion and the Tax Office's Response-an Audit Office view was delivered to the Australian Tax Research Foundation conference on 13 and 14 June 1987. In the course of that paper a number of examples were given by people from the Audit Office of problems in the tax area. I will give some of those examples. They looked at group certificates that showed earnings above $20,000, presumably from the taxpayers' main source of income. They took a second sample of group certificates showing mainly low incomes, probably from second jobs. The intention of that was to try to work out from the taxpayers' returns whether undisclosed income from second jobs, dividends, interest, Department of Social Security benefits or false claims for spouse rebate could be detected. A second sample was taken of unpresented group certificates prepared by 39 employers from industries known to employ part time or casual employees-employees such as caterers, cleaning contractors, clubs, hotels, nursing homes and restaurants. It is interesting that the examination of unpresented group certificates and other records found many cases where assessments had been issued but the ATO procedures had failed to discover omitted income because of processes in the ATO at the time, particularly on matching. As honourable members have said in debate this morning, the matching problem to date has been one of trying to match names and addresses with appropriate people. I will say a little bit more about that when I talk about more recent committee examples and how this issue is being tackled. In this paper presented by representatives of the Auditor-General's Office it was concluded:
There is clearly a need for the employees to be better identified on group certificates so that unpresented group certificates can be allocated to taxpayers' returns by means of computer processing.
Computer processing should also assist in detecting false claims for spouse rebate and, if extended further, in detecting undisclosed benefits from the Department of Social Security.

I am sure that every member of this House supports the need to act upon that independent assessment made from case studies done by the Australian Auditor-General's Office and reported at a conference on taxation and the underground economy. In that report reference was made to computerisation and the need to upgrade facilities within the Australian Taxation Office.

We move on to yet another committee of the Parliament which has examined this issue and the question of matching. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts, comprising both members and senators, in 1987 presented report 287 entitled Australian Taxation Office: Computer System Re-equipment and Redevelopment. The Opposition members of that Committee included Senator Watson, as the Vice-Chairman, Senator Bishop, the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) and the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) who, of course, is the shadow finance Minister. That report, when detailing its examination of computer re-equipment in the Tax Office and how it might be applied, looked at the issue of the Australia Card, income matching and other identification processes that may be necessary. The Committee noted at paragraph 5.21:
. . . income matching activities of the ATO involved substantially manual processes and that they relied heavily on paper documents.
I think we would all agree that that is not appropriate. However, it went on to say:

Unless you have a unique identifier with an acceptable degree of integrity, you are putting a lot of effort into gathering information which you cannot effectively and efficiently match with taxpayer returns.
The ATO, in evidence to that Committee, which was accepted by the Committee, said at paragraph 5.30 on page 68:
. . . our analysis says also that if you had a unique numbering system you could probably improve the efficiency of (the matching) process by 50 or 60 per cent.
It went on further to say, at paragraph 5.32:
It was clear to the Committee that there were substantial benefits to be gained through the Australia Card or some equivalent high integrity numbering system.
Paragraph 5.37, on page 69 of the Public Accounts Committee report, states:

The Committee notes that the matching of dividends, interest and other income with taxpayer records is a vitally important part of the work undertaken by the ATO. The Committee notes that while the matching programs already conducted are highly revenue productive they involve substantial manual processes and are heavily reliant on paper documents.
It concluded, therefore, at paragraph 5.39 that:

the development and use of a high integrity numbering system could give the Australian Taxation Office the potential to maximise the improvements in its operations that are anticipated from the Office's computer systems re-equipment and redevelopment proposal.

There we again have that example from the processes of the Parliament examining, through public hearings, through the receipt of information from government departments and the like, further evidence to substantiate the need for the tax file number system that has been introduced into this House. More recently, in May 1988, a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled A Taxing Review. Review of Six Efficiency Audits of the Australian Taxation Office was tabled in this place. The audits which were undertaken in this review were: the prescribed payments system, unpresented group certificates, external sources of information, disclosure of diesel fuel rebates, partnership and trust distributions and late lodgment penalties. The membership of that Committee included from the Opposition benches the honourable member for Sturt as Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Dawson who is, of course, the shadow Minister for community services and aged care, the honourable member for Parkes, again the honourable member for Wentworth who is the shadow finance spokesman, and the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur). Again a bipartisan report was handed down based on evidence and on the parliamentary system of conducting thorough inquiries. At recommendation 13, on page 69 of that report, it was again stated:
The ATO to take the necessary steps to establish a high integrity identification system which would ensure maximum taxpayer compliance.

We then moved to the final example that I wish to bring to the attention of the House today, and that is of an ongoing inquiry, the results of which will probably be tabled in this House next week. Again it is an inquiry into an efficiency audit report conducted by the Auditor-General's Office into the Australian Taxation Office and involves taxpayers in unincorporated businesses. Once again it is the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration which is carrying out this inquiry which, of course, I chair. The Auditor-General's efficiency audit report-this is not the Tax Office or some group out in the community; it is the Australian Auditor-General's Office-states at paragraph 7.2.5 at page 43:
The AAO agrees that systems effectively assigning a unique identifying number to individuals would provide a basis for resolving the present difficulties.

Those difficulties that were identified were of course, associated with taxpayers and unincorporated businesses, the examples that were used being restaurants in Hobart, home builders in Canberra and home unit owners on the Gold Coast and the Sunshine Coast in Queensland. The Auditor-General therefore stated-I reiterate that this is the Australian Audit Office; it is not the ATO or a group in the community; it is not even a government department that is responsible for the tax system per se-in recommendation 44:

. . . the ATO develop a high integrity unique identification system for all taxpayers which will provide full cross-referencing of relationships among companies, partnerships, trusts and individual taxpayers including those whom the ATO exempts from having to lodge returns.

It did so because on the evidence that it had collated in that audit it found there was still a degree of non-compliance and a degree of evasion and avoidance in the wider community. By going through and looking at those various efficiency audits handed down by the Tax Office, and in looking at the process whereby the Parliament, both the Senate and the House of Representatives, can go through this process of a scrutiny of recommendations, it clearly concluded that an upgraded and improved tax file number system was essential in combating tax avoidance and tax evasion. I believe it has been proven conclusively, by those examples and by the process, that that is the case.

I am pleased that the Opposition parties have chosen to support this legislation. I would certainly like to know whether any Opposition members of the committees that I have referred to argued strongly one way or the other in their party rooms on this issue, because I think on the evidence that has been presented to the committees on which they sat, they would clearly have to come out in its favour.

The privacy issue is one which has also raised some concern. In the minute or so that I have left I would make this comment: concern was expressed about the time in which some members of the Opposition had to review that legislation. That surprises me, given what I read as the events over the last several weeks, when Opposition spokesmen involved in the privacy legislation and so on had a more than ample opportunity to discuss what the Government was proposing, not only with advisers in departments, but also with the Ministers responsible for the carriage of this legislation. Clearly the Government has been prepared to accept some of the concerns, indeed all of the concerns, that the Opposition has raised. I am pleased, therefore, that the Bills will today receive passage through this House and presumably also later through the Senate, and that this legislation will take effect. Once again, those honest taxpayers will have nothing to fear. The scaremongering tactics that may be used by certain groups in the community will not be necessary. I am sure that my friend, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who is about to speak in the debate for our side, will testify that the privacy provisions of the legislation will more than safeguard the taxpayers' interests. I welcome the support from the Opposition members for this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The great deal of behind the scenes activity prior to the introduction of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill gives some indication of the great uncertainty in both the coalition and the community at large as to the intentions of both the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his colleagues in the Labor Government. My outright opposition to the tax file number (TFN) as originally proposed is well known. Despite the Opposition's agreement to an amended form of legislation, I wish to state for the record that I still have very grave reservations about the ultimate aim of the Treasurer's new tax file numbering system. So as not to be misconstrued or misrepresented, I say now, as I have always said: tax avoidance must be stamped out. Those who profit from it do so at the expense of the majority of honest hard-working Australians who have, under the crushing tax policies of this Government, seen their standard of living decline quite significantly.

SPEECH.PARA: Overtly, the Government says that its intention in introducing this Bill is to clamp down on tax avoidance. However, the system with which it proposes to do that has the capacity to be applied well beyond the needs of the Australian Taxation Office. It is not a dedicated system; it is a multi-purpose system. In other words, it could become a de facto Australia Card with subsequent enabling legislation over time. The Government's attempt to foist the Australia Card on the Australian people was, as we all know, pursued with a fanaticism rarely seen in this Parliament. Are we now to believe that an issue so vigorously pursued by this Labor Government has been dropped from its agenda altogether? I for one do not believe that to be the case.

From the time when the Treasurer first announced the expanded tax file number system, precious little of the facts have emerged-and very little of the truth. The new Australian Labor Party branch office at No. 2 Constitution Avenue here in Canberra, formerly known as the Australian Taxation Office, has waged a campaign deliberately to muddy the waters of the TFN. The Taxation Office's submission to the Senate Standing Committee inquiring into the TFN was of such poor quality that the Committee told the Tax Office to go away and come back with some properly researched facts and figures. The Tax Office, in its first submission, failed to provide any breakdown of revenue estimates. It failed to take account of any contra-revenue outgoings and its treatment of alternative schemes was cursory and dismissive, being confined to generalities and with no proper analysis.

Although the Senate Standing Committee, in its majority report concluded that, on balance, the TFN would result in a significant increase in revenue, it also said it `had some difficulties with aspects of the estimates, in particular with the basis of their compilation'. Before the Senate Committee, officers from the Taxation Office provided figures indicating that the likely revenue gains by 1994 would total $337m. However, in later evidence before the Committee, the Tax Office made certain concessions. It said that the revenue estimates were gross and did not take account of refunds. This was despite the fact that a Taxation Office pilot survey showed that more than 50 per cent of those who failed to present group certificates were likely to be entitled to refunds. It was apparent that no allowance had been made for the current tax amnesty under which 275,000 persons have filed tax returns, resulting in substantial revenue gain likely to exceed $100m. These funds would obviously reduce the potential revenue gains available from the TFN.

The revenue estimates contained an allowance for increased voluntary compliance, but the Tax Office was unable to quantify the extent of this figure. Even with the use of a unique identifier, approximately 70 per cent of the interest which currently goes untaxed could still go untaxed. Little has changed. It was unclear to what extent the estimated allowance for interest of $204m took this factor into account.

Some four million children under the age of 16 and 2.4 million pensioners would not be required to register under this scheme. These perfectly proper exemption categories would nonetheless provide irresistible temptations to deposit interest and dividend money into the bank accounts of children and pensioners.

One area of cost consideration that has received no mention whatsoever, and is in fact one of the most important, is the cost to private enterprise of the TFN system. As far as I can ascertain, the Taxation Office has not produced any cost estimates for this area, despite the fact that the requirements of the TFN legislation impose extremely costly compliance and reporting procedures on all employers and investment bodies. Without doubt, these costs will eventually have to be borne by consumers themselves, adding further to the cost of living; and, as I said earlier, Australians have already suffered a very significant decline in their standard of living under this Government.

I have searched my conscience long and hard on this piece of legislation. Stamping out tax avoidance is a must for any government. However, the method of doing so is just as important. In supporting the Opposition's amendments to this Bill, I strike a note of warning. Future exploitation of this proposed legislation by the Labor Government is a real possibility, given its fanatical endeavours to impose the Australia Card on the community. Turning the TFN system into an Australia Card could become a gradual fait accompli.

In striking this note of warning, I remind the House that similar numbering systems in the United States and Canada-and this has already been referred to in this debate here this morning-began as dedicated, limited systems, but soon became universal identity systems. Furthermore, the success of the Government's privacy legislation is in large part dependent upon its commitment to the new bureaucratic body set up to administer it. To be effective, the new privacy body will need to be well resourced. However, the Government has a very bad track record in relation to the various oversight bodies for which it has responsibility. There have been very substantial reductions to the resources of the Auditor-General's Office-and that has been referred to in debate in this place and in the outside community-and also, of course, to the resources of the Parliament's Joint Committee of Public Accounts. That, too, has been a matter of public debate and concern.

The Government has even frustrated the access of ordinary Australians to documents under the freedom of information (FOI) legislation. It is well known that a $30 fee is now payable upon application; further charges are imposed by the Department concerned to service the FOI request; a $40 fee is payable for a departmental internal review; and if, as occurs all too regularly nowadays, an FOI applicant is forced to take a matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, a further fee of $240 is payable. I wonder how long it will be before the Government moves to frustrate community access to the Office of the Privacy Commissioner through the imposition of fees and charges, as we have already seen in relation to FOI requests and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

I referred earlier to the Taxation Office's deliberate attempts to muddy the waters on the TFN. Part of those efforts was certainly its inaction in servicing a freedom of information request concerning the TFN proposal that I submitted to it on 30 June of this year. The FOI legislation requires that departments receiving FOI requests service them within 30 days. To date I have received no documents from the Australian Taxation Office, despite it being today day 125 since my FOI request was submitted. The Constitution Avenue branch of the Labor Party has done its bit towards frustrating informed public debate on the TFN, yet again.

In concluding my remarks, I say that a degree of acceptability of this legislation has been achieved through the Opposition's amendments to the tax file number legislation and also, of course, to the Privacy Bill. From here on in, great vigilance must be exercised by this Parliament to ensure that the Government does not enlarge and expand the TFN system to fulfil its earlier aims as manifested in the Australia Card proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate as it has progressed today has seen speakers from both sides of the House claiming victory for the manner in which the legislation has come forward. But the real winners are the people of Australia, because two very important social steps have been taken. Firstly, we have a measure that will ensure that tax avoidance is substantially reduced and, in some areas, eliminated. Secondly-and to date this very important part of the debate has not been highlighted-some very far-reaching protections of privacy will be brought into our law for the very first time.

SPEECH.PARA: In referring to these matters, I might congratulate both the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who has been responsible for the conduct of the privacy legislation, and the Opposition spokesperson. Notwithstanding the shadow boxing and the claims as to who has best served the Australian people in this process, the end result has been a piece of legislation which, years on, we will look back at and about which we will say, `That was the beginning of a very important period in Australia's social development when we began to protect privacy in a serious way'. We will look at this as a foundation for further steps in the protection of privacy of individuals, not just in the public sector but also in the private sector-a point I will return to later.

Let me first look at the situation regarding the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988. We have had today from the Opposition what must be the most lukewarm support for the proposals that one could imagine. It really does seem that, notwithstanding the Opposition's agreement yesterday to support this legislation, there are still many members of the Opposition who would take opportunistic advantage of creating the kind of hysteria in the community that measures of this sort can so easily engender. We have just had a good example of that kind of nonsense from the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), who, not content with raising spectres that have no substance at all, denigrated the Commissioner of Taxation, claiming that he was somehow an Australian Labor Party stooge. This is the kind of personal and trivialised nonsense that the Opposition is substituting for policy on taxation.

Let us look at what has happened in this instance. No-one disputes that substantial sums of revenue are being evaded illegally by persons who should be paying tax. In the couple of instances where studies have taken place and industries have been subjected to exhaustive scrutiny, the Commissioner of Taxation has produced documented evidence that companies and individuals are ripping off honest taxpayers literally to the tune of millions of dollars. For example, there were not only instances of people in the cleaning industry taking cash payments, which I suppose in the order of things one would not say is the worst offence but which should be stamped out and prevented, but also instances of companies in the industry which fraudulently had imaginary employees on their books. They were paying people who did not exist, collecting back the payments they had claimed against outgoings on tax, and then pocketing that money, thereby reducing their corporate tax liabilities very substantially. That meant that those fraudulent company operators-not the individual employees; not the little battlers that we sometimes hear of-were benefiting and enriching themselves to a contemptible degree at the public's expense.

Estimates of the extent of evasion, illegality and wrongdoing in this area will inevitably be the subject of some conjecture. It has been estimated that over 10 years the measures that will be introduced will result in the collection of something like $2,200m-that is, $220m each year over the next 10 years. This will be in addition to the money which honest ordinary taxpayers, like those people in the galleries who are listening to this debate, pay regularly to the Taxation Commissioner but which the cheats and the frauds in the community have so far avoided. These measures will go a long way to making sure that we have an honest straightforward tax system incapable of being subject to the kinds of rorts and abuses that have been so prevalent in the past.

The Opposition really has nowhere to move on this issue, because for so long it was the supporter of rorts and practices which operated to the disadvantage of ordinary taxpayers. Measures which have been introduced to make sure that those on higher income levels and those who in the past have had opportunities to evade or avoid tax pay their full measure of tax have always been opposed by the Opposition. The capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the prescribed payments system were all attacked by the Opposition. But there comes a point at which the Opposition's credibility would simply be zero if it persisted in its objection to a measure so fundamentally designed to make sure that honest taxpayers do not get overcharged, ripped off or cheated by people who are prepared to go to criminal lengths to defraud the tax.

Nobody likes paying tax. We would all love to have our tax liabilities reduced. The Government has committed itself to substantial tax reductions in the next financial year. Those are the sorts of matters which are open for legitimate debate in this Parliament. But there can be no place in this Parliament for those who would sponsor the illegal evasion of taxation by those who are cheats and criminals within the system. The legislation before us will make sure that the evasion that has occurred in that area is largely stamped out.

But even in this area the Opposition found itself wavering. Time after time excuses appeared. Questions were raised about how revenue effective the measures would be. That issue was hunted down, chased down, in the Senate by a Senate select committee. Ultimately, of course, the most telling blow in that area was dealt by Senator Stone, a former Secretary to the Treasury and now, I suppose, the eminence grise of the National Party of Australia-the leader in waiting in the Senate-who at least had the common decency and the good sense to tell the truth: that these measures would collect substantial revenue. That left the Opposition with nowhere to stand. It could not oppose the measure as being ineffective or not cost-effective in collecting revenue.

Of course, a number of civil liberties arguments, mainly spurious but sometimes genuine, were raised in relation to privacy protection. We have to remember that, although the Privacy Bill does touch on and provide guidelines for the protection of privacy and the tax file material in particular, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill itself provides very detailed and serious penalties for those who would breach the obligations of confidentiality that are imposed under that law. The penalties for the unauthorised use of tax file information are very high. Proposed new section 8wa in clause 26 of the Bill states that a person who requires or requests another person to quote the other person's tax file number for the purpose of establishing the other person's identity or for any other purpose not associated with its legitimate use is subject to a penalty of $10,000 or imprisonment for two years, or both.

Similar penalties apply to the unauthorised recording of tax file numbers and other abuses of the system. Those very serious criminal penalties are in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill itself. They have been there since the Bill was first introduced. These measures are not designed simply to provide a framework which can be abused; they are strong internal safeguards and intimidatory penalties that would measure with the penalties for any serious crime.

In addition to the penalty provisions in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill, the Privacy Bill provides for detailed guidelines to be established by the Privacy Commissioner after consultation with the collectors and users of tax file numbers. To make sure that provisions are in place when the scheme is first introduced, schedule 2 provides interim guidelines which will stand until such time as the Privacy Commissioner has brought in more detailed and more specific provisions. If the alternative guidelines put to the Parliament by the Privacy Commissioner are not thought appropriate by either the House of Representatives or the Senate they can be disallowed and the schedule 2 provisions will stand. Schedule 2 says very clearly that the tax file system is not to be used as a national identification system and includes detailed provisions about security for the collection of tax file number information, its storage, its use and similar matters.

So there is a very comprehensive scheme to protect the privacy of individuals, but also to make sure that the system works, that the tax file system operates to ensure that those who have tax liabilities cannot avoid them by criminal action, cannot create phoney employees, cannot take jobs in two names-one fraudulent and the other the real name-and cannot engage in other activities of which we have already heard in this debate. These are very sensible provisions.

As the possible excuses for opposing this legislation have been cut from under the Opposition one by one, it has been forced in the end to support it. But what a cavilling tone of support we have had. From the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), who spoke first, we had the most lukewarm support. That has been echoed throughout the debate, with the honourable exception of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). I think the shadow Attorney-General has made the greatest and most positive contribution from the Opposition to this debate. There is no doubt that the work of the shadow Attorney in relation to the Privacy Bill has resulted in legislation that we will all be proud of years into the future.

The Opposition's cavilling and unhappy acceptance of the provisions of this legislation was exemplified by the honourable member for Bruce, who made all kinds of damaging and outrageously unrealistic smears of the intention of the Government and, I believe, attacked the integrity of the Commissioner of Taxation. That is becoming the ball game for the Opposition. The Opposition does not have a tax policy. It does not have any framework for putting forward positive and constructive suggestions to the Australian people as to what it would do were it in government. Instead, it does three things. It says, `Let us bring forward tax cuts', but does not specify them, and, `Let us cut expenditure', but will not say where the expenditure cuts would be made. It also says, `Let us kick the head of the Tax Commissioner; let us attack the man. Let us play the man, because the Tax Commissioner has irritated some of our supporters, some of our friends'. That is sometimes the job of the Tax Commissioner. His job is to articulate clearly the needs of the revenue, to speak out on behalf of the ordinary, law abiding taxpayers of Australia and to make sure that people cannot get away with engaging in schemes that are devised to defraud the revenue or to avoid legitimate charges that have been imposed through legislation.

It is a measure of the Opposition's lack of policy and of the way in which it has allowed its guard to drop in this area that, without specifics, it is now playing the man rather than the ball. On the front page of this morning's Australian Financial Review the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is reported to have made a renewed attack on the Commissioner of Taxation, saying that under a coalition government the administration of the Australian Taxation Office would be placed in the hands of a board dominated by the private sector. That does not seem to me to be an appropriate response to the kinds of concerns that the Taxation Commissioner has raised, I believe legitimately, in the community.

I now turn to the Privacy Bill. I believe that this has been given insufficient weight in the debate to date. It is unfortunate that in the context of this debate it has become so tied up with the tax file numbers proposition, because the Privacy Bill extends far beyond the control of that scheme. The Privacy Bill extends to all information collected by Commonwealth government agencies. It establishes rules which those agencies must comply with-broad rules called the information privacy principles. Let me give an example of how such broad propositions are expressed. The first principle is:
Personal information should not be collected . . . for inclusion in a record or in a generally available publication unless-
(a) the information is collected for a purpose that is a lawful purpose directly related to a function or activity of the collector; and
(b) the collection of the information is necessary for or directly related to that purpose.
The second principle is:
Personal information should not be collected by a collector by unlawful or unfair means.

The Bill sets out 11 information privacy principles which govern the type of information that can be collected by government and restrict the use of that information. There has never been anything like this in Australia before. In the past, when a government has wanted information it has just collected it. If it has wanted to cross-reference that information, to use it as it has wished, it has done so. There has been no requirement under the laws of Australia that would restrict the use of such information. Citizens have a very real and proper concern that over time this build-up of information in the hands of governments will give rise to the possibility of abuse. No-one thinks that this Government would abuse such information, and I would hope that the Opposition, were it in government, would not do so, but some government might. These principles, established in the legislation, make sure that that possibility is much reduced. They give us great hope for the future and ensure that we will live in a society in which rights and freedoms are treated with the genuine respect that we ought to give them.

I say in conclusion that there is one point that I think many of us in this House would like to see. We would like to see the privacy protections extended to the private sector. In the private sector consumer credit information bureaus collect information through credit card use and through other credit transactions and give information about people's credit ratings, creditworthiness and the like. At the moment they can make mistakes and abuse the information but are not subject to legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) said that there had not been enough attention in the debate so far to the Privacy Bill but he gave it about three minutes. I want to devote my speech to that Bill to rectify the imbalance. We know that this legislation is of crucial importance, but we have been given a scandalously short time in which to consider it. As we all know, the Bill was available to only one member of the Opposition until it was introduced into this House late yesterday afternoon. We have been given a scandalously short time in which to study vital legislation. We cannot be expected to say that, on such a short study, this Bill provides the answers to the complex threats to privacy which are posed by modern technology. I want to make some contribution now which at least my colleagues in the Senate may be able to take some advantage of when they have had a bit more time to look at the legislation. On looking at the second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), it is very clear that he recognises the need for this legislation, especially as it is coupled with the tax file number legislation. In his speech the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The enormous developments in technology for the processing of information are providing new and, in some aspects, undesirable opportunities for the greater use of personal information.
He went on to say:
The Privacy Commissioner will ensure that some balance is brought to the debate as to the desirability of using the opportunities provided by new information technology to their fullest extent.

While he spoke of some balance, I think one could say that the Minister and the Government are acknowledging that the task of the Privacy Commissioner to produce real balance between the public interest of gathering information and the public interest in protecting privacy will be exceedingly difficult. I do not think that any Government member can be sanguine about this Bill actually achieving that because, as we know, it is based on a draft Bill produced back in 1976 by the Australian Law Reform Commission. It is interesting to note that in the Journal of Law and Information Science, volume 2, No. 1 of 1986-a decade later-there are two important articles. One is a critique of the Law Reform Commission's proposals and the other is entitled `Privacy principles-tacit assumptions under threat'. It is important to recognise that this legislation, based as it is on the Law Reform Commission's report, has itself been overtaken somewhat by even more rapid developments in technology of the kind to which the Minister alluded.

There is no doubt that privacy legislation is essential to ensure that individuals have some rights over information which is theirs, which is gathered by a range of agencies. However, this privacy legislation, based as it is on these privacy principles, is inadequate because of the way in which modern technology has been developed. Quoting from the article to which I referred, I can give one example: an on-line database collects information from many different sources and is available to the public. There are many different record keepers at various locations, none of whom may be responsible to the end user of that information. National boundaries are no obstruction and databases can be accessed from a different State or a different country. Even the storage of full text, such as newspapers, in a public database can lead to problems with privacy for individuals. James Thom and Peter Thorne say, in the article to which I have referred:
It is already possible to interrogate the New York Times database for all the information collected on a particular person over the last ten years.

There are very serious questions as to the right of privacy which some people have. They may be on a whole range of subjects beyond the consideration of the Australian Commissioner of Taxation. One can think again of people such as the Chamberlain children. Are they to be plagued for the rest of their lives because of the notoriety of a case involving the death of one of their siblings and the conviction of their parents? Will they be hounded forever by the media? Will they be subject to examination by other people as to income that their parents might get from stories, films or whatever? There is a whole range of ways in which our lives are intruded into and this legislation represents only a tentative beginning at giving us some protection. Certainly, common law and other statute law does not give us adequate protection. In fact, our distinguished former Governor-General, Sir Zelman Cowen, touched on the need for privacy legislation in the 1969 Boyer Lectures. It is a reflection on this Parliament and a succession of governments that we have not introduced legislation of this character earlier. He revisited those lectures only last Sunday for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and again pointed to the screaming need for legislation of this character and the reluctance of all interested parties, whether governments, media organisations or private data collection agencies, to have legislation. I think that the honourable member for Denison has been far too confident and complacent in believing that what we have before us now goes any way towards providing privacy. But it is a step and, as such, it must be welcomed.

One of the privacy provisions set out in the Bill states that the record keeper should ensure that the person to whom information relates should be advised that information has been collected. The article to which I referred points out that the use of personal computers and publicly accessed databases makes this principle impossible to enforce; hence the importance of trying to reach the private sector. That is something which the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development principles on privacy have wished us to do but which is exceedingly difficult to do.

The Australian Law Reform Commission considers the right of access to be the single most important principle, but there are instances where information about one can reveal information about another individual. So the Privacy Commissioner will have a very delicate task even in weighing that set of balances, quite apart from those to which the Minister referred in his speech. With the wide dissemination of information in the public access system, the right of access will be virtually impossible to provide. Many times people will not know that someone has had access to information about them and has acted upon it. In the United States of America there have been cases of people impersonating people because they have access to a file number which gave them a whole lot of information. Eventually, criminal action and other rights of action will have to be provided for people in those circumstances.

Under the Freedom of Information Act there are numerous exemptions relating to the right of access of an individual to personal information. Those restrictions are too great. The Minister claimed in his second reading speech that this Bill has extended the Freedom of Information Act. It is true that it has amended it, but it has not extended the basic rights available to it. One of the problems with which we are faced in drafting legislation of this kind is that the people who gather information, whether in private or public agencies, have something of a fetish about not releasing it. I will quote from a Yes, Minister script which makes the point rather well. A very famous letter to Sir Humphrey from the Campaign for Freedom of Information says:
Dear Sir Humphrey,
We are delighted that you have accepted our invitation to become a patron of The Campaign for Freedom of Information after your retirement from the Civil Service.
We note your proviso that you intend to work for the freedom of information `whenever it is in the public interest'.

That is the nub of the problem which we have in handling privacy legislation. Having read the legislation, in conjunction with the tax file legislation, I do not feel confident that the Privacy Commissioner or any individual affected by the gathering and dissemination of information will ever be able to get past the mental barrier of people who are the custodians of the information in the civil service or the private collection agencies, because they have a great belief that what they have is very important and it is in the public interest not to have it made public. Although the Bill deals with many of the responsibilities of the Privacy Commissioner, I believe that much more work has to be done effectively on getting a job description. What we are asking the Privacy Commissioner to do is to produce privacy impact statements, just as we are now looking increasingly for environmental impact statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the honourable member for Goldstein will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

On his instructions on 10 August 1988 did a senior member of his office write a letter to a senior member of the staff of the Minister for Local Government, his colleague in another place, seeking additional Federal assistance for the Tennant Creek Town Council `to keep the Northern Territory Government out of the Warumungu land claim negotiations' and to enable the Commonwealth Government to `raise its image' with the Tennant Creek community? —Can the Treasurer please advise the House whether the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher, continues to enjoy his full confidence? Furthermore, will the Treasurer adopt a recent suggestion that a board, incorporating a majority of private sector members, be appointed to oversee the operations of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first part of the question I say very positively that the Tax Commissioner does enjoy my full confidence and the confidence of the Government. The second part of the question arises from the discussions associated with the tax file number debate. I take this opportunity to emphasise that the Government welcomes the constructive manner in which the Opposition has approached that debate. I think we have probably produced a better Bill as a result. However, I reject absolutely the claim that the Tax Commissioner has been too vigorous in his approach to implementing the tax laws. This view has been put particularly by a minority in the corporate sector.

ANSWER.PARA: It is certainly true that the ATO has in recent years intensified its efforts to crack down on corporate tax evasion. The results have been significant. Corporate tax collections will rise in 1988-89 to $10,200m-up from $4,563m in 1983-84. As a percentage of the total tax take corporate tax collections have risen from 9.4 per cent in 1983-84 to an estimated 11.8 per cent for this financial year. Of course, the greater part of these increases is due to increased economic activity-that is, more people are doing more things and there is more growth for companies to feed from. But much of it is due to increased action by the Australian Taxation Office, which has directly increased revenue while increasing the climate of compliance. From 1982-83 to 1988-89 total collections from audits increased from $228m a year to $820m a year, up by more than 3 1/2 times. Within that increase company audit collections have risen from $86m in 1982-83 to $383m in 1988-89; that is, up 4 1/2 times. I repeat: company audit collections have risen from $86m in 1982-83 to $383m in 1988-89, up more than 4 1/2 times. In other words, nearly half of all the extra tax collected from audit checks is now coming from companies, compared to one-third in 1982-83.

In summary, the Tax Office is doing a good and effective job. Of course, some people do not like it and they have pressured the Opposition about that. In particular, the Leader of the Opposition has come up with the idea of having four people outside the tax system running the Tax Office. One would not have to be a political genius to understand where those four people would come from. It would not be a random selection of four ordinary taxpayers. They would come from the top end of town. The Leader of the Opposition would go to the so-called Liberal tax specialists, the people who have been out there managing some of these schemes, and put them in charge of the tax administration. We would reject such a notion out of hand.

The ATO's job is to implement fairly the tax laws of the day. The current Commissioner is doing that. If he makes an incorrect decision there are, of course, the normal remedies in the courts. That is why the courts are there. There have been many challenges to the Tax Office and to the Tax Commissioner in the courts.

We reject the claim that the Tax Commissioner has intervened in the political debate. He has merely made observations about what is needed to make the tax administration effective. Similar conclusions have been reached by numerous bipartisan bodies. What a shocking thing! He has said that in this day and age of computers the tax system would be advantaged by having a common number. Such an innocuous observation draws the stinging reproach, `How dare you enter the political debate! Do not remind us of the tools that are required for a Commissioner to run the tax system. How dare you remind us of these things! That is an unwarranted participation in the political debate'. I will leave it to the public to make its judgment about the veracity of those kinds of comments.
The speech from which some of this debate started was the one by the Commissioner on 19 September 1988 in Brisbane when he said:
Our tax system is built on the premise of equity, every person paying their fair share.
What a shocking concept that is! If one person does not pay his or her share, someone else has to cover for that. What a shocking and objectionable proposition that is!

—I ask you, Mr Acting Speaker, to ask this Treasurer, as he has been asked to do frequently in this House, to bring his answer to a close.

—I rise on a further point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. My point of order was not that the Treasurer was not answering the question. It related to the amount of time he was wasting to do so. He is now making a speech and it is your obligation to ask him to draw the matter to a close.
—Order! The Treasurer is in order. The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. The Treasurer will answer the question.

—The Opposition is saying, `We approve of the corporate tax rate being declined. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CORONATION HILL AND EL SHERANA: AUTHORITIES FOR EXPLORATION AND ACCESS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Will the Minister advise the House whether he has issued authorities for exploration and access at Coronation Hill and El Sherana in the Northern Territory? If so, has he attached environmental conditions to all such activities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Perth has always exhibited an abiding interest in conservation matters. I have issued four authorities with regard to these two areas, which are, of course, within the Kakadu conservation zone. There have been two exploration authorities and two access authorities granted to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) and BHP Gold Mines Ltd. The first exploration authority basically was to validate the legality of the existing leases at Coronation Hill. The second exploration authority was, in fact, to allow some drilling to occur on the parameters of the leases to allow the preparation of an environmental impact statement and a mining feasibility study.

ANSWER.PARA: Two access authorities have been issued. The first access authority is in regard to a large area of the conservation zone in which BHP considers it necessary to undertake some drilling and testing in order to support the production of an environmental impact statement and of a mining feasibility plan. The second access authority has been granted on the advice of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, so that we can produce a public environmental report prior to the consideration of whether exploration should proceed at the old El Sherana goldmine site in the Northern Territory.

On the advice of Senator Richardson, I have attached very strong and stringent environmental conditions to these four authorities; that is, two exploration authorities and two access authorities. I would like to table the most recent of those environmental conditions. Of course, if they are breached, I can withdraw access at any given time. I would like to say also that, as far as El Sherana is concerned, I believe that the public environmental report that has been ordered by Senator Richardson is now publicly available and open to public comment.

As far as actual mining at Coronation Hill is concerned, there is a great deal of interest. The Government and I would take no decisions as to whether to grant a mining authority until the Minister responsible for the environment, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Minister for Resources have had an adequate opportunity to study the environmental impact statement, and until the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Government have had the opportunity to undertake the fullest possible consultation with representatives of the local Aboriginal community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. In view of the national concern, particularly of the financial community and the national editorials, and indeed the general concern of the taxpayers of Australia, that has been pointing to the role played by the Western Australian Government in sponsoring Rothwells Ltd merchant bank with taxpayers' dollars, and following yesterday's suspension of trading in the corporation's shares, will the Attorney-General now order a special investigation into the corporation as section 291, subsection (2), of the Companies Code empowers him to do under such circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, the question assumes that nothing has been done by way of investigation. Secondly, it requests that action be taken by me in what is called the national interest. There is no precedent for that and there never has been any action taken by an Attorney-General pursuant to that particular provision, for this very reason: under the cooperative scheme-as the honourable gentleman would know-the administration of companies particularly relates to the State in which they are incorporated and also relates to the Corporate Affairs Commission in those States. It also relates to the fact that the National Companies and Securities Commission itself has a responsibility. Further, all these matters are the subject of report to what is called the Ministerial Council, which was set up under this scheme. The Ministerial Council gets reports from Mr Bosch of the National Companies and Securities Commission as to the particular company that the honourable member has now raised questions about. Those reports have indicated that the National Companies and Securities Commission is investigating the situation, and that is still the position.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it would be far better to leave it in the hands of Mr Bosch and the National Companies and Securities Commission, and any State Corporate Affairs Commission that has the jurisdiction so to do, to undertake that investigation. I think that it can be done and is being done. I suggest that the honourable gentleman await the deliberations of that inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Will the Prime Minister inform the House of progress towards ensuring the ceasefire in Namibia, which was to become effective yesterday, and the proper implementation of United Nations Security Council resolution 435?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Throsby for his question. His strong and continuing interest in African issues is well known. I must say that the prospect for a negotiated settlement of Namibia's independence is now looking more hopeful than it has for very many years indeed. One can say with confidence that all parties-that is, Angola, Cuba and South Africa-appear to be committed to reaching an agreement, but, as the honourable members has indicated in his question, the earlier target date of 1 November has not been met. Nevertheless, I can say to the honourable member that very substantial progress has been made in discussions between the parties and in recent discussions, both in Brazzaville and in New York, on the question of the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

ANSWER.PARA: As the House will appreciate, there are a number of difficult issues still to be settled, particularly the question of future national reconciliation within Angola itself and, of course, the question of continued South African destabilisation in the region. That does now look more optimistic than at any previous stage. For that process to come to a successful conclusion, we do look to the Government of South Africa to cease its support for insurgency by guerilla movements opposed to the Government of Angola. The position is, as all honourable members would appreciate, particularly the honourable member who asked the question, that Australia is not a party principal to these talks. We do, however, welcome and welcome very strongly the very constructive approach that has been taken so far, and we certainly call on all parties involved to continue those constructive negotiations. We strongly believe that the implementation of the United Nations plan for independence in Namibia, contained in Security Council resolution 435 of 1978, offers the best possible process and path to resolution of this issue.

I conclude by reminding all honourable members that an integral part of the United Nations plan is the deployment of what is known as the United Nations Transitional Assistance Group (UNTAG) to monitor the implementation of this plan. Honourable members may recall that Australia offered under the previous Government in 1979 to provide an engineering contingent for UNTAG totalling some 300 personnel. That offer was made, as I say, under the previous Government in 1979 and that commitment was reaffirmed by my Government in August of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Social Security confirm that there is not an entitlement to family allowance for all families with parental income of less than $50,000, that a family can have an income significantly lower than this supposed means test point but get no family allowance? Since he claimed at the time that he introduced the means testing of the family allowance that it was necessary for reasons of social justice, how can he justify that some families may not be paid any family allowance whilst other families on substantially higher incomes do receive the allowance? What action is he prepared to take to prevent this inequitable treatment of different families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not altogether certain that I understand the question. I thought that the rules with respect to family allowance were well known. The fact of the matter is that the income test on family allowance is not only set at the level of $50,000 but is tapered in such a way that where there are additional children families with incomes substantially above $50,000 are eligible for family allowance. The year of taxable income on which the family allowance income test is based is the previous year's taxable income. So I suppose that the implication of the honourable member's question, although it certainly was not clear in the question, is that in subsequent years people may have a significant reduction in their income. That is provided for in relation to the income test for very substantial variations in income. It may be that the honourable member is referring to the fact that where those variations are less substantial, but nevertheless significant, it is possible for people to be in the circumstances described, where they are not eligible for family allowance.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that the family allowance is related to the taxation system. Of course, the taxation system does operate essentially on the basis of the previous year's taxable income. The assumption that applies, for example, in relation to payments for beneficiaries, or payments for low income working families, is that the question of the immediate circumstances is not quite as pertinent when we are dealing with what is effectively a tax measure.

I will certainly examine the issue that has been raised by the honourable member to see whether we do need to make any further adjustments to the way that the income test operates. But I say to honourable members that I have been rather surprised that not only have the estimates in relation to the number of families affected by moving to income testing the family allowance been so precise-that is, the number of families affected is almost exactly the number that was predicted, or certainly very close to the range that was predicted-but also the community has recognised that in current economic circumstances at least, the extent of family assistance should be targeted towards low income families. It is true to say that something like 60 per cent of the expenditure in relation to families is currently concentrated in the lowest quartile of the population. I think that in difficult economic circumstances that is a very good illustration indeed of the Government's commitment to social justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to the release of the Social Security Review paper Towards a National Retirement Incomes Policy. Does the paper express concerns about early retirement? Could the Minister indicate the community's reception to the paper?

—Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Under standing order 101 provision is made for the calling on of business of the House, questions without notice, presentation of papers and ministerial statements. This paper should be debated in this House and a ministerial statement should be made on it.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will come to his point of order.
—The Minister for Social Security has been asked to make a statement on a paper.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.
—And he should not be allowed to abuse Question Time in this--
—I warn the honourable member for North Sydney. The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.
—Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The frivolous points of order taken continually by the Opposition in disrupting Question Time are directed simply at answers which they do not like.
—There is no point of order.
—Mr Acting Speaker, why do you not warn him or is there some reason that you feel--
—The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member, in asking his question, referred to the concerns about early retirement. Attention is drawn to these concerns in the paper he mentioned. The question asked for information about the trend towards early retirement. The statistics are very dramatic. Honourable members opposite, of course, prefer to have a committee meeting, presumably to discuss tactics. In early 1968, 80 per cent of males aged 60 to 64 were still in the work force. That fell to 50 per cent by the 1980s, and in 1987 just under 45 per cent of males aged 60 to 64 years were still in the work force. Increasingly, early retirement is shown up not only in that age group but also among people still in their fifties. For example, among males in the 55 to 60 age group one also finds an equally significant and quite dramatic trend towards early retirement. Under the previous Government, when there was very high and growing unemployment that trend was welcomed and accepted. It was not seen as a matter of any great concern. But Professor Cass, in her paper, quite cogently argues that if we are to develop within this country a retirement income policy not only for the 1980s but also for the 1990s and for the first decades of the next century that trend needs to be arrested. In her discussion paper, issues paper No. 6, she makes a number of suggestions about the way that that issue might be addressed. It has been extraordinarily impressive how widely this issues paper has been welcomed. It is true that the aged community-including various pensions and retired persons associations-the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the industry and many informed media commentators have seen this paper as a very significant contribution.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. The Minister is answering the question.

—The question clearly asked me to indicate the community's reception to the paper. If the community had reacted against the paper, there would be no problem about this issue being raised in Question Time. But because the reaction has been positive, we have honourable members opposite complaining. The reception to the paper has been extremely positive. People see this paper as providing a very effective framework. There will be widespread opportunities all around Australia for people to respond to this paper.
—But not in the Parliament.

—Indeed, in this place. If honourable members opposite had the slightest interest in policies, they would ensure that under the Standing Orders of this Parliament, within the rules, the matter was debated. I have no concern about such a debate because it is only through discussion and debate that that very widespread positive reaction to this paper will be translated into a long term retirement incomes policy. It is of considerable concern to me and to this Government to ensure that we put in place a policy in this area that endures over the longer term. That is why we are interested in widespread discussion, consultation and debate. That is why people will have the opportunity to make submissions to me and to the Social Security Review over the next several months.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Given that the Joint Select Committee on Video Material reported six months ago, why has the Government failed to take appropriate action to stop those in the community who continue to peddle X-rated pornography and excessively violent videos in those areas under the control of the Government, particularly in view of the fact that the Opposition declared its support for such action more than nine months ago? Is it a fact that many members of the Labor Party are opposed to such action and that, at present, the Government is considering a conscience vote on the issue for its own ranks? In short, when can we expect to know the Government's position?
—Very shortly.
