—My question is directed to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. I appreciated his comment yesterday on the greenhouse effect. Can the Minister explain to the House the reason for the large number of bogong moths invading the precincts of the Parliament?
—Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. We are here for Question Time. This is making a joke out of the whole procedure. That is what is damn well intended, and you know it.
—Order! There is no point of order. Honourable members on my right and left will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bogong moth-or, as the Opposition would call it, the Agrostis infusa-migrates through Canberra at this time each year. The larvae are minor pests of crops and pastures on the western slopes and plains of New South Wales and other--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Spender

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. A Minister may be questioned about matters of public administration. Under standing order 142:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which he is responsible.
We know that he is a man of many talents, but he is not responsible for the moths.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister, as I understand it, is responsible for the CSIRO, which may have something to say about the moths.

—As Minister responsible for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and in particular CSIRO's Division of Entomology, which is giving advice on this area, I think it is absolutely central. The numbers of moths this year are higher than average. Problems can be expected in most years, but it does not seem to be as great as the great invasions of 1952 and 1969. However, Parliament House does appear to be a special problem. The moths are attracted at night to strong illumination and at dawn seek shelter in dark places-I would have thought perhaps where the shadow Cabinet meets. They frequently enter buildings via air-conditioning systems. The moths are attracted to white or blue lights, less so to yellow and red lights. The Parliament will have to evaluate the advantage of having this building on the summit of Capital Hill illuminated all night-indeed, in some areas of the building the floodlights stay on throughout the day-against the disadvantage of having the building inundated by bogong moths, which occasionally make the place look like a set from a Bunuel film. The problems may be eased by reducing the intensity and/or colour of outside illumination and placing mesh--
—This is an abuse of Question Time.
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting. I warn the honourable member for Flinders.

—The problem can be eased by placing mesh screen, maximum distances between wires of 3 millimetres, over entry points-for example, air-conditioning ducts. We are in a building where for the first time we have bogong moths circling around us.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left and the Leader of the Opposition will stop interjecting.
—There is quite a direct connection, and I concede that, but that was not the question I was asked.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will answer the question. Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.

—The migration is very seasonal. It will abate in November. The moths migrate back to the breeding ground in the autumn and the migration is less conspicuous. But there is a problem, and I think the solution essentially lies in Parliament's hands.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. When will the Minister answer my question No. 374 regarding the purchase of the Nardoola property near Moree, which has been on the Notice Paper since 4 November last year? When will he answer my question No. 624, placed on the Notice Paper on 26 November last year, regarding the provision of information about all the capital outlays for property Australia-wide and subsequent funding by the Aboriginal Development Commission and his Department of Aboriginal Affairs? When will he answer my question No. 621 regarding the purchase and the running costs of the Oasis Hotel, Walgett, placed on the Notice Paper on 18 February this year? Does he think that the millions of dollars expended on these and other unproductive investments would have been better spent in Aboriginal housing, job training, education and health? Because of the public interest in these matters will the Minister refer these issues that I have mentioned to the Auditor-General's inquiry for a thorough investigation and report to this Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I referred to two of those points in my comments and I did make the comment that I would be supplying the information to the honourable member because I know he has a deep interest in particularly--
—What has this to do with--

—Just a moment. He has a deep interest in particularly those cases concerning his own electorate. In fact, yesterday we had a discussion and both he and I later this afternoon will be meeting one of the groups involved in a particular case that he mentioned. The answers will be provided and, as I said yesterday, they will be provided probably within about 24 hours.

ANSWER.PARA: The question did go to the point of whether I thought some of these projects were a `waste'; I think that was the word used. I would remind the honourable member and the House that one of the cases he mentioned goes back to 1982. I think he appreciates the fact that there is a long period of time involved in at least two of these cases. They are very complex and complicated but I will be discussing them with the honourable member and supplying the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. In view of the finding that cement is being imported from Japan at dumped prices, can the Minister indicate why no dumping duty has been applied? Does this give a competitive advantage for discounting to the importer? Does the Minister have authority to apply a dumping duty retrospectively should the importer use the price advantage gained by dumping as a basis for unfair competition? Did the Minister seek information or comment from the Australian cement manufacturers before deciding not to apply a duty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian cement industry lodged a dumping complaint on the basis that future exports to Australia of cement from Japan threatened material injury to the Australian industry. The Australian Customs Service (ACS) notified the initiation of the investigation on 16 May. The first shipment of cement arrived on 30 August and the ACS published a preliminary finding on 21 October. Essentially the ACS found that although the imports of cement from Japan are dumped, the ACS has calculated the non-injurious price level as being much lower than normal value. If anti-dumping measures were to be taken they could be taken only to the extent of lifting the import price to the non-injurious price level in accordance with Australia's legislation and obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. However, this imposition would not force any increase in the price of the imported product to end users. The imports into Victoria account for less than 3 per cent of the estimated Australian market of 6.4 million tonnes per annum. ACS has ascertained that the imports into Victoria are not causing or threatening material injury to Australian industry on the basis of no price suppression, as the imported goods are being sold at the Victorian market prices. There were no lost sales at 1987-88 production levels, which were high as Victorian cement producers operated at or near their full capacity. The predicted volume of imports is expected to be absorbed by the forecast market expansion in Victoria and the most conservative estimate is 130,000 tonnes.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I have indicated that if the circumstances were to change-for example, if the imports were to be re-sourced from elsewhere at a dumped price, which did then cause material injury-the ACS would regard this as a new situation and fresh action could and would be taken very rapidly. There is no power on the part of a Minister to change the law about tariff levels on his own motion. We have set up the Anti-Dumping Authority so it can make appropriate recommendations to the Government. Indeed, I have indicated to the cement industry that if it were to challenge the nature of the finding by ACS, although technically it would not be eligible under the existing law to apply as of right for a review to the dumping authority, I would use my ministerial discretion to direct the dumping authority to review the matter as if it were an appeal. So the matter raised by the honourable member for Corio is being looked at very carefully. I think he can assure his constituents that their interests are being looked after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members earlier today. Details of the papers will be recorded in Hansard and the Votes and Proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule read as follows-
Steel Industry Authority-Annual Report 1987-88-section 31 of the Steel Industry Authority Act 1983.
Independent Air Fares Committee-Annual Report 1987-88-section 32 of the Independent Air Fares Committee Act 1981.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, we are debating one of the most glaring examples of this Government's failure to take a hard decision. This Government is very fond of telling us that it is quite capable of addressing the hard decisions that are necessary to be taken in the best interests of the Australian community and the Australian economy. But, when it really comes down to taking those hard decisions, absolutely nothing is done.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I will address my remarks to Kingsford-Smith Airport in Sydney. I am sure the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch), who is at the table, is well aware of this matter. He is the only Minister responsible for this particular area in the chamber today. His electorate is located very close to that airport, and, of course, that is an issue which we will discuss later in this debate. We will discuss the significance of this Minister and his electorate and the impact that it has on the political process and what that means in terms of cost to the Australian travelling public, to the aviation industry and, of course, to the tourist industry in Australia.

Let me quote what was said by Mr John Riley, the Chairman of the New South Wales Air Transport Council. In a speech the other day to a conference in Tamworth, at which the Minister was present, he said:
The greatest challenge facing aviation in Australia today and tomorrow is the capacity of Kingsford-Smith Airport.

What Mr Riley was alluding to was the inability of that airport at the present time and under this Government's policy to cope with aviation growth in this country. Any person who has caught a plane on the eastern seaboard of this country knows that he or she will encounter serious delays, which not only inconvenience travellers and have an impact on air safety standards in Australia but also cost real money, and not just to aviation operators as these costs are passed on to travellers in the form of higher air fares. The effect of those increases flows through to the entire economy.

Perhaps people do not understand just how serious this is getting. Qantas Airways Ltd, Australia's government-owned airline, says that unless the capacity of Kingsford-Smith Airport is increased our tourist boom will be stifled. I quote from yesterday's press for the Minister, in case he has not read it:
The boom in tourism to Australia would halt unless the Federal Government reversed its opposition to a third runway at Sydney Airport, Qantas said yesterday.
But the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA)-
which is another creation of this Government-
has already approved new buildings to be erected near the boundaries of the airport, which would prevent aircraft landing on the runway proposed by Qantas.

This is very serious, because the Government not only is prepared to adhere to a policy of not building an additional runway at Sydney but also is prepared to adopt a deliberate course of limiting the options of a future government in this area. People say aircraft noise is significant. Aircraft noise affects 78,000 people in Sydney very seriously. Let us not deny that; it does. The Minister has said on occasions that it is one million people. If he mentions that figure in here today, it is incumbent on him to tell us where that figure comes from, because the Air Transport Council of New South Wales quotes a figure of 78,000. So the Minister should not come up with any pumped up figures when he responds later; let us talk about the realities of the situation as it is in New South Wales.

Sydney Airport is the ninth busiest airport in the world, according to the people of New South Wales. It has more international activity than all the rest of the Australian international airports. But it is unique in that it is not a multi-runway airport-and under this Government it never will be. It has capacity limitations. Its theoretical maximum capacity is 220,000 movements a year. In fiscal year 1987-88, there were 211,725 movements, and already for selected periods it is operating at over its theoretical maximum. When bad weather occurs massive delays result there. Sydney Airport has a capacity for 32 arrivals an hour. If we have bad weather, that is reduced to 15; and in fact the airport can be closed. We get delays of three hours to scheduled services and five hours for others. Only the other day Continental Airlines Inc. had a 747 sitting on the end of the runway for an hour. It was moved from one runway to another. Does the Minister know what that cost? It cost $8,500 an hour. That is what it costs to sit a 747 at the end of a runway-and the traffic at Kingsford-Smith Airport will continue to increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your answer?

—Our answer is to build a third runway. That is what we will do. We will build a third runway. But let us get back to the issue at hand. A few years ago, in an attempt to come to grips with this increasing traffic at Kingsford-Smith Airport, slot times were introduced. Now the Civil Aviation Authority is saying, `We have done all we can. We can do no more to increase the capacity of Kingsford-Smith Airport, Sydney'. That is what it really comes down to. So the Minister said, `We will upgrade the terminal'. That is marvellous. It should have been done years ago; the Government has been in office for 5 1/2 years and there have been all sorts of inquiries and reports into the matter. We now have a proposal to spend $214m-about 5 1/2 years too late.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity the Government did not listen to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) when he was telling it what would happen with tourism. Does the Government not realise what is happening? We will have just over two million tourists this year; the projection was for 5 million tourists by the end of the century; and that projection has been revised to over seven million tourists. How will the Government get them into the country? What will it do? Will it go to Boeing and say, `Build us a 747 that flies like a helicopter and we will drop them straight in'? It is not going to happen. The only way we can cope with the growth in traffic is to build that third runway.

Not only have we this problem with the CAA and the upgraded terminal, but also both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines have commitments to increase by one-third the parking facilities for their aircraft at Kingsford-Smith Airport. They have just signed 20-year leases with the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) to upgrade their terminals. They will not reduce the number of flights going in there. And, of course, Qantas will expand its jet base. Of course, all the international airlines that operate into Australia at present have landing rights for more flights and they will use them into the future.

This issue involving Qantas raises another question to which I refer in passing. Qantas will spend $6 billion expanding its fleet, when it works out how this Government will finance it. The real problem is that there is policy paralysis on the other side of the chamber. When it comes to addressing the issues that the Government confronts day by day, it gets policy paralysis; it is too hard. The paralysis in this particular case is because of one electorate. There is a major conflict of interest between this Minister sitting at the table and the needs of aviation in Australia, the travelling public and the tourist industry. For the sake of one lousy seat, this Government will not address the problem.

Mr Acting Speaker, if you do not believe me, let me illustrate how paranoid the Government is in talking about this issue. I quote from a press release from Gary Punch, Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, which refers to the curfew changes at Sydney Airport. It states:
The Minister said the development did not call for any expansion of the runways and restated the Hawke Government's firm opposition to any second runway.

There is a second runway there; he really meant a third one. The Minister should talk to his press office about that. The Minister really should be precise. The Government says, `Don't worry: we are building the new airport at Badgerys Creek'. But at the bottom of this press release we get some clues as to what Badgerys Creek is all about. The Minister says, `Badgerys Creek will be operating within five years'. The holding time of a 747 is pretty long, but it is not five years. Badgerys Creek was referred to as an important general aviation airport. Honourable members know what general aviation is; it is light aircraft. It is not 747s, 767s and 727s. It is none of those. It is Pipers, Cessnas and all of those aircraft. This is what the Minister is talking about. What will he do about it?
Qantas is quite open about this matter. It says there is a major problem. It has said:
Inbound tourism is growing 8 per cent faster than Qantas estimates earlier this year of 18 per cent annual growth.

The promotional efforts of other States are not moving people out of Sydney. Most foreign tourists insist on landing in Sydney. It is the natural airline hub for the South Pacific. It is the preferred destination for airline travellers. Qantas says:
Some flights could be diverted to Brisbane or Melbourne, but those airports are approaching capacity during the peak arrival times.
Honourable members should listen to this:
For several hours each day it was impossible to fit an extra international jet into any three of the East Coast capitals.

Qantas then goes on to say that it plans to double its fleet and double its flights. I ask the Minister to say where those flights will land. What will he do about it? At present we have a proposal by the FAC to introduce discriminatory landing and parking charges at Sydney Airport to reduce the number of light aircraft.

The Minister, when he goes to his electorate, talks about the need to control air traffic noise pollution. He is running a policy under which small light aircraft will be moved out from Sydney Airport. That is quite an interesting policy. The aircraft are small and they do not make a lot of noise. But guess what is going to happen to the slot times that they leave behind? Has the Minister told the good people of Barton that these small aircraft are going to be replaced by jets or has he not figured that they could probably work that out themselves?

There is not even any logical consistency in the Minister's approach to this whole issue. What is the Minister going to do about the capacity at Bankstown Airport when general aviation aircraft under 5,700 kilograms are moved there? Bankstown is operating at near operational capacity. If intrastate commuter airlines are moved to Bankstown, money will have to be spent to upgrade the airport's standards and there will be some operational and safety difficulties. When are we going to get a statement about this matter?

What we do not have from this Government is any sort of comprehensive statement about its master plan for Sydney Airport-or in fact for the whole aviation industry right throughout Australia. This comes back to the very important issue that I raised about what Botany Council is approving at present and what the CAA is unable to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —A famous council for the Labor Party.

—A very famous council. If the Minister wants any guidance, he could probably talk to Laurie Brereton about it. I am sure that Laurie would tell him all about it. He will tell the Minister the ins and outs of it and whom he should talk to. The Minister could probably achieve anything he liked, despite the fact that, because of the Government's policy, the CAA does not have power to do anything.

SPEECH.PARA: The position at present is that Botany Council is about to approve development applications for buildings on the perimeter of the airport that go above the general 15-metre limit. They go to 51 metres, which is the old 150-foot height limit for development in proximity to airports. Qantas, the government-owned airline, is worried that these buildings effectively prevent the development of the third runway which it has proposed. This matter has been referred to the CAA for a response. The CAA, being a fairly efficient and pretty good organisation, went out and got a legal opinion. It was told that it would be in a very difficult situation if it objected to these buildings. This opinion was given on the basis that it was Government policy that there would be no third runway. So the CAA could not hypothetically, on spec, say, `No, you cannot put these buildings up'. The Minister knows this. But he has done nothing to help the CAA's situation, because he is determined to ensure that Sydney Airport is frozen in time, no matter what the consequences and the costs are.

The real problem is that the Minister cannot put his own political career behind the significance of aviation and the growth of Sydney Airport. The Minister should really consider whether his conflict of interest should make him walk away from making this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is putting the future of the tourist industry of Australia at risk for his own selfish purposes.

—That is right. The good people of Barton might be backing him. However, I wonder whether they really are, because a survey conducted a few years ago indicated that most of them were in favour of the development of a third runway. But we have a situation in which the most significant airport in Australia-and it is going to be the most significant airport into the future-is being held back because of the political interests of one member and the right wing machine of the Australian Labor Party. As I said, this is a very important issue. The Government has to overcome its paranoia and address the real issue. It has made some curfew changes but it should make a few more, because the technology is such that aircraft are getting quieter and larger. It is quite possible to bring more aircraft in at later times. It is not appropriate to say that aircraft can be diverted to other airports. As Qantas said, those airports are absolutely chock-a-block and there is not much else that can be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Government's current plans, Badgerys Creek will operate general aviation within five years. Badgerys Creek is needed. Let me assure the House that we on this side recognise the need for this airport. We would certainly go ahead and build it. But it is not the solution to the problem facing aviation in Australia at present. The Government should be building the third runway at Sydney Airport. If it took a decision now, that runway would come on stream at about the same time as the new terminals. That would be a masterstroke, would it not? The Government would actually coordinate something. Terminals and runways would be finished at the same time, and maybe we would get away from the lousy reputation that the Government has given us in the past few years for totally inadequate airports.

The Government should proceed with Badgerys Creek in an orderly fashion. Badgerys Creek should not be used just for general aviation. The Government should recognise that Sydney is growing to such an extent that there is going to be a need for a second major airport and that there is a role for Badgerys Creek in terms of interstate and intrastate transport and, eventually, international transport. If we look at what Qantas has had to say about Badgerys Creek in terms of international transport, we can see that it is going to be like Narita Airport: it will be 15 to 20 years before it is a major international port. That is what Qantas says about this issue that the Government will not come to grips with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really flattered. We just heard the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) say, over too long a period, that it is all because of me that we are not building another runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. Occasionally I like to claim credit for that. But the honourable member should bear in mind that for some two decades now it has been Australian Labor Party policy that we should not build another runway. This view has been consistently held at State, Federal and local government levels. This view has been consistently held for two basic reasons. First of all, the building of another runway is not in any way a sensible proposition. Secondly, another runway would be to the detriment of the 1.1 million Australians who live in the municipalities that surround Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that I find it a little amazing that the honourable member went into a diatribe about how this Government has not been keen to make the tough decisions. I wonder where he thinks the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation came from. When the Opposition was in government its whole back bench was on about this matter. What did the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) have to say about that? We did it, and we are doing something about it. The Bosch Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery was initiated by this Government. We put in place structures like the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Civil Aviation Authority to make airline operations in this country work, and work effectively. We set up structures so that they would continue to operate effectively into the future.

The honourable member for Richmond talked about Sydney Airport. The Government's consistency on this airport cannot be doubted. It is a long held policy decision from which we have never been deterred. Our policy is that we should acquire and build the second Sydney airport at Badgerys Creek, a site that we established after a suitable and proper process, and that in the meantime we have to make adjustments at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to allow that airport to cope. Frankly, if there is one line I am sick and tired of hearing, it is this tired, hackneyed old piece that, if we do not build another runway, the tourism boom will end. There is no second runway protruding into the bay-or third runway, as the honourable member wants to describe it-of the type that is wanted by the honourable member. But the record growth in tourism under this Government cannot be disputed. The honourable member's argument is paradoxical.

What is the Government doing about Sydney Airport? First of all, just recently the Federal Airports Corporation announced a $214m extension to the international terminal building, with associated apron works and gateways, to take the loading bays from 14 to 22. These extensions are designed to meet the peak periods in Sydney where there is a problem at the moment. That is what we are doing. The problems with that terminal have been brewing for years. It took this Government to correct those problems. Action was taken several years ago at Sydney Airport in regard to baggage handling facilities and so forth.

Let me talk about the curfew for a moment. Honourable members opposite have a classic hypocritical stance on this matter. Members of the local Liberal Party parade up and down the streets saying, `We will not touch the curfew at Sydney. We will not touch the Sydney curfew at all'. The honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) is holier-than-thou about the whole issue. The curfew, after the runway, is target number one in this chamber and in every country newspaper across the State. It is the subject of repeated targeting. If honourable members opposite think that the people of Sydney do not know what a coalition government would do with the curfew, they are mistaking them for fools, because they do.

What has the Government done in respect of the curfew? We have adjusted to the hard reality of finding a curfew pattern that provides, firstly, more flexibility and capability for Kingsford-Smith Airport in the short term while, secondly, improving the lot of the local residents if we can. We think that we have found a formula that does that-a formula that adds two extra hours to the day with a quota of flights between 11 and 12 at night and five and six in the morning. It is a trial, and so it should be, because we want to see what the effect of it is. The curfew is the second instance of what we are doing at Kingsford-Smith to help that place cope while Badgerys Creek is being built.

The third issue which the honourable member raised is the peak hour charges of the Federal Airports Corporation. It is of interest to note that at the moment general aviation (GA) aircraft take up some 15 per cent of peak hour capacity at Sydney. There would not be a member on either side of the House who has not sat on the tarmac at Kingsford-Smith Airport while plane loads of tourists in 747s, domestic airliners and so forth were held up by two- and four-seaters. The FAC has come up with a peak hour charging proposal for the hours 7.30 a.m. to 10 a.m. and 4.30 p.m. to 7 p.m. for GA non-regular public transport flights. The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) interjected a short while ago, `What are you doing about the country commuters?'. He should know that country commuters are not affected by proposals such as this. That is a simple fact. This proposal would not affect helicopters nor would it affect domestic and international aircraft. Again, we are following the same theme, the same policy direction-to give Kingsford-Smith an extra capability in the short term while Badgerys Creek is being built.

What else is being done? The joint Federal-State task force will report to me very shortly. It should have reported by now and I have been, to say the least, hurrying it up. It will examine a range of issues in the light of helping Kingsford-Smith cope better while the second Sydney airport is built. Issues such as hubbing through Sydney have to be explored. All such issues must be explored. Sydney's airport tarmacs are a very precious resource. Sydney's airport tarmacs are roughly one-third the size of those of most major international airports. The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Richmond, a few moments ago talked about the business that goes through Kingsford-Smith compared with a number of other airports. What he said in this respect is quite true, but he should note that Sydney Airport is about one-third the size of most other major airports. It is hemmed in on all sides except the Botany Bay side, and it is hemmed in to some extent on that side by the nature of the industries at Kurnell and Botany. That issue should not be dismissed lightly, either.

That brings us to Badgerys Creek. I found it very interesting that the honourable member acknowledged that we need to get on and build the airport at Badgerys Creek. That seems to be a pretty standard departure, to use airline vernacular, from the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I find it quite amazing that he matched his rhetoric with such a departure, because the Opposition's policy seems to have done more somersaults than a Romanian gymnast. It goes back as far as 1981 when on two occasions the then Liberal Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, said that a second Sydney airport had to be found. So the Labor Party, in opposition and now in government, has not changed its position on this matter; we are just finding it active viewing watching the Opposition change its policy. No doubt it will change it again before the next election.

We come to the issue of the runway. Not once did the honourable member for Richmond say what sort of runway was needed. Why did he not? It is because, like his predecessors, he does not know. It is as simple as that. Does he mean a close-spaced parallel runway west or a close-spaced parallel runway east? Does he mean a stubby runway for small general aviation, a wide-spaced parallel runway east or a wide-spaced parallel runway west? Does he know how much the resumptions would cost on the properties that would have to be resumed? Has he gone into the estimates for the fill requirements for coming into the bay? According to one estimate, one of the larger runways, which we would have to build to get any economically sane capability or extra capacity at Kingsford-Smith out of another runway, would require some 40 million cubic metres of fill. I invite the honourable member for Richmond to identify where we are to get that fill from. We cannot get it out of Botany Bay. I invite the honourable member to tell me how quickly we could build the preferred runway. He bandies around figures such as five years. The former Minister, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), sitting next to him, was not too sure about that when he announced a close-spaced parallel runway. He was not so keen then.

The honourable member for Richmond ought also to bear in mind that in the case of one of the runway proposals it would take one tip-truck arriving on site every 20 seconds for five years to bring the fill in. The honourable member asks where the 1.1 million people who will be affected come from. I will tell him where they are. They are the ratepayers of the councils which will have to pay for the cracked roads and the diminished standard of living in that area, right across that part of Sydney. Under him, one-fifteenth of the population of Australia would bear that cost. There is no doubt about it. If I had the time we could talk about environmental issues. Such a development would destroy Australia's birthplace, Botany Bay.

But, even if we accept all of that, as the honourable member for Richmond clearly does, to what avail would we do it? What additional capacity would we generate at Kingsford-Smith with that huge and bottomless pit of public expenditure, if such a runway could be built? I believe that it is the classic urban myth; that it cannot be built. The honourable gentleman did not mention capacity once because he does not know. That is the truth. The truth is that we can meet Sydney's long term air needs only by getting on with the construction of a second Sydney airport. What are we doing about that? I will tell the House. We have said it on a number of occasions, but I will say it again. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), who has primary carriage of this issue because it is a policy issue, and I will be taking a submission to Cabinet, we trust before the end of the year, to speed up the development at Badgerys Creek. That is consistent with the pronouncement by the former Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, in August this year about the need to get on with the second Sydney airport. He identified the four-phase development at Badgerys Creek, commencing-not limiting, as the honourable member implies-with general aviation standards. He even gave some rough figures-$10m to $15m on the first phase and $15m to $25m on the second phase.

The honourable member walks around the bush saying that this Government has no clear policy conception of these issues. We have a clear policy conception about Sydney's airport needs and are pursuing it. I might say that we have never been aided in meeting Sydney's airport needs by any Liberal-National Party Government, State or Federal, and the present New South Wales Government is no exception. The Liberal and National parties have a simple cement psychology. `Slap a bit of cement in there. We don't know how much it will cost, how long it will take or what capacity it will generate'. They produce no figures and no facts-just more of the urban myth about a third runway. I will tell honourable members why it has not been built to date. If honourable members opposite really believed that that runway could be built when they were in government, they would have got on and done it, and not left it until the final hours when their regime was crumbling, as they did in 1981. It is as simple as that.

Those opposite are not interested in Sydney's airport needs. We are, and so are the people who live in the area. There are 14,000 people who work at Kingsford-Smith Airport whose interests we are concerned with, on top of the other 14,000 whose jobs directly depend on it. We are interested in Sydney's airport needs; those opposite are not. Very clearly, as has been traditional Liberal Party philosophy in this country for 70 years, they would rather see the business transferred to Melbourne. Under us it will not be. We have a sensible, logical plan that is valid not only for the aviation industry but also for the residents. Let me say finally that I saw Captain Terrell's remarks. I just put it on the record that it is the Government, not Qantas Airways Ltd, that sets policy on aviation matters; and the Government, not Qantas, will continue to set aviation policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every time a member of the Australian public buys an airline ticket and worries about the cost of that ticket, I hope that he will blame this Government and the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch). Every time people read of a further increase in the price of international air tickets, I hope they will realise that the blame rests with this Government and the Minister. Today we have had a typical example of the `couldn't care less' attitude that has been displayed towards the whole aviation industry by this Government since it came to power in 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: I take great exception to some of the statements made by the Minister this afternoon because what he has said is patently not true. He talked about the grand plan for Sydney and for Australian aviation, but there is not one shred of evidence that anything is happening. I take exception to some of his remarks about Sydney Airport. One thing that has not been raised this afternoon is the situation in the airport terminal. He made brief reference to the fact that the Government is looking at changing things there, but for more than two years Sydney's international terminal has been an absolute disaster. Despite the bandaid remedies he has applied in recent times, every international tourist who comes to Australia takes at least one hour to get through immigration and at least one hour to get through Customs and is fed up with the place within an hour after arrival. Nothing has been done to improve that situation and it is getting worse.

We cannot say that it is all about slots because there has been a massive change in the number of arrivals at Sydney international from the morning to the evening. We now have a double disaster area. The disaster area exists not only from 6 o'clock until 9.30 in the morning but also at night. With four or five arrivals and a couple of take-offs then too, one cannot move in the terminal; it takes an hour to get through. It is no wonder that the surveys that are made of departing visitors to Australia show that they do not like those delays and, in particular, the attitude of some of the personnel who serve at the airport. I have a great deal of sympathy for the Customs officers at Sydney international purely because of the sheer hell conditions in which they have to work. There is no doubt at all that the worst possible introduction and farewell that we can give to international tourists coming into and leaving Australia is the perception that they get in Sydney.

I now turn to the impact this `do nothing at Sydney international' attitude will have on the Minister's electorate. At present about 18,000 people are employed at Sydney international terminal. Does the Minister realise that his part of the world attracts about $900m a year in expenditure? He is going to get rid of that direct expenditure by airlines and infrastructure from his area. Is he worried about that? Is he worried that his head in the sand attitude will deprive the young people of his electorate and those in other electorates of much needed employment? His is one of the high unemployment areas of Sydney, but he stands there and says, `I don't care what happens to young people'. If we had had a sensible redevelopment approach to Sydney international those young people might have had a chance of getting employment. The Minister has not taken that into consideration. I hope that when he walks up the main street of St George people go up to him and say, `I am unemployed. Thank you very much for not allowing the proper expansion of Sydney international so that my sons and daughters might have an opportunity to get a job'.

The trouble with this Government is that it does not realise that aviation is big business. Lots of benefits can be gained for Australia's international economy and lots of benefits can be gained through employment for our young people, but obviously that is disregarded. We heard of the tremendous advances that have been made by the establishment of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) and the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). I say on record in this place that so far those decisions have proved to be absolutely disastrous. The prime reason the decisions have been disastrous is simply that the FAC does not know what its responsibilities are; the CAA does not know what its responsibilities are; and indeed this Minister does not know what their responsibilities are. I asked him a question in the House last Thursday week regarding security at Brisbane Airport and he got the answer wrong; he stuffed it up. He did not know which part of the operation airport security came under.

We have heard all about the situation at Sydney international, which is a disaster, but let us look around the rest of Australia. The prime reason Brisbane international cannot take any more international traffic at the moment is that the Government has given it only five gates. Because of the Government's small-minded attitude and its refusal to proceed with the construction of a new international terminal for Brisbane, we are missing out. One of the options which the Government had to take some of the pressure off Sydney international has been lost. As I have said in this House on a number of occasions, private enterprise corporations are prepared to build a brand new terminal costing the taxpayers of Australia not 1c, but the Government closes its mind to that.

What is worse, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson)-this Minister's bosom buddy-gave a major speech in Brisbane last Thursday to the Queensland Tourist Industry Association's annual lunch, at which I was present, and I was appalled at what he said. When he was asked about future growth in tourism he rightly said that there would be about five million coming in the year 2000. In fact, the figure will be 7.8 million. When the follow-up question came to Senator Richardson about what he intended to do about the lack of facilities at Brisbane international he said, `Frankly, I think that there are other areas that are more important than the Brisbane international airport because everybody wants to go to Sydney'. That is probably true. Fifty-eight per cent of the international traffic wants to go through to Sydney. Qantas Airways Ltd says that it will double its capacity by the turn of this century. And what does the Government propose to do? It intends to build a light aircraft strip at Badgerys Creek. Let us get this on the record: How long will it take before there will be full international operations at Badgerys Creek? The latest projection is that it will occur in about the year 2015. So what will we do until then? It will cost about $3 billion, and the Government says that it is not possible to get a third runway in. Of course a parallel runway is possible. Of course it is possible to get quick taxiway exits, which would relieve the traffic. Of course it is possible to kick the air traffic controllers around a little to try to get them to change some of their procedures. But no, the Government does not have the intestinal fortitude to do that either. Of course it is possible to get the whole procedures at Sydney international into some semblance of order.

The Government is not just charging the passengers of Australia higher fares because of its head in the sand attitude. Over the last couple of years, there has been a magnificent increase in the amount of air freight carried in Australia. In September there was an increase in domestic air freight of 7.6 per cent, up to around 40,000 tonnes. That is not counting international air freight. I invite honourable members to look at the freight forwarders and the international freight airlines. They are all screaming for space at Sydney international. There is space capacity there, but the Department and this Minister will do absolutely nothing about it. They are helping to ruin the export market because of that sort of attitude. The whole thing begs comprehension. It is no wonder that people get terribly worried and upset at this continuing lack of effort by the Government.

On numerous occasions in this House we have talked about the growth of international tourism, the contribution that it makes to our economy and the fact that in the last five years an additional 400,000 jobs have been created, but what do we have? Brisbane's terminal is at capacity; Sydney's terminal is at capacity; Cairns is out of control with more and more airlines trying to fly in; there are difficulties in Melbourne with the whole radar set-up; there are tin sheds in Adelaide, in which nobody is terribly interested; and the Government managed to stuff up the Perth terminal. On and on the story goes. The greatest warts on the backside to progress and the future growth of the tourism industry in Australia happen to be the Minister's Department and the attitude that the Minister has taken in recent times on these questions. Until we get some sort of action and sense into the situation, we can never realise the full growth potential of tourism in this country, Never let us forget the figures of the Bureau of Industry Economics that show that every time we increase the number of international tourists coming into this country we provide another 1,400 jobs for young people. The attitude of the Minister and his Department would indicate that they could not care less about that. I hope that the message gets through to the people of St George.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) that the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch) is the honourable member for Barton, not the honourable member for St George. The honourable member for Barton makes one thing very clear; that is, the stark difference between the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who is leaving the chamber now, and our side of politics. The Leader of the Opposition wants to build a third runway into Botany Bay. He also wants to abolish the curfew which currently protects the one million Sydney residents who are affected by aircraft noise. The Leader of the Opposition does not care about those people. He does not care that their lives are affected, that they cannot get to sleep at night and that they cannot pick up television reception as planes zoom in and out of Mascot Airport hour after hour. There are probably people in the galleries today who live near Mascot airport and therefore know what it is like to live near an international airport that operates 24 hours a day. The Leader of the Opposition, who lives in Bennelong on the north shore, does not care about those people and the effect that a 24-hour a day international airport has on them. They are the sorts of people that he is not concerned about. Come the next election campaign he will be shaking hands in the main streets of Hurstville and St George and trying to pretend to the people in those areas that he is not really going to run a third runway in Botany Bay, he is not really going to abolish the curfew, that is something he will look at at a future time.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the Opposition has put it on the record. The shadow Minister for aviation, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), has said that aircraft are getting quieter and in his opinion more jets can be brought in at night. The shadow Minister is saying that the curfew which currently exists at Sydney International Airport should go. The Opposition wants to have jumbo jets and the loud jets of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines coming into Mascot at 2 a.m., 3 a.m. or 4 a.m. What will that do to the people who live in this area?

The shadow Minister commutes from his farm on the New South Wales north coast. The people who live in Sydney should not have to sacrifice their quality of life so that the honourable member and his mates can land there in their jets. People such as John Elliott who are flying around in sleek gold-plated executive jets think that they should be able to land their executive jets at Mascot at any time of the day or night, any day of the year. I think that the people of Australia have a right to decide who uses those runways at Mascot. They are a scarce resource.

Anyone who saw the Sunday television program a few weeks ago which showed a small light aircraft with one or two passengers delaying a jumbo jet carrying hundreds of passengers as it was approaching Mascot airport would understand the problems we face at Mascot. As the Minister said, 15 per cent of its capacity is used by these small aeroplanes, the Pipers and Cherokees, that the shadow Minister mentioned. The shadow Minister believes that those small aircraft should be allowed to hold up the very large jets which are carrying the bulk of Australia's domestic and international commuters.

We on this side of the chamber are prepared to take action to make sure that Sydney Airport works better. This cannot be done by building a third runway into Botany Bay with, as the Minister said, trucks dumping fill into Botany Bay every 30 seconds for five years. That is not the answer. The answer is not to abolish the curfew. The answer is to get the small planes and helicopters which are currently using Mascot out of Mascot. It is ridiculous that the jumbo jets are held up by these small aircraft, especially when the runways at Sydney International Airport are a scare resource.

Let me go to the history of the proposed second international airport for Sydney. In the long term that is the answer to Sydney's airport needs. In the 1970s we had a Liberal Prime Minister, John Gorton, wanting to build Sydney's second international airport at a place called Towra Point in the electorate of Cook. The honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) ran a great campaign to save Towra Point. It ran along the lines of, `Do not build Sydney's second international airport at Towra Point because the residents of Cook would be affected by that international airport'. He had a great win. Prime Minister Gorton backed down. In the next Liberal Government-the McMahon Government-no decision was made, as with many other areas under that Government. The Fraser Government set up the MANS committee. It received lots of submissions but could not make a decision.

The Fraser Government was in power for seven years. What did it do about a second international airport for Sydney? Could it come up with a site? Could it pick a site in the electorate of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock)? No, because he was too busy protecting his constituents. The Liberal Government could not force itself to make a decision. It was too gutless. It had no backbone. It was left to the Hawke Labor Government. It is the only Federal government which has taken the tough decision of picking Sydney's second international airport site. That site is at Badgerys Creek. The Minister has made it clear that there will be a phased development of Sydney's next international airport at Badgerys Creek. That is the long term answer. The answer is not the Opposition's solution of building another runway into Botany Bay and destroying its national park. The solution is not to abolish the curfew and have people kept awake all night. The answer is the phased development of Badgerys Creek.

The Minister has also ensured that there will be other improvements at Mascot to make sure that it runs better. He has announced that $214m will be spent on the new international airport. The shadow Minister scoffs at that. That is something his party never did when it was in power. This Minister is responsible for the Federal Airports Corporation announcing that there will be a new international terminal which will provide not 14 gates as we have at the moment but 22 gates. Many people who fly through Sydney Airport complain about the facilities at Mascot due to the massive expansion in foreign tourists visiting Australia. I can understand that. What is the Government's response to this massive expansion of our tourists?

TALK.START.PARA: —None.

—The honourable member for Mitchell says there has been none. It shows how little he knows about this whole area. This Government is spending $40m of taxpayers' funds on expanding and improving the existing international terminal at Mascot, including new baggage handling facilities. I hope next time the honourable member is jetting off around the world on an overseas trip he will be able to take advantage of the new baggage handling facilities. Then he will not make the ridiculous comment that we are not making any changes.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the aviation industry in Australia as a whole we see that the most fundamental change which will occur in this decade will be due to the fact that this Government has given notice that it will be terminating the two-airline policy. What did the Opposition do about the two-airline policy? The Liberal and National parties signed the two-airline agreement. They brought in regulation in 1952 when in government. The last time the two-airline agreement was renewed was in 1981 when the shadow Minister who is attempting to interject from the Opposition benches was running the National Party in New South Wales. At the same time the National Party in this chamber was fighting as hard as it could to preserve the two-airline agreement. It was fighting the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) and his deregulatory views because they were a danger to the protection of country residents. The National Party rump had a win. It ensured that the two-airline agreement was signed for another 10 years, locking Australia into a restricted regulated environment until the 1990s. Last year this Government, with courage, introduced in this House a motion giving notice of termination of the agreement. I am pleased to say that it finally got the support of the Opposition. Perhaps the National Party has reconsidered its position on this matter.

This Government has introduced other reforms in aviation. We have renegotiated overseas agreements with the United States and Japan to ensure that Qantas Airways Ltd is able to have fairer access to overseas markets. That will help not only Qantas but also Australia because Qantas earns money for all of Australia. The Government has reformed the structure of Australian Airlines so that it is no longer a statutory authority. It is now a company. It is owned 100 per cent by the Government, but it is a company and no longer has those unnecessary and needless bureaucratic controls which were hampering its performance.

I believe that this Government can be proud of the changes it has made in aviation. It has reformed Australian Airlines. Qantas gets a fairer deal in overseas markets. The Minister is responsible for millions of dollars being spent at Mascot to make sure it works. He has tried to get rid of those small general aviation light aircraft that are holding up the large passenger jets that should be using Mascot. What is the Opposition's response? It is against our moving general aviation out of Mascot. It wants to abolish the curfew. It wants to build a third runway in Botany Bay, a proposal that just will not work. Perhaps the crisis is not in this Government's policy on aviation; the crisis is in the Opposition's lack of policy on aviation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION: DEPARTMENT OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the member for O'Connor moving:

That this House authorises the release of all in-camera evidence provided to the Standing Committee on Expenditure Inquiry 1984-85 into the Aboriginal Development Commission and all documents, proceedings and reports of this Committee to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and to all other persons directly associated with such inquiries into the Aboriginal Development Commission or the Aboriginal Affairs Department as the Minister authorises.

In speaking to this motion for the suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders, I remind the House that it is the responsibility of every government to ensure that all expenditure is effective and that the operations of its departments are above charges of maladministration and/or fraud. The recent Senate Estimates committees hearings have uncovered evidence of gross maladministration amongst bodies associated with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. We have asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), in response to his answers in this place that there was no hard evidence to assist him in his inquiries, to look to the reports tabled in this House of the inquiry into the Aboriginal Development Commission by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure.

Consequently, when the Minister was asked today whether he had taken any action on those matters, he responded that because the evidence was given in camera he had no right to see it. Section 340 of the Standing Orders strictly provides for that, but it also provides that, if the House so approves, the matters can be released. The Opposition is pleased today to facilitate that for the Government, to give the Government the assistance it needs to do one simple thing: to run its affairs properly and, of course, to protect the rights of the people for whom this Parliament allocates those moneys. It is interesting to get the views of some of those people. This morning the Australian Broadcasting Corporation sent Mr Mike Carey to Walgett to discuss some of these matters. I would like to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is strictly a motion debating the suspension of Standing Orders. It is not a motion permitting the detailing of the matters that are involved. The honourable member should stick to his motion.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to speak to the motion.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am asking the House to suspend Standing Orders so that the Opposition can move a motion to assist the Government in its administration. It is my responsibility to give the House reasons as to why it should offer me this facility. One of the reasons I am putting this forward is that there is great concern in the community, and the House, therefore, should make the time available for this motion to be debated. Of course, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has a simple solution: he can jump up, accept the motion, and vote with us. If the Government were to be embarrassed by the release of this information to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and his inquiries, I would be agreeably surprised. I am happy for the Leader of the House to say that he will accept the motion and vote to support it. In that case we can all go back to discussing matters on the Notice Paper. However, if he is not prepared to do that but is planning to oppose the motion, it is my job to explain to the House why it should support it.

SPEECH.PARA: I was drawing the attention of honourable members to the fact that certain people would otherwise be in receipt of the moneys that this Parliament allocates to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission. This morning we were told by Mr Carey:
Namoi reserve is out of sight, and out of mind. It's decidedly worse than Toomelah which was called Third World--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. There is a very strict interpretation of Standing Orders applying to a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. It does not permit a canvassing of the issues related to the debate. It is a debate as to whether at a particular period of time there is a requirement for the House to debate this matter now, rather than having it placed on notice. That is what the suspension of Standing Orders is about. Quite clearly, the honourable member for O'Connor is now canvassing broad materials that would be appropriate for a debate on the motion itself.
—I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to address the issue for the suspension of Standing Orders, rather than debate the issue.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have to say to you again that evidence must be given to the House as to the urgency of this motion. The urgency of this motion is contained in the views of the people on this reserve, who are browned off with the Government wasting their money on blooming gambling houses in Canberra.

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will listen to the Chair. The honourable member for O'Connor will be given ample protection by the Chair, but the Chair is requesting that he address the specific issue of the suspension of Standing Orders rather than debate the issue. If the suspension of Standing Orders is resolved in the affirmative, he will have ample time to address the specifics of his concern.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Again I put to you that we are debating the urgency of that matter. I put it to you that it is urgent because there are allegations in the community relating to fraud, corruption and maladministration in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and its associated commissions. They have been dealt with at some length in the Senate. Consequently, the Minister has told us that he lacks evidence. The Standing Committee on Expenditure has to my knowledge, because I was a member of it at the time, a literal raft of evidence that in some cases would make one's hair stand on end. People are concerned. I thought that there was a third component to this Parliament-the people. The people are concerned. Consequently, we are asking the House to enable the suspension of Standing Orders so that this Parliament can give the Minister permission to view that evidence. Mr Deputy Speaker, I wanted to give you some examples of the urgency of that matter in terms of the views of these people. The words I read out a few minutes ago are evidence that there are Aboriginal people living in shocking circumstances while a department of this Government proposes to give $1m for a gambling club in Canberra, another $1m for a hotel that can only bring upon these people further degradation--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, these are matters that were in no way canvassed by this 1985 committee report. The honourable member is obliged to argue in this House--
—How do you know?

—It is alleged to have happened last year. No, it did not happen in 1985. So the remarks of the honourable member for O'Connor are quite clearly irrelevant to a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.
—Order! I have asked the honourable member--

—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will cease interjecting. He is interfering with the time available to his own speaker. I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to heed the Chair and to direct the discussion to the suspension of Standing Orders.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, let me now refer to the actual reports. The first report, which was a unanimous report, I recollect, barring one small dissent, said:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of other matters brought to the attention of the Committee have involved serious allegations of maladministration which in some instances may lead to criminal prosecution.

The Committee went on to add that it would submit another report-the second report. However, in the interim, the Committee got a Mr John Coombs, QC, to give it some assistance. Mr Coombs is reported as referring to the now Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Perkins, in the following terms:
Perkins was generally an evasive and unhelpful witness from whom Committee attempts to seek answers were probably a waste of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a further point of order. These matters have been in the public domain since 1985. The honourable member for O'Connor has not explained to this House why this matter cannot be dealt with in the normal way on notice and why the suspension of Standing Orders is necessary three years later. He has not explained that to this point.

—In the time remaining let me say that we are raising the urgency of this matter because the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs advised the House this morning that he was not able to read the in camera evidence or pass it on to the inquiries which have been announced by the Government. We are asking for the suspension of Standing Orders so that we can assist the Government to provide that information to the Minister. As I said, I can think of no better reason for the Leader of the House to move us to that situation straightaway. Let us have that vote so that we can see whether the Government is game to let the Minister read the evidence about his own Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and about the way in which his Government is running Aboriginal Affairs, to the detriment of the poor Aboriginal people.
—Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. The motion before the House is to suspend Standing Orders to enable to be debated and, I hope, carried a motion that would release to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) certain information that is presently the information of a committee of this Parliament. This week the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has been under severe questioning in relation to the administrative and other arrangements within his Department and the organisations under his control. Yesterday in the way in which he answered a question, I thought he put his reputation on the line in a very positive way. He said that if there were any allegations drawn to his attention relating to the conduct and affairs within his Department, or the people within his responsibility, he would urgently set in train inquiries and investigations to see that any doubts that might arise were fully examined. He made it quite clear that if information of a serious nature was brought before him he would act quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: Today he was asked whether he would act in relation to some findings that were before the former House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, albeit some time ago, and he has now sought to hide behind the procedures of this Parliament because the evidence on which the allegations were based was taken in camera and is the property of that Committee, unless it is opened by the Parliament. What this proposal is seeking to do--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask that that comment be withdrawn. It is wrong and dishonest to say that that is the position.
—Order! The honourable member for Sturt will withdraw the word `dishonest'.
—The Minister said `dishonest'.
—I did not use the word `dishonest'.
—`Sought to hide', you said.
—The Minister said `dishonest'. Couldn't you hear him?
—I do not really need the assistance of the honourable member for North Sydney. I call the honourable member for Sturt.

—Therefore, in the light of the commitment made by the Minister, it is urgent that he should have made available to him all the information upon which allegations are based. Some of that information is the property of the former Expenditure Committee and, through the rules of this House, is the property of this House. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) is proposing that there should be a debate so that this House can decide whether that information should be made available to the Minister so that he can examine it on its merits.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that when members of the Expenditure Committee did go into the matter, instead of doing as a large number of the members of the Committee recommended-mostly those sitting on this side of the House-and having a judicial inquiry, they said that they would get the opinion of a Queen's Counsel. The Queen's Counsel examined the information that was before the parliamentary Committee and recommended that certain matters be referred to the Australian Federal Police for potential prosecution. The Committee then took the matter into its hands and by the Government members using their majority sought-in conflict with Mr Coombs's advice that the Committee was not a criminal investigating body-to investigate the matter itself, and in a most unsatisfactory way reached the conclusion that there was no further matter to be dealt with. They then went behind the whole Committee and referred the matter again to Mr Coombs. He wrote to the then Chairman of the Committee and said:
. . . I see no reason to disagree with the Committee's decision-
which was a bare majority of all Labor members voting against the coalition members-
not to pursue the various allegations further beyond the current investigations by appropriate authorities in respect of the allegations against Mr O'Brien.
The significant thing is that he did not say `not to go against the allegations against Mr Perkins'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will reject this motion because it has too much respect for the way in which evidence is given to parliamentary committees to take this nonsense for one minute.
—Cover-up.

—There is nothing for us to cover up as far as this matter is concerned. The considerations that were before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, which reported in 1985, were almost exclusively about the administration of this portfolio during the Opposition's period in government. The administration of the portfolio, I believe, was in the hands of the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), who sat on that Committee in a semi-judicial position despite the fact that matters that were being considered by that Committee went to the question ultimately of his administration. The performance of the Opposition at that time gave it a sufficient degree of embarrassment for it to determine then that it would no longer proceed with it. We are talking about a committee report which is now supposed to be urgent that was dealt with in this Parliament three years ago, about administration of matters by the Opposition when it was in government. We are supposed to regard this as a relevant matter for consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time the matter was dealt with by the Parliament a couple of points were made quite clear: the Committee had obtained legal advice about the matters that were raised before it. That legal advice suggested that some matters ought to be referred to the Australian Federal Police for investigation. They were referred to the Federal Police for investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they weren't.
—Some matters, not all of them, were referred to the Federal Police for investigation and the Federal Police found that there was nothing further to proceed with. The other matters--

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am concerned at the assertion the Minister has made. He is suggesting that evidence before a committee of this Parliament has been referred to the Federal Police. As I understand our Standing Orders, they prevent the disclosure of any evidence before any committee of this place. If that is so, I suggest that that is a very serious breach of Standing Orders of this place. We seek to lift any veil on those proceedings, albeit some of them affected the matters that took place during our term in government. I suggest that the Minister needs to direct himself specifically to his concerns in that area.

—The right honourable member knows very well what the response of that situation was because he debated it in Parliament at the time and that matter was covered during the debate in Parliament. So he should not come in here with his bogus respectability on that particular subject. The fact of the matter is that the Committee chose, as any committee is entitled to do, to seek what help it needed to arrive at its conclusions. The right honourable member should not come into this place with that sort of nonsense. Of course a committee is entitled to seek what help it needs in arriving at its conclusions. In this instance it did choose, as I understand it, to seek the assistance of authorities and, in the other instance, sought the assistance of Mr Coombs. As I understand it, Mr Coombs, QC, looked at some seven matters that were referred to him by the Committee and did not say that a prima facie case had been established on any of them, but did say that it was appropriate for the Committee to look at those matters further. The Committee did choose to look at those matters further and it came to a series of conclusions that were put down in this place. They were available for debate in this place and were the subject of a minority report, but the Opposition chose to take that no further.

SPEECH.PARA: We suddenly find it reappearing at this point for one reason and one reason alone-a pathetic stunt. That is what has come forward from members of the Opposition on this matter at this time. It is part of a pathetic stunt to try to distract attention from their own known difficulties and to attempt to open out other matters that have been quite adequately covered by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand).

There are many reasons why we do not think it is appropriate to suspend Standing Orders on this matter that go beyond simply matters related to these subjects which were canvassed appropriately at the time. They go to the matter of the protection of the sensible conduct of committee business in this place. The committees operate with a considerable degree of authority from this Parliament. We all from time to time have concern about natural justice related to our committees and not all of us are fully convinced on all occasions that our committees do operate in a way that is consistent with normal principles of natural justice. Therefore we tend to be extremely careful, if we are wise, on our committees about how we handle the evidence that is presented to us. Committees quite sensibly seek for many reasons to take some evidence in camera. Sometimes it is in order to be able to tease out facts and sometimes it is to protect the reputation of other individuals against bogus allegations which cannot be sustained, but a great deal of damage can be done to persons involved. All these matters are considered by committees when they decide to hold evidence in camera. We in this Parliament have always, wisely, left it to committees to determine when to recommend to this Parliament that matters held in camera should be revealed publicly. In fact, committees very rarely do that for the very sensible reason that they seek to protect their business in order to advise the House properly on matters that come before them.

To walk away from that places us in several difficult situations. It threatens to call into doubt the viability of the operations of parliamentary committees. We vest parliamentary committees with enormous powers. They have the authority, like this House if it so wishes, to act in a star chamber manner. We are able to do that. However, we attempt to exercise some form of self-restraint. The Opposition today is effectively inviting us to vest star chamber powers in committees, against the committees' own recommendations. Do honourable members opposite think for one moment that, if a committee believed that it could usefully release in camera evidence in a way that protected people's right to natural justice, it would not have recommended that? Of course it would have. As I said at the outset, these matters went to investigations of the administration of a portfolio set up by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then what are you worried about?

—I know that the honourable member for O'Connor will find this difficult to comprehend, but a few of us on this side of the House actually have some respect for principles of natural justice. I know that he finds it extraordinarily difficult to come to grips with this because he operates in this place with the full possibilities open for star chamber processes. That is his mode of operation. He finds himself in some degree of difficulty when he confronts us and suggests that we should behave in the way he normally conducts himself in this House.
