We are prepared to recognise that he has a psychological problem with projection but, at the same time, we do not feel that we necessarily need to have visited upon us the way in which honourable members opposite seek to conduct their business here.

SPEECH.PARA: We, on this side of the House, believe in due processes. In select committees anybody-this is not totally undesirable-should feel free to unburden himself of anything he happens to think. I have served on parliamentary committees and know that a fair bit of what is presented to them is bogus, nonsense and often libellous. That is fine. Parliamentary committees are entitled to receive from the electorate a full range of opinions, views and allegations on any matter. But a prudent parliamentary committee determines when a reputation is likely to be unjustly damaged and uses that as one of the criteria for determining when evidence should be taken in camera. I recollect-I may stand corrected on this-that while there may have been arguments from the other side of the House over whether all matters had been appropriately investigated, there was one matter on which all sides agreed. There is no suggestion, in the record, as far as I can see, that in camera evidence should be made public. Three years ago, when Opposition members had the opportunity to sit down and deliberate on this, they had various views on how the matter should be handled, but their views did not include the view that in camera evidence should be made public. They had a degree of principle in the position they were adopting at that time, but that degree of principle seems to have deserted them today.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has come into this House with a series of bogus arguments. The real reasons for his coming in here were revealed in his argument because he did not raise a single matter associated with any of the matters before the Expenditure Committee but other matters that had been the subject of recent consideration by the Senate. That is what the honourable member for O'Connor was talking about-other matters raised by the Senate. This reveals the true reason for his coming in here and being prepared to suspend natural justice associated with people who appear before committees. We reject this nonsense out of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: Radio Licence Fees Bill

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House of the following nominations of members to the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation: Mr Ronald Edwards, Mr Kerr and Mr Lindsay have been nominated on behalf of the Prime Minister, and Mr Peter Fisher and Mr Smith have been nominated on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition.

Bill presented by Mr Kerin, for Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill marks a further phase in the Government's policy of extending greater choice in radio and television services to the people of Australia. It implements the first stage of the national plan for metropolitan radio services which will provide more commercial FM radio outlets in mainland State capital cities and establish AM networks for parliamentary broadcasting and radio for the print handicapped (RPH). The plan, announced by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, on 9 August this year, addresses several interlocking issues. These are: the general desire by existing AM licensees to convert to FM; the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's (ABC) wish to extend its JJJ youth network and to provide for parliamentary broadcasting in a cost effective manner which does not disrupt ABC programming; the need to expand and improve radio for the print handicapped services; and the desirability of reforming the existing system of allocating frequencies for commercial purposes and deriving an appropriate return to the community from the commercial use of a public resource, namely the FM radio spectrum.

The national metropolitan radio plan involves two stages. Under the first stage eligible commercial AM licensees will be invited to lodge bids for the right to convert from their existing AM frequencies to FM frequencies. The two highest eligible bidders in each capital city will be selected to convert to the FM frequencies. A condition of eligibility for the tender process will be that the successful tenderers must transfer their AM transmission facilities and sites to the Commonwealth for use by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for parliamentary broadcasts, and by public licensees for radio for the print handicapped purposes. I intend shortly to invite applications for a public radio licence serving print handicapped listeners for the first vacated AM channel in each mainland State capital.

The second stage of the plan will involve invitation for tenders for two new commercial FM radio licences in each mainland State capital. I intend to bring forward legislation in the autumn sittings of 1989 to implement this second stage. This will provide time for more detailed consultation on the process proposed for stage 2. It also will allow these steps to be considered in the context of the review of the Broadcasting Act currently being undertaken by the Department of Transport and Communications, and the current inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure into the role of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

Two of the central aims which this Government has consistently pursued in its broadcasting policy have been to maximise diversity of choice in radio and television services and to limit concentration of media ownership and control. These objectives are being pursued through a significant expansion of existing services and through the introduction of new, competitive services. In television, the policy of equalisation is bringing new commercial television services to regional areas. We are also well advanced in providing additional commercial radio services in regional areas. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has made decisions on new FM commercial radio licences in Newcastle, Geelong, the Gold Coast, Gosford, Shepparton and Moree. Two supplementary FM licences are on air in Canberra. Tribunal inquiries are under way in Ipswich, Geraldton and Townsville, and will soon begin in Mildura, Hobart, Lismore, Mackay, Renmark, Darwin, Albany, Kempsey and Nowra. The program up to the end of 1990 will bring new commercial radio services to some 4.2 million people. I will soon be announcing a further phase of the program for 1991. In public radio, at least six to eight new services are being introduced each year while the ABC continues to expand its services with the development of the second regional radio network. Consistent with this policy of extension of services, the national metropolitan radio plan should increase the diversity of radio services available to listeners in the mainland State capitals. In conjunction with the existing one-to-a-market ownership limit, the entry of new operators into the industry will further diversify the ownership of radio stations.
Tender Procedures

The Bill empowers the Minister to invite applications from existing metropolitan commercial AM licensees for conversion to FM. Applications will be submitted to the tender board of the Department of Transport and Communications. Applications will include sealed bids and a range of other material detailing the nature and value of the AM transmission facilities which will be provided to the Commonwealth in part satisfaction of that bid. The transmission equipment will need to meet technical standards set by the Minister and the interest in the transmission site will need to be sufficient to ensure continuing delivery of parliamentary and RPH services. The equipment will be valued by the Department and the site by the Australian Valuation Office, with facility for reference to commercial arbitration in the event of disputes.

Bids will be subject to a confidential reserve price established by the Minister. A secure procedure will be followed to ensure that the reserve price remains confidential. After the closing date, the Tender Board will examine the applications and reject any which do not meet the prescribed conditions, and provide the Minister with a ranking of applicants whose bids exceed the reserve from the highest bidder down. The Minister will offer FM frequencies to the two highest bidding applicants, with the highest bidder having its choice of preferred frequency, subject to normal planning considerations. Where the successful applicant defaults, the next highest bidder will be offered a frequency. In making offers to the successful applicants, the Minister will advise the date by which the fee as bid must be paid and the AM facilities transferred. The Minister will be empowered to re-call tenders if satisfied that there has been collusion in tendering.
Radio for the Print Handicapped

RPH services have been operating unsatisfactorily for some years outside the broadcast band, on low power and with sub-standard equipment. This legislation empowers the Commonwealth to acquire transmission sites and associated AM equipment from existing commercial licensees in part satisfaction of their bid for conversion to FM. The Commonwealth will then lease these facilities to RPH groups at a nominal rent. I will invite applications for a public radio licence to serve print handicapped listeners on the first vacated AM frequency in each mainland State capital. The tender procedure for conversion of AM commercial licensees will ensure that the sites and facilities tendered are adequate to provide an acceptable signal across the metropolitan areas.

The Government had previously intended that RPH services would be provided on FM frequencies. However, the technical characteristics of AM are more appropriate to the predominantly spoken word RPH programs and the availability of vacated AM frequencies and facilities from the conversion of AM commercial stations provides an excellent opportunity to improve the quality of existing RPH services in mainland State capitals. The only disadvantage is that AM transmitters are more expensive than FM to operate. The Government will therefore provide a grant of $100,000 per year to meet this extra cost. In Canberra and Hobart frequencies are available on the FM band and will be allocated in 1990. A capital grant of $600,000 will be provided in 1990-91 to assist the establishment of these two new RPH stations.
Parliamentary Broadcasts

For many years the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has met its legislative obligation to broadcast parliamentary proceedings. This has been at some cost to the ABC in the development of coherent radio programming and also in building up its audience. This legislation will facilitate the use by the ABC of the sites and facilities of the successful tenderer for the second frequency in each city for the establishment of a parliamentary broadcasting network. The new and permanent network for parliamentary broadcasting will replace the interim parliamentary broadcasting network which is presently being established through the use of the ABC's standby transmission facilities. Following the complete transfer from Radio National to the interim network, the ABC will be able further to develop Radio National as a high quality news and talk service.
The Extension of the ABC's Youth Network

An important part of the national plan is the extension of the ABC's JJJ FM service from Sydney to the other capital cities. This initiative links with the Government's recent establishment of the Australian Contemporary Popular Music Development Company. The youth network will be financed by the ABC from its existing resources and requires no legislative amendments.
Financial Implications

This Bill has no direct financial consequences, because the formal obligation to pay the fees it introduced will be imposed under the Radio Licence Fees Act 1964 through amendments introduced in the accompanying Radio Licence Fees (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill 1988.

In conclusion, I believe this Bill creates new opportunities for commercial radio operators in the mainland capital cities. The ability for some AM stations to convert to FM will help to redress the imbalance between commercial operators using the AM and FM bands. The Government hopes that this will lead to a more dynamic approach to programming, resulting in a more diverse range of services to the community. Commercial broadcasting has shown a capacity to meet changing circumstances. In recent years, the level of competition has increased markedly with the introduction of new commercial radio services, particularly on FM. Competition is likely to intensify as AM stations convert to FM in stage 1 of the plan and later with the establishment of two additional commercial stations. The listening public should welcome the addition of new commercial FM services as testified to by the success of existing commercial FM stations. I table the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: RADIO LICENCE FEES (NATIONAL METROPOLITAN RADIO PLAN) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented Mr Kerin, for Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill formally imposes the obligation to pay the fee on conversion from AM to FM broadcasting by large city commercial radio licensees determined in accordance with the tender process introduced in the Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill 1988. It is purely a machinery Bill and all the relevant policy elements are covered by the accompanying Broadcasting Bill.
Financial Implications

The first stage of the national plan, implemented in this Bill and the accompanying Broadcasting (National Metropolitan Radio Plan) Bill 1988, is expected to produce net revenue of $79.9m over the five years from 1988-89 to 1992-93, with an ongoing annual additional cost of $0.2m. This comprises revenue from tendering for AM-FM conversion, partially offset by the costs of retaining vacated AM sites and facilities for parliamentary and radio for the print handicapped networks and some small additional capital and recurrent outlays.

A $0.6m capital grant will be provided in 1990-91 for the establishment of FM RPH stations in Canberra and Hobart. The Appropriation Bills provide for an ongoing annual subsidy to RPH of $100,000 to meet the additional cost of maintaining AM rather than FM facilities, and an increase in the grant-in-aid for RPH from $25,000 to $125,000 per annum. They also provide for additional departmental administration expenses of $400,000 in 1988-89. An additional $100,000 will be required in 1989-90. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill and the associated Levy Collection Bill will provide the basis for the establishment of triticale research funding arrangements. The triticale industry will join other small emerging industries unable to support their own independent administrative arrangements in developing a research capacity under the auspices of the Australian special rural research fund. The Bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on triticale produced in Australia for the purpose of funding triticale industry research. The associated Triticale Levy Collection Bill 1988 will provide the machinery for collecting the levy. Expenditure of moneys raised through the levy will be matched dollar for dollar by the Commonwealth. Administrative and organisational arrangements for the research scheme will be provided by the Australian Special Rural Research Council pursuant to the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. The triticale industry is a relatively small industry but has the capacity to expand its domestic markets and possibly to develop significant export markets.

Industry research to date has been funded by a voluntary levy on the industry with some Commonwealth funds from the Australian special rural research fund. The industry has established research programs in several States but those programs have rested on a precarious funding base, with no capacity to expand to meet the needs of an emerging industry. Recently these programs and funding have proven inadequate to cover the range of issues the industry needs to address to develop as an efficient and competitive industry on the domestic market and in a hostile world market. The Commonwealth supported program is intended to provide secure arrangements for an expanded research effort into production and beyond that into areas such as economic and marketing research.

The legislation provides for an initial levy rate of $1 per tonne of triticale. Provision exists for the rate to be varied by regulation up to a maximum of $2 per tonne. Provision is also made for any recommendations arising from consultation between the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the triticale industry organisation to be taken into account prior to any adjustment to the operative rate of the levy or leviable weight.

Amounts equal to the levy will be paid into a separate account established for the purpose in the special research fund. This will be accommodated by a provision in the accompanying amendments to the Rural Industries Research Act 1985. The Commonwealth's matching contribution will be up to a maximum level equal to 0.5 per cent of the average gross value of triticale production. It is expected that initially the levy will raise about $160,000. The Special Research Council will therefore have scope for an annual triticale research program approaching $300,000.

The commencement date of this legislation will be a date to be proclaimed. It is intended that the levy be imposed on triticale produced in the 1988 harvest. A full year research program under the scheme cannot begin until 1989-90. However, the actual level of expenditure on research will be determined by the Special Research Council and it is possible some research could be funded in 1988-99. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide the machinery necessary for collecting the levy imposed by the Triticale Levy Bill 1988. This Bill should be read as one with the Triticale Levy Bill 1988, and is to come into operation on the same day that the levy Bill becomes operative. The Bill specifies the liability of purchasers and receivers under the scheme, outlines penalties for non-compliance and provides appropriate powers of enforcement. There are no financial implications other than those covered in the second reading speech for the Triticale Levy Bill 1988. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The purposes of this Bill are:
(a) to provide for an improved organisational and administrative framework under the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 (principal Act);
(b) to enable the expenses of collection and administration relating to relevant levies to be recovered from the Australian special rural research fund; and
(c) to remedy minor defects in regulations under the principal Act.
The main organisational amendments will enable:
(a) new levies to be added to existing rural research schemes without having the effect of creating new councils and new trust funds;
(b) matching Commonwealth contributions for any statutory levies paid into the Australian special rural research fund; and
(c) the amalgamation, reorganisation and winding up of councils and trust funds.

The first two of those amendments will have imminent application under the Australian special rural research fund in relation to the triticale industry. Bills for triticale industry levy imposition and levy collection were introduced with the Rural Industries Research Amendment Bill 1988. Amounts equal to triticale levies received into Commonwealth revenue will be paid into the Australian special rural research fund to be used for the purposes of research and development relating to the triticale industry. The Government will provide funds on a matching basis up to a maximum contribution of 0.5 per cent of the triticale industry's gross value of production, in the same way as it provides matching contributions to existing rural research funds. Negotiations are well advanced for the addition of other small industry research levies.

There is no immediate application contemplated of the new provisions enabling the amalgamation, reorganisation and winding up of councils and trust funds. The new provisions would allow, for example, a smaller fund to amalgamate with a larger fund for economic purposes. The amendments would also provide, in that event, for the smaller fund, and council, to be wound up and the money in that fund, relevant levies and research agreements to be transferred to the larger fund. Where such an amalgamation takes place, levies raised from each industry involved and the Government's matching contributions will continue to be for the purpose of funding research for that industry.

The amendments enabling new levies to be added to existing rural research schemes without having the effect of creating new councils and new trust funds will not apply in relation to the barley and wheat trust funds and councils. This exclusion from the Bill had regard to the need to consult with the State research committees for barley and wheat before including them in such an amendment and the current examination of the feasibility of a grains research and development corporation which could include both barley and wheat.

There are three main amendments to the administrative framework. First, there is a clarification of the form for the annual research and development program that councils are required to submit to the Minister for approval. The new form will provide for essential information, without unnecessary detail, to be included in a council's annual program for the Minister's consideration. Approval of individual project expenditure will continue to be the responsibility of councils.

Secondly, councils will be able to replace a partly completed five-year research and development plan with a varied plan to cover a new five-year period. Under existing arrangements, a council's plan, or varied plan, relates to a fixed five-year period at the end of which a new plan is prepared for a further fixed five-year period. The new arrangements will provide councils and State research committees with more flexibility in their planning systems, particularly in incorporating changing industry and market circumstances.

Thirdly, the existing legislation requires the approval of councils or State research committees for the bulk of expenditure under sections 9 and 36 of the principal Act. However, some expenditure relating to a council, or State research committee, for example, administrative expenses and investment management expenses, can be made currently without the approval of the council or committee. This is clearly undesirable. This legislation will require council or State research committee approval for all such expenditure that relates to it.

The Australian special rural research fund (ASRRF) was established to support small and infant industries. It has been funded from appropriation sources. There has been no attached industry levy. The legislation provides for small industry levies to be credited to ASRRF. When the triticale levy imposition and levy collection Bills currently before the House become law, the triticale levies will be attached to the ASRRF. In line with Government policy, the principal Act is being amended to enable the expenses of collection and administration of relevant levies to be recovered from the ASRRF. A number of minor defects have been identified in the regulations under the principal Act. These are being remedied by provisions in the Bill.

This Bill will contribute to effecting Government policy on rural research funding. The Bill facilitates matching Commonwealth funding of rural research under the Australian special rural research fund, but of itself has no budgetary implications beyond those announced in the May 1988 statement on primary industries and resources.

As I have said on many occasions, rural research is a high priority of the Government. This is partly reflected in the Government's commitment to increase Commonwealth matching contributions to rural research to a maximum of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production for each of the industries concerned. Commonwealth matching funding for 1988-89 is budgeted at $65.4m. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:PRIVACY BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (TAX FILE NUMBERS) BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was saying before the suspension of the sitting for lunch that it is most regrettable-indeed, scandalous-that the Privacy Bill 1988 has come before us for debate today when it was introduced only yesterday. Normally we expect at least a week's opportunity to study legislation. Even since getting halfway through my speech before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I have come across other material which I have not had an adequate opportunity to digest. I will have to give it to my good friend Senator Peter Baume to examine when the Senate deals with this legislation next week.

SPEECH.PARA: Amongst the material I have found on this matter is an examination of the previous Bill, upon which this Bill was based, by an academic named Maeve McDonagh at La Trobe University, published in the Legal Service Bulletin of August 1987. It is a devastating criticism of the failure of the Government to protect the privacy rights of individuals from the Government's desire for more and more information about people. I have not had an opportunity since discovering this article to compare the 1986 Bill with this one-they are both massive pieces of legislation-but one suspects that the haste with which this Bill was prepared has left it with many of the deficiencies that are highlighted in this publication. It is a devastating condemnation but we will have to wait for a senator-Senator Baume, no doubt-to find the faults in this Bill, if the faults remain, as I suspect they do.

I do not see evidence of the Government having taken account of the example of other countries, such as Italy, the Netherlands, Sweden, Belgium, Denmark and France, which have defined certain categories of information about individuals which may not be stored. For example, in Belgium, information may not be stored concerning racial origin, sexual orientation, political and religious beliefs, trade union membership and sickness insurance. In each of the countries I have mentioned a range of items is excluded. I believe that it is very important for our well-being that we examine what we have asked government agencies and allowed private agencies to collect about people and decide that some of what is now collected ought to be expunged and not collected again. I see no evidence of the Government being aware of those kinds of problems.

The New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties has pointed out, too, that under clause 15 of this Bill information privacy principles 1, 2, 3, 10 and 11 apply only in relation to information collected after the commencement of the Act. That may be appropriate in respect of principles 1, 2 and 3 but not, I would have thought, in respect of principles 10 and 11. I ask the Minister who is to respond to this debate to explain why principles 10 and 11 apply only to information gathered after the commencement date of operation. It seems to me to be a major deficiency.

I would like briefly to turn to the interim guidelines in schedule 2 concerning the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information. As they stand, they are certainly an important step along the way to what we in opposition would like to see and what we believe the public should have. Guideline 1.1 states the Parliament's clear intention that the tax file number should not become the basis of a national identification scheme. Guideline 1.2 reinforces the prohibitions on unauthorised cross-matching of tax file numbers with personal records of individuals. That is important. Also, the guidelines prescribe that the collection of tax file number information should be carried out in a way which minimises the opportunity for unlawful recording of tax file numbers and, under the storage guideline, an effort is made to ensure that access is confined to those with a need to know and is not available to all staff of an employer or a financial institution. Having said that, I fear that the guidelines, especially as they relate to the private sector, are deficient, but I shall come back to that.

To deal briefly with the Bill itself, on the positive side, it is important in the light of the remarks I made at the outset of my speech this morning that clause 27 enable the Privacy Commissioner to undertake research into and to monitor developments in data processing and computer technology to ensure that any adverse effects of such developments on the privacy of individuals are minimised. That is exceedingly important because the rate at which technology is developing can mean many invasions of privacy quite uncontemplated by any act of this Parliament or any administration of the Privacy Commissioner. Financial resources have to be made available to the Privacy Commissioner to enable him to be able to undertake the research and monitoring of developments referred to in clause 27.

Clause 28 is a very desirable clause. It enables the Commissioner to examine the records of the Commissioner of Taxation to ensure that the Australian Taxation Office is not using tax file information for unauthorised purposes and is taking adequate measures to prevent the unlawful disclosure of the tax file number information which it holds. There are some obviously desirable steps in this Bill, but I have some concerns about whether it goes far enough. One illustration is in part VIII of the Bill, which gives effect to certain recommendations made by the Law Reform Commission. I think I said this morning that that Commission reported in 1976. In fact, it was commissioned to inquire into privacy in 1976 but did not report until 1983. In paragraph 828 of its report entitled Privacy, the Law Reform Commission summarised the action for breach of confidence as providing:

a civil remedy for use or disclosure of information which is not publicly known and which has been entrusted to a person in circumstances imposing an obligation not to use or disclose that information without the authority of the person from whom it has directly or indirectly been obtained.

This Bill incorporates that recommendation, but again, as my colleague the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) will say in the committee stage of the debate, it does not go far enough to give a right of action to individuals.

I was talking before lunch of the relevance of privacy impact statements. In effect, we are asking the Commissioner for such statements. The Commissioner will require a greater job description than this Bill gives, and will probably require greater powers than this Bill provides. Nevertheless, it is an important first step. But it has a long way to go before it becomes a fully fledged privacy law.

The first of the information privacy principles relates to Commonwealth agencies having a lawful purpose for collecting personal information. Apart from the onus which we are placing on the Privacy Commissioner, this Parliament has an obligation to consider carefully each purpose which it makes lawful and, I believe, to examine each purpose which it has made lawful in the past. It is most important in this age of technology that we examine what we are asking of people, why we are doing it and what use we are putting it to. Perhaps the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, or the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances should have a privacy impact study function added to its responsibilities. I will put that thought to some of my Senate colleagues.

I am glad that the Bill recognises the special nature of medical research and epidemiological research in particular. I am also very glad that the Privacy Commissioner can and should make random audits of agencies, including the Commissioner of Taxation, so that they examine their databases to ensure that adherence to the information privacy principles is maintained. It is also commendable that the Parliament may review and disallow determinations of the Privacy Commissioner that an agency has adopted a practice in breach of the information privacy principles contained in this Bill. If agencies are going to breach the principles, we should have the final surveillance of that. The balancing of public interest considerations is always complex, and it is proper and wise for the Parliament to have surveillance over and the ultimate responsibility for those decisions. It will help us to develop an increasingly stronger law of privacy.

The interim guidelines to which I have referred look like a reasonable beginning, but it is again wise and proper for the Bill to give the Parliament the obligation to review the permanent guidelines and to disallow them if it sees fit. I hope that whoever is appointed as Privacy Commissioner will welcome personal contact with members to get insights into problems and to undertake a more liberal interpretation of this and the associated legislation, which otherwise is quite narrowly drawn. The private sector remains the problem area. There is not enough information available to us about the private sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill being debated in the House today continues this Government's proud record on taxation. Many people will remember that, prior to 1983, there was a feeling in the community that there were two sets of standards as regards taxation: those for people of substantial means who were able to choose whether they paid tax; and the poor old mug, the pay as you earn taxpayer, who took up the slack because some of the former chose not to pay tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the things that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill does not do are very important. For instance, there is no compulsion to use the tax file number and to carry a card. The simple fact is that if a person does not use the tax file number in the way it is intended, tax will be taken out of income at the top marginal rate, plus the Medicare levy. So the tax is still collected one way or the other. I believe that in the wider community there will be general acceptance of the principles behind the tax file number and that people will volunteer that information to bodies such as banks and other financial institutions.

Also, there will not be any databank. In Western Australia a number of letters have been sent to the editor of the local newspaper trying to draw comparisons between this legislation and the Australia Card. Of course, no databank is intended. It is interesting to note that the Australian Taxation Office has used a tax file number since 1936. I believe that the integrity of that tax file number is very high because the Taxation Office does not release that sort of information.

As a result of the legislation before us today, no more information will have to be delivered to the Tax Office. It is rather surprising to the person in the street just how much information the Tax Office gets. For instance, the amount of interest paid on every savings account in Australia is furnished to the Tax Office, and has been for quite some time. I remember taking part in a parliamentary committee inquiry in Melbourne and an executive of one of our large banks talked about what was termed the good old days when 20 trucks used to roll up to the main branch in Melbourne and take away reams of information from that bank to the Taxation Office. Of course, that exposes the deficiency in taking 20 truckloads of information from just one bank in Melbourne, let alone all the other banks and financial institutions that also make available to the Taxation Office all of the information that is required of them.

The simple fact is that it is an impossible job to match all of that information against what a taxpayer has furnished in his statement. What the Bill does is to bring the Taxation Office into the 1980s. It allows it to use technology that would simply enable computers to match numbers attached to each of the statements that are given to the Taxation Office with the statements furnished by taxpayers. As the saying goes, honest taxpayers have nothing to hide. I believe that the vast majority of Australians fall into that category. For that reason, I believe that the measure should be supported. Another thing that the Bill does not do is to link this information with any other government agency. For that reason it can be seen to be very secure. The Taxation Office is the only beneficiary of the Bill before us.

A very important point that must be stressed is that the Bill will not increase taxes: it is not a tax increasing or revenue Bill. All it does is give the Taxation Office the power to collect tax more efficiently. By collecting tax more efficiently, there will be a shift in the tax burden. It is a desirable shift because it makes those people who are not paying tax pay it and it gives relief to the people who have been taking up the slack-the poor old mugs out there who are honest enough to put everything on their statements and for years have been carrying the can, so to speak. For that reason alone, the Bill deserves support.

The Opposition's position on the legislation is to be commended. In supporting the Government's recommendation to support the tax file number, the Opposition has increased public recognition of the fact that some Opposition members at least do care about what happens to the Taxation Office, although I am moved to say that that is not unanimous, certainly within the Liberal Party. I quote from an article which appeared in today's West Australian:
The State Liberal individual rights spokesman, Mr Hassell, said the decision of his Federal colleagues was both wrong and politically incompetent.

By way of explanation, Mr Hassell is not well known on this side of Australia, but back in the early 1980s he was a member of a government that brought in the 54b legislation in Western Australia which restricted individual rights. Under the legislation introduced by the government of which Mr Hassell was a Minister, it was unlawful for more than three people to meet in the streets of Perth without a permit. As well, later on in his career as Minister for Police Mr Hassell used the 54b legislation to smash through picket lines at Noonkanbah, which was a very damaging thing morally to the Aboriginal people of north-west Australia. One can see that in those days the present State Liberal individual rights spokesman did not care too much about individual rights. But we must make allowances because he is a born-again civil libertarian and is now trying to protect what he deems the individual rights of some people. The article continued:
Referring to the Federal MPs, he said: I am sorry that they compromised themselves by negotiating with the Government over the associated privacy legislation.
Privacy is important. But it is not the main issue. Australians should not be made accountable to the Commonwealth Government through a computer data bank.

The Western Australian Liberals at least show their ignorance and opposition to this move, unlike the Liberals here. I believe that in the Party room yesterday a number of speakers were against the legislation. I believe that those members came from Western Australia where, it seems, they have a fanatical opposition to legislation of this type. One wonders why. It seems to me at least that they remember the last days of the Australia Card with some relish and believe that they played some major role in the activities of that time. It seems to me that the imminent election in Western Australia may have something to do with it. Mr Hassell and his colleagues in Western Australia-I could refer to another spokesman there, but as he is not well known I will not do so-seek to have the Liberal Party in Canberra oppose the legislation for nothing more than grubby political ends. What they are seeking to do is to deny this Parliament the raising of $2,200m in taxation from people who are not currently paying it just because they believe that it will enhance their prospects at the coming State election.

In today's debate the Australia Card has been mentioned on a number of occasions and comparisons have been drawn between this legislation and the Australia Card. I have said that in Western Australia at least people seem to think that there is some political advantage in opposing the tax file number, notwithstanding the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that he would be willing to reintroduce the legislation and even fight an election on it. Just to put into perspective the role played by the Liberal Party on the Australia Card issue, I refer to an article which appeared at page 9 of the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 October 1987. The article was written by Mr Simon Davies of the Australian Privacy Foundation and it sought to set out how his foundation led the charge against the Australia Card. In it he referred to the role played by the Liberals. He said:

The Liberals proved to be less than adequate campaign partners. Although Mr Howard had personally assured me the foundation could count on his party's co-operation all the way, when asked to help with the underwriting of $25,000 needed for campaign purposes, he refused, saying `the Liberals are in the business of promoting themselves, not other people'.

One can see there the motives behind the Liberal Party's involvement in the anti-ID push: self-promotion, without worrying about the principles and taking its share in the fight against the Australia Card that Simon Davies talked about. There is nothing in that article about the fact that the Liberals believed it was the right thing to do; it was self-promotion. Those are the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). The article goes on to state:
The Nationals were marginally more helpful. Senator Ron Boswell rang the foundation at the outset of the campaign seeking assistance for a private member's bill for a referendum on the card.
At least Senator Boswell tried to involve himself in a meaningful way in the fight against the Australia Card. The article continues:

But Senator Boswell was blocked by shadow cabinet and his bill was usurped by the Liberals. When my disappointment was conveyed to Wilson Tuckey, he responded, `Boswell will do what he's bloody well told or we'll toss him'.

There we have it. The fact is that when it comes to the part played by the Liberal Party in the anti-ID card push it really was a pimple on the backside. It really did come in after the whole movement got rolling and tried to attach to itself some recognition of the fact that it fought against the Australia Card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get back to the Bill.
—The honourable member asks me to get back to the Bill. I will.

—Order! The honourable member for Mayo, although not strictly in order, virtually pre-empted the intentions of the Chair. The Chair has been rather tolerant of the honourable member for Canning as he has been at the very best peripherally relevant. I would like him to address himself more seriously to the Bills.

—Certainly, Mr Deputy Speaker. The legislation before us today does not raise taxes. It cannot be claimed that in any way it inhibits the privacy of members of the public. The Government has gone out of its way to negotiate the privacy aspects of this legislation. Even the matters contained in the Bill have been discussed with a number of groups, including the Opposition, which have a deep interest in this area. We have consulted widely. We believe that by consulting with those groups, including the Opposition, the Bill is better for it. As I said before, I think the role of the Opposition in Canberra, as distinct from the Liberals in Western Australia, is to be commended. It shows that when a government and an opposition get together on a piece of legislation as important as this the legislation can go through the Parliament in a much more meaningful way than if we were to fight about it and start the old slanging matches which are usually a feature of debates on legislation before this House.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to refer to the role played by the Commissioner of Taxation. In addressing an audience in Brisbane he referred to the fact that the legislation before us today was essential. In his view, if tax is to be collected more efficiently a tax file number is necessary. I believe that the Commissioner of Taxation was expressing not only his true feelings but those of the Australian Taxation Office in saying that the tax file number would allow him to do his job more efficiently and to release staff to carry out functions such as company audits, which are labour intensive, rather than checking through records at random to see whether they can match up information supplied by taxpayers with information the Taxation Office received from other sources. I do not think the attack made on the Commissioner of Taxation by the Leader of the Opposition did the Leader of the Opposition any justice because the Commissioner of Taxation was really expressing a view that is widely held not only within the Taxation Office but throughout the wider community.

As a back bench member one can gauge reaction to a lot of legislation before the Parliament by the number of contacts one gets either by telephone or letter or by looking at the letters in the newspapers. Certainly from my experience there have been no objections to this legislation. No letters have been written to me about it. I have received no phone calls. I have seen the odd letter in the papers but we always get those. There will always be opposition to moves made in this House to increase efficiency within government departments. In the wider community there is a general acceptance of the Bill and the aims for it.

At the outset I said that this legislation continues this Government's proud record on taxation. Honourable members will remember that some of the things we have done in terms of fringe benefits, capital gains tax, substantiation and withholding tax have made the collection of taxation much more efficient. I believe that the Bills before us today go one step further. In due course they will allow taxation relief to be provided for those people who have always paid their tax and who have always been honest. For that reason, I commend the Bills to the House.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that so many members of the highest taxing Government have come into the House to hear my speech on this particular subject, which relates to imposing and collecting more taxation in what was once a great country.
—Queensland is all right.

—Queensland is not too bad, but under the present Labor Government we are looking at record taxation and record expenditure. We are also looking at record interest rates, record borrowings, and record balance of payments deficits-not credits, but deficits-which is very sad for us. Of course, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 and the Privacy Bill are quite involved pieces of legislation. With the computer age, I suppose we could argue that this means that we will have even more numbers placed on our backs.
—Forehead-up here.

—Well, forehead or feet-wherever you like to put a number, these days we seem to have numbers stamped on us. Of course, the intention of the legislation is to make it easier for the Australian Taxation Office to carry out its duties. I do not believe that the legislation will result in the collection of any more revenue, although the Taxation Office says that it will, but it tends to forget that people who are not paying tax either will stop working altogether, which is what they normally do, because under these arrangements--
—We should not do it then?

—That would be right. I would probably argue that. As an employer and someone trying to get Australia moving again, I would argue that the whole exercise is probably a damn waste of time. Those who knock around Australia know that some casual workers are paid a cash wage that they are not taxed on. As soon as this legislation is brought into force and the tax is taken out, the employer will not be prepared to pay the extra money involved in employing such people, and they are not going to get work. It is as simple as that. The dole in Australia is so high that it pays people not to work. The first thing I would do is abolish the dole. I think that is a disgrace, and it is one reason why--
—Is that your policy?

—That is true. This legislation has been introduced to try to pick up more taxation revenue from those people. It just will not work. The total tax take will not increase. All the Government will do is move one set of circumstances into another area. In actual fact, 99.9 per cent of employers use wage payments as a tax deduction because that is part of the cost of production. If producers are no longer paying out those wages, obviously they will not have that tax deduction and, therefore, their profits may go up or go down. In most cases those employers need the employment. If they are not able to employ such people, the production that is badly needed in this country does not eventuate and the balance of payments deficit, which is running at $1 billion a month, continues to stay down the mine. There is no sign of the J-curve. I have been a member of this House ever since the Treasurer (Mr Keating) came to office when he reckoned that there was a J-curve on the way.
—So have I.

—Brownie, where have you been? Did you have a win at the Melbourne Cup? I bet you lost every cent. I bet you do not pay a cent tax on your winnings either, you rascal. This legislation will catch up with you. If there is one person in this House this legislation will catch up with, it is the honourable member for Parramatta, with all his untaxed racing earnings. He will have--
—Order! The honourable member will come back to the Bills before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to inform the House that not only do we have some new taxation legislation before us today and have seen the Labor Government impose iniquitous capital taxes, but we are now seeing the assets testing of isolated children. Mr Deputy Speaker, you spent many years of your youth in Dirranbandi. You know what it is like to live in isolation. You understand that people living in inland Australia have to send their children to boarding school to get a proper education. However, what do we see the members of this Australian Labor Party doing? We see them now applying and extending the assets test to children who have to have an education, and they wonder why we on this side of the Parliament are screaming about this particularly iniquitous sort of taxation. Of course, they scream all the time for equity in the system. Of course, this taxation Bill is designed, so they say, to achieve a bit more equity into the system. Yet we saw a report in today's Australian of how the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is pouring buckets on the National Farmers Federation (NFF) for having the audacity to discuss the Government's tax proposals.
—Blackmail.

—It is absolute blackmail of the farmers of Australia. We have seen the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy threaten to delay the introduction of the income equalisation deposits (IED) scheme, which is at least a way of achieving more equity in the tax system. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, it is essential for primary producers to have some form of levelling effect in their taxable incomes because of the nature of primary industries. One year primary producers have a massive income and the next year they have none at all because of seasonal and market variations.

SPEECH.PARA: The IED scheme which was introduced by the Liberal-National Party Government in the Fraser days was withdrawn by this Labor Government. Of course, the Government has now seen the bad effect that that has had on rural producers. I see some members of the Government's rural task force sitting in the chamber. They have travelled around the place and no doubt many farmers have indicated to them the need to reintroduce the IED scheme under the tax regime of the Labor Government.

Yesterday we met with delegates of the NFF. When we met Wally Peart, a member of my electorate, the Chairman, John Allwright, and a number of other members of the NFF at lunchtime today, they expressed very strong views about the Government blackmailing them by threatening to extend the introduction of the IED system if they do not toe the line on the sorts of tax policies that the Government wants. I just say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to honourable members opposite: when the day comes that we cannot have a frank discussion about what sort of taxation system we should have, God help us all.

I think it is a very poor effort on the part of the Government when the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, of all people, is telling the farmers that they cannot have the reintroduction of an IED scheme unless they do such and such. Many farmers are desperately waiting to try to spread out their incomes. Not only have we not had the re-introduction of IEDs, but most primary producers also pay provisional tax. In a good year they must pay a massive amount of provisional tax. In actual fact, many primary producers get to the stage where they just do not have the funds to pay the provisional tax and they have to borrow money to do it.

I have mentioned that this Bill will not increase the overall gross domestic product (GDP) of the nation. Somehow or other-I do not know why-this Government continues to make it harder for people to do business. I spoke some time ago on the depreciation allowance legislation, the purpose of which was to rip $1 billion out of business in Australia, yet this Government wonders why we have a balance of payments problem. The Treasurer comes in here and bemoans that situation and wonders why we are seeing record investment overseas by Australian corporations. The only reason they are investing overseas is that they are paying too much tax in Australia. They can see that it is not beneficial for their stockholders for them to continue to invest in this country. What do we see? We see an outcry from people about overseas investors coming to Australia. If this Government put a decent tax regime in place and made it more interesting and easier for business to get on with the job of creating employment and increasing production, we would not see the disastrous balance of payments figures. We would not see companies such as the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Elders-IXL seeking to invest vast sums of money worldwide and not wishing to re-invest their funds in Australia-where they should be. There is no incentive in the tax system for them to do that.

Until the Labor Party is heaved out of office and the coalition is returned to government, at which time we can reintroduce some decent tax incentives into the system, we will see the Taxation Office continuing to try to find ways of raising more revenue, because it is not getting it through an increase in the size of the cake. The GDP is not growing at the sort of rate it should be. As a result, the Taxation Office will continue to scrape around to get $200m or $300m here, or $200m or $300m there, through all sorts of new tax legislation-pages and pages of it.

This time around we have a tax file number. We have always had one, of course. All taxpayers have had a tax file number since the 1930s. Everybody who is paying tax today has a number. All that will happen is that the Taxation Office will extend the use of that number. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) has done a fantastic job in convincing the government on the Privacy Bill, which accompanies the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill. They will come into effect at the same time. After many weeks of negotiation and after longwinded discussions in our Party room we decided to support this legislation- under great pressure, I can assure honourable members. It took me a long while before I was prepared to support it. I am here today speaking in support of the amendments that we have put forward.

The honourable member for Menzies has done a fantastic job in seeing that some of the inequities that the Labor Government had written into the legislation have been withdrawn. The fact is that it is not compulsory for an employee to present his tax file number. I wonder about that fact, but that is the way it is. As usual, all the compulsion is back on the employer, as in the case of the fringe benefits tax. I thought that under our system of employment it was the responsibility of the wage earner to declare and pay his own taxation. The Tax Office and the Treasury have developed this creeping extension of forcing the employer to do all the tax collecting for them. In other words, each and every employer in this country-that includes every farmer and me-is now an arm of the Taxation Office. We are just tax agents now. We are out there doing the work for all the employees whom we may employ from time to time. It is not compulsory for them to declare their number to the employer, but if they do not it is compulsory for the employer to tax them at the current top rate of 49c in the dollar, plus the Medicare levy, which at present is 1 1/2 per cent. Who knows what it might be after the next May statement or the next Budget. The costs of running this so-called free hospitalisation or free medicine scheme that we have continue to skyrocket and, no doubt, the Medicare levy will increase.

I spoke to members of the Taxation Office this morning. Apparently all group certificates will have to have a tax file number on them. This will make it easier for the Tax Office with its massive computer system, its $700m worth of computers, to track one cash transaction across to another. Perhaps honourable members could argue that that is a good thing. I do not think that those people who have a tax number have anything to fear. The legislation is being tightened to force us to take the tax from people whom we employ. As I said earlier, unfortunately all that will do is drive people on to the unemployment queues. It is also compulsory for people receiving unemployment benefit to declare a tax file number. I think that is good. I cannot for the life of me understand why pensioners, unmarried mothers, and all sorts of other people receiving pensions should be exempt from this system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to stop them getting pensions too?

—Can you explain what will happen when we turn 60 and retire? We have a number, but will we have it scraped off the record? Is that your intention? I hope it is. We all have a tax file number. Once I become a lone parent, for instance, and start picking up a pension, will you wipe my tax file number? Are you prepared to do that?
—Order! The honourable member will address the Chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am asking the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table, whether she is prepared to do that. There are a few questions I would like to ask under this legislation, and that is one of them. It seems to me that there is no provision in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill to have our tax file numbers wiped once we become pensioners. Of course, 30 per cent of the Australian population are already pensioners. God knows what we will end up with if this crew stay in office for another 10 years. We will end up with half the population receiving one sort of pension or another. This Bill exempts those people. It also exempts most children, not all children. Children earning a wage over $94 a week or whose bank accounts earn interest over $420 per annum will have to have a tax file number. I ask the Minister: What happens in the case of a family trust? Do the children of that trust have to have a separate tax file number if they open their own bank account? I notice that the scribes in the officials area are busily writing things down. I hope that they put a few of these questions back to the Minister at the table. The Minister shakes her head and laughs. She will have a chance to answer some of these questions I put to her. I hope that she has some pretty smart answers because I do not think she will be able to answer them, if the truth be known.
—Order! The honourable member will come back to the Bill before the House.

—The Government makes one set of laws-I have here a book of explanatory notes of about 100 pages-and all it does is open up a whole lot of other ramifications and ifs and buts about what it might do with the legislation. I would also like to ask another question about stocks and shares. Today the Taxation Office is able to trace the owners of stocks and shares through companies that are registered. I just wonder why it is that we have to put our tax file numbers on these things. I know that we will have to use our tax file number for investments, interest from banks, building societies and credit unions. We will also have to use our tax file number for investments from government and semi-government organisations, companies and solicitors' trusts. Again, pensioners are exempt, for some strange reason, from declaring that they have anything to do with these companies. I find that rather strange, but that is the way the legislation is drafted.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I would also like to point out to the House, having spoken to the Tax Office this morning, that I think it is going to be very difficult for people, particularly those who live in rural Australia, to find sufficient people to employ once this legislation becomes law. I point this out to the people who do not know that.

There seems to be different dates involved as to when operation of the scheme will start. From November 1988 those starting a new job or changing jobs will need to quote their file number on an employment declaration to their employer, while file numbers will be quoted for all new accounts opened or investments made on or after 1 July 1991. There seems to be a whole range of start off dates. I put it to the Minister at the table that we should have a standard start off date for the introduction of all these new regulations that are being imposed upon the taxpayer once this Bill becomes law.

I have much pleasure in supporting the amendments that have been put forward by the Opposition. I remind the House that it is a far different story from what was in the legislation a few weeks ago. Although a lot of people do not support the extension of the tax file number, I think that the people of Australia ought to be thankful that they do have a good Opposition in Canberra, that we have been prepared to stick it to the Government in the last 10 days and that we have a whole lot better legislation than we would have had if we had sat back and done nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill and the Privacy Bill. I do so with some satisfaction. Before I actually talk in terms of the contents of the tax file number, I would just like to comment on a couple of issues that have been raised by members of the Opposition. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), raised some of the issues relating to the disquiet and perhaps the division in the Opposition over this question. Certainly members of the Opposition have attempted to put forward that in some miraculous way they have turned legislation which was inherently bad into something that was good and that what brought about their support for the tax file number was the fact that they have taken care of the privacy issues. One has only to read the Australian to find out that it is really not as simple as that. In fact, we find that there was a grudging acceptance by the Opposition and that there was a sullen sense of inevitability in the Opposition. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Support of the Bill flowed from the political difficulties of opposing the legislation once the Government had made substantial amendments, and concern that the Opposition could be portrayed as a ``friend of the tax cheats'' if it did not support the measure.
It goes on to say:
. . . Howard's stand on the position left the leadership ``with its neck sticking out'' and the party room had little choice but to protect the leadership.

We then turn over to read the back part and see what the rest of the Liberal Party thought about it. We find that there was a bit of a backlash once the party structure out in the sticks found out about it. I quote:
The national president of the Young Liberals, Mr Cam Tinley, said the ``grassroots . . . are fed up with members masquerading as Liberals . . .

It seems that he does not have any qualms about being called a friend of the tax cheats. He will be urging all the Young Liberals around the country to use their preselection votes to dump those who support the Bill. We should get away from this notion that in some way the Opposition has become an opponent of the tax cheats. We have to remember that during the Opposition's seven years of government under Malcolm Fraser, with the present Leader of the Opposition as Treasurer, the only growth industry was tax avoidance. Unemployment was growing, industry was being destroyed and for seven years the coalition Government, under Malcolm Fraser, sat around and allowed the tax cheats to make millions and millions of dollars at the expense of the community. The general community, the average pay as you earn taxpayers and honest taxpayers in other tax groups, were absolutely fed up with the way that the opportunist Opposition, when in government, allowed the tax cheats to thrive and to grow and to make millions of dollars at the taxpayers' expense.

Honourable members opposite are now forced to accept the legislation simply because they know that if they try to go out into the community and say, `Hey, we knocked off the tax file number-support us' the vast majority of people will say, `We're not going to support you. We're absolutely fed up with you supporting tax cheats'. That is why the Opposition supports the Bill. Sure, it has had some amendments accepted. I will not discredit all of its amendments to the Privacy Bill but some of them have made the tax file number system less efficient than it might have been. I still think that the Government has done the right thing in agreeing with the Opposition so that we can at least have a system which will continue the crackdown that we have been carrying out on tax cheats.

Nearly three years ago the Parliament set up a joint select committee to have a look at the then proposed Australia Card. I was a member of that committee. We carried out an extensive public inquiry throughout Australia. One of the satisfying things about this debate today is that we are now looking at the introduction of a tax file system, which was the recommendation of the majority report of that committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a tax file system.

—As the honourable member knows, that tax file number was a recommendation. A proposal on how it could be introduced was the basis of the majority report. There was certainly some concern in the community and in the Parliament about the Australia Card proposal. Ultimately, those concerns were proven to be of such magnitude that it was correct that the Australia Card not proceed. In fact, that was the majority view of the report at that time. Nevertheless, all the members of that committee from all of the parties agreed that tax avoidance was an ongoing problem, that there were clear deficiencies in the existing tax system, and that it was basically difficult, if not impossible, for the Australian Taxation Office to operate efficiently without some improved means of matching information.

SPEECH.PARA: An argument put forward by the Opposition was that tax avoidance was something new; that it had grown because all of a sudden there was tax creep in the tax system. We know that that is absolute nonsense because, if we look at some of the figures made available by the Tax Office during that inquiry, we see that even in 1986 tax evasion in Australia was running at about $6 billion to $7 billion a year. It was a problem not unique to Australia but one of varying magnitude throughout the developed countries. The major difficulty that the Tax Office had was not necessarily obtaining information but being able to match that information to material which would enable it to properly apply income to the individuals that earned that income.

A study was recently done by the Tax Office in, I think, the Sydney area. It concentrated on employment in the hospitality industry and the cleaning industry. Group certificates that had been issued were looked at. It was found that 25 per cent of the group certificates issued to people in some hotels had fictitious names or addresses. In one hotel, the percentage of incorrect group certificates was as high as 68 per cent. Clearly, in some of those instances there was collusion between the employer and the employee in a deliberate attempt to avoid paying tax and probably to avoid applying proper award conditions. In other instances, the employer had done his or her best to obtain the information but had not been able to satisfy the Tax Office.

The use of tax file numbers in this area and in the area of banking will close down the avenues for opportunities to avoid tax. It will not totally eliminate tax avoidance but it will make it much more difficult for people to operate if they do not have a tax file number. That is the key to this process. No-one is suggesting that an improved tax file number and a system which requires a person, in certain circumstances, to provide that number is a perfect system which will eliminate tax avoidance and cut out the so-called black economy but there is no doubt that, coupled with other legal mechanisms, it will begin to close the net and make it much more difficult for people to operate outside the legal system.

A good example of how that can work was the use of the withholding system in the building and related industries. The Opposition, when in government, introduced the legislation but never enacted it. When it was finally enacted under our Government, it was found to be effective. It brought into the tax system people who had been able to operate in a cash economy environment without paying tax. When that system was applied, they could no longer operate effectively without paying some form of punitive withholding tax. Effectively, they had a choice of either getting out of the industry or becoming legal. Thousands of them in fact came back into the tax system. To a great degree, the industry has been somewhat cleaned up. The use of the tax file number will assist that.

I think the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), made the point that there were a number of matters that honourable members opposite had to acquaint themselves with before they would support the Bill, one being whether there was a cost benefit in the tax file system. Obviously, he has not bothered to read the original report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card; otherwise he would have known that the cost benefits were clearly stated there. It did not matter that he was one of those who, in their opposition to the Australia Card, kept quoting the report and saying that the tax file number was the way to go and that that was the majority view. Clearly he had not bothered to read the report, because if he had he would have found quite concise information put forward by the Taxation Office following, I might say, a request from me and the Committee to provide some information on the basis of an enhanced tax file number being used as a means of improving the tax collection system. In running through that information, the Tax Office laid out how it would be able to raise money and what it would cost. Clearly the cost was significantly less than the amount of money that could be raised. At that time the Taxation Office would have expected to raise some $290m a year for a much smaller introduction cost.

The other important thing about the tax file system was that it could be introduced in a much quicker way than any other form of identity system. So it had two things going for it: first, that it could be introduced quickly and, secondly, that it would concentrate specifically on the issue of tax avoidance.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a tax file system now.

—The honourable member for Maranoa says that we already have a system, and that is correct. But obviously he has not read the report either, because if he had he would find in it a quite detailed examination of the difficulties that exist with the current system. The Taxation Office indicated that it had no security measures in issuing the current tax file numbers and that in some instances there was no cross-referencing of individuals who may have available to them a number of tax file numbers for different purposes. Thus, there was no way to measure the full income that might be available to individuals. The honourable member would not have raised that point if he had bothered to read the report, which was issued some two years ago. He has certainly had time to read it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is good to see that the Opposition is supporting the Bill, even if it is reluctant to do so. I think all Australians will be much happier when this system is introduced, not just because they will immediately see a tangible benefit, but because they will have some greater comfort in knowing that those who are not prepared voluntarily to pay their fair share in the burdens of running this country will at least be brought to task.

The only other thing I would like to say is that I find some disquiet in the way that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) took the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, to task and made an implied threat about the continuation of his job. It is a great pity that the Opposition should take some exception to the fact that a public servant has been very vocal in his support for an improved taxation system. The fact is that Mr Boucher has openly argued for a more effective system and he has called for help from the legislators to give him a more effective system. That has resulted in the Opposition saying, `You appeared to be supporting a system which we did not necessarily want to support. We do not think that was right and therefore we cannot guarantee your continued employment if we come to office'. I think that is a great tragedy.

I would have thought that the Opposition, like the Government, would have been concerned about efficiency and effectiveness in government. I think it is a great pity that when a high ranking public servant is prepared to stand up and say, `The system I have to operate with has deficiencies and the only people who can fix them are the legislators; I need your support to help give me a better system so that the whole of the Australian community can benefit from it', the Opposition then says, `We do not like your saying that because it does not suit us at this time. Therefore we cannot guarantee your ongoing employment'. That does nothing for a more efficient and dynamic public service. It simply means that we will find a more compliant public service sitting back and saying nothing, giving no advice and not letting the community know what it believes is wrong or good with the system and then leaving it simply to the Government to sort out.

I think this matter clearly shows that sometimes the legislators, whether they be on our side of politics or on the Opposition's side, do not necessarily have the right answers. We ought to encourage public servants, particularly senior public servants, to let us know whether they agree or disagree with options that are put forward by us, rather than threaten them and say that their jobs may be done away with if there is a change of government. This should be more openly encouraged, in my view, rather than discouraged.

I support the Bill. I believe that the view of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card has been vindicated by the introduction of this system. I hope that we will see the speedy passage of the Bill to allow the timetable that has been planned by the Government to be implemented as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills before the House, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill and the Privacy Bill, are, as is known, supported by the Opposition. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), have set out the reasons why we support those Bills, although of course it is known that in the process of coming to support those Bills we examined them very carefully because we were deeply concerned about some of the things they did in their original form.

SPEECH.PARA: We support the Bills basically because we believe everyone should pay his fair share of tax and at the same time privacy should be respected.
