These two considerations are not necessarily considerations that match easily together, because when we say that people should pay their fair share of tax, we then have to ask: What are the measures that should be adopted in a civilised society that believes in the rule of law, to make sure that people do pay their fair share of tax? How do those considerations match up to our concerns about the protection of privacy and civil liberties? I can give you a guarantee, Mr Deputy Speaker, that all tax owed by citizens in this country could be collected. We could pass laws that would make that a guaranteed outcome, but this country would then not be a place that any of us would want to live in. The truth of the matter is that we have to put up with some abuses of systems, whether they be the social security, tax or other government provided systems, as part of the cost of living in a tolerable and decent democracy.

As I and other speakers have said, the Opposition supports the legislation. I wish to say something about the legislation and the reason why we support it, and I also wish to say something about two other issues: first of all, the great burden of tax that has been imposed on this country by this Government; and, secondly, the astounding incompetence of this Government, as demonstrated by the way in which it went about framing the legislation now before the House. And this, we recall, is the Government which was praised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as he looked at the somewhat bedraggled objects sitting on his front bench, as the best, the brightest and most luminous that the country has ever seen.

Let me go first of all to the tax file numbers Bill. At Question Time today we had from the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-he must have been at a bad moment; he must have been in a fugue-an admission that, as a result of discussion that had taken place between the Government and the Opposition, in the tax file numbers Bill `probably we have produced a better Bill'. Let me just turn that around and put it explicitly. What the Treasurer was saying is that the Opposition has improved his legislation. There is no doubt about that; and the shadow Treasurer has outlined the reasons for that and how it came about.

Let me address very briefly the way in which the tax file numbers Bill works. It sets up a procedure which enables the matching of tax file numbers against situations where income should be declared. Let us just run through those situations. It deals with the non-declaration of income from interest bearing investments in banks, building societies, credit unions, government and semi-government bodies, companies, solicitors' trust accounts and unit trusts. It deals with the non-declaration of dividend income and with non-declaration of employment situations. The way in which the Bill will operate when it is an Act of Parliament is such that, effectively, one will have a choice: one will be able not to declare one's tax file number and then wear a heavy penalty, or one will be able to declare the tax file number and then open the relevant financial affairs to the Commissioner of Taxation. Under the system which we have, aided these days by computers-which have quite transformed the business of tax gathering along with the business world itself-there will be a far greater ease of matching sources of income for taxpayers because the tax file number will be the matching code in each case.

We support the legislation because we believe it will bring about benefits and we believe that the amendments which we have forced the Government to accept as the price of our support of the legislation will protect the privacy rights of individuals.

I move on to say something about the Treasurer's second reading speech. This gets down to the issue of the burden of income tax in this country. When one sees what the Treasurer said one is reminded that this Government, when it comes to humbug, propaganda, hypocrisy and straightforward misrepresentation, has few peers in contemporary democratic history. The Treasurer, in his second reading speech, said:
Today people much more readily comply, simply because lower rates make compliance less of a burden.
If one knew nothing about the realities of the world, one would believe that the tax burden in this country had in fact been reduced under this Government and that this was a low taxation government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is by OECD standards.

—The Minister at the table is saying that it is low by Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) standards, but what he does not say is whether it is low by historical Australian standards. The short answer is that it is not.
—More people are working and there is less unemployment.

—Here we have a mindless interjection from one whose mind is always in neutral. He says that more people are working. I say to my friend that that has nothing to do with it at all. Since the Minister at the table has raised the matter of the OECD, I go first of all to what that organisation said in its most recent economic survey of Australia. This gives one some idea how the taxation burden in this country has historically increased. Later I will give a few figures which show precisely what has taken place under this Government. What did the OECD say? On page 59, addressing the question of the vertical equity of the new system, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: First, progressivity of the tax scale just before reform was very different from the situation two decades before. While only one per cent of taxpayers faced a marginal rate of 46 per cent or more in fiscal year 1954-55, the proportion had risen to almost 40 per cent in fiscal year 1983-84.
That is an increase from one per cent to 40 per cent over that 20-year period. It continued:
A top marginal rate of 66.7 per cent in fiscal year 1954-55 began at 18 times earnings, while a top marginal rate of 60 per cent in fiscal year 1983-84 cut in at 1.6 times average earnings.
The report went on to say:

Second, the increased tax burden before the introduction of the new system had led to greater incentives to avoid tax at higher incomes, thereby reducing the effective progressivity of the tax system.

Of course, it needs to be recalled that all the major general anti-avoidance measures were introduced in the time of the Fraser Government. That report points to the increasing burden on taxpayers and the greater number of taxpayers who are now paying tax at the highest marginal rates. I remind honourable members again that in fiscal year 1954-55 only one per cent of taxpayers faced a marginal rate of 46 per cent or more, whereas the proportion had risen to almost 40 per cent in fiscal year 1983-84.

What do the figures tell us? I have some figures: selected indicators for 1981-82 and for 1986-87. The sources of these figures are the taxation statistics of the Commissioner of Taxation for 1981-82 and income tax statistics from the Budget Papers for 1986-87. These figures show us that in 1981-82, the last full year of the Fraser Government, 285,396 taxpayers earned more than $28,000 a year taxable income and paid tax at the rate of 46c in the dollar or more, that is, they had entered those brackets. Some 285,000-odd were on the 46c or more marginal tax rate. One would think that the figure would be less. After all, this Government constantly tells the world that its tax collections are less and that it is effectively a low taxing government. In 1986-87, the number of taxpayers with a taxable income of over $28,000 and who were on a marginal rate of 44.25 per cent-remember the earlier figure of 46 per cent; this one is about the same at 44.25-had increased from the 285,396 figure to 1,290,867. That is an increase from 285,000 in round terms to 1,290,000 in round terms. That is one of the great achievements of this Government!

Is it any wonder that people out there in the community-which is never visited by the Treasurer or by the Prime Minister-are hurting because they are paying more tax? They have less disposable income; they are less well off; and, incidentally, they are paying for motor cars anywhere up to 100 per cent more than they were at the time when this Government came to power. It takes them far longer today to finance the purchase of a motor car out of their earnings than it did when this Government came into power. They are now facing mortgage rates and costs of housing which are far greater than comparable rates at the time that this Government came into office.

Let me just refer the House to some other sets of figures which, again, are very revealing. According to a table headed `Income tax and average earnings: 1966-67 to 1987-88', in 1982-83 a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children paid 14.1 per cent of his total earnings in tax. What was the estimate for 1987-88 under this brilliant Government with this brilliant Treasurer, this brilliant Prime Minister, and this brilliant front bench? We have seen some exhibitions of the brilliance of this front bench in the last few weeks. The figure is 18.1 per cent. The proportion of total earnings paid in tax by such a taxpayer has gone up from 14.1 per cent in 1982-83 to 18.1 per cent in 1987-88. The marginal rate on the last dollar earned for the same taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children was 30.67 per cent in 1982-83 and 41.2 per cent in 1987-88. Effectively this Government has made that taxpayer pay around 25 per cent more of his disposable income in tax than he had been paying in 1982-83.

Let me say something about the privacy legislation itself. That legislation is a tribute not to this Government but to the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies. The Privacy Bill is made tolerable as a result of the amendments put by the shadow Attorney-General and accepted by this Government. The legislation in its original form would have been unsupportable. It was shoddy and slipshod with gaping holes in it and did not even contain an obligation on the part of the Privacy Commissioner to hand down privacy guidelines.

Let me run through the achievements of the shadow Attorney-General, since I think they should be put on the record. First of all, the Bill in its original form provided that the Privacy Commissioner may issue guidelines on the collection, storage, use and security of tax file number information. The legislation said `may' not `shall'. We did not believe that that was right. Indeed, the Government does not believe it was right because it accepted the amendment. We recommended that `may' should be changed to `shall', and that was accepted, which means, of course, that the Privacy Commissioner will have an obligation to issue guidelines.

Next, there were no actual guidelines or rules set down in the Bill for the tax file number. The Opposition took the view that the Bill must set out in actual terms the rules that the Government believed were adequate for keeping privacy over the tax file number. This view and our schedule have been accepted. Can one imagine this Government coming to the people and saying, `Look, we are going to have guidelines or rules but we are not going to tell you what they are; we are going to tell you some time in the future, but not now' and asking us to pass that kind of legislation? What collection of ministerial dopes put this together?

Let me deal with the exemption of information from privacy principles on the ground of public interest. The original Bill allowed agencies to apply to the Privacy Commissioner for an exemption from following the principles on the ground of public interest. The only supervision of this process was an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This was entirely unsatisfactory and, in effect, gave a Federal agency the scope to ignore privacy principles enacted by the Parliament. The Opposition said that if the Privacy Commissioner made such an exemption it should be disallowable by the Parliament, which was accepted.

No complaints against interference in privacy could be made for the first six months of the operation of the Privacy Bill. We thought that was wrong. We put up an amendment which was accepted. We believe that the way in which powers to enter premises were drafted was inadequate and wrong. Again, the shadow Attorney-General put up amendments which were accepted. We thought that the duty of the Privacy Commissioner to report to the Parliament was too narrow and that he should report to Parliament on at least some of his major activities. Effectively, what we said about that was adopted. The other amendments were covered by the shadow Attorney-General in his speech at the second reading stage.

I want to make one last point. A lot was said by previous speakers about the Commissioner of Taxation. The Commissioner has wide powers. Let us understand that great powers of the kind that he has have to be exercised with wisdom and restraint. The proposal put forward by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is designed to secure just that. Anybody who has anything to do with the world knows that powers under the Income Tax Assessment Act have been abused. Powers of that width can easily be abused. There must always be a balance between, on the one hand, the collection of revenue and, on the other hand, the fair treatment of citizens. And that is what we are determined to secure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tax file number legislation which is before us today is, of course, being supported by the Opposition. But, if one reads today's newspapers, it is very clear that it is reluctant support. Indeed, a front page article in today's Australian headed `Howard tax file backers reluctant' states:

SPEECH.PARA: A grudging acceptance of the need to back Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, forced a Coalition party room meeting in Canberra yesterday to support the Federal Government's proposed upgraded tax file number and privacy legislation.
The article goes on to talk about the dissatisfaction that exists on the other side of the House. Clearly there is great division among honourable members opposite. Further on, the article states:
West Australian members of the joint party room were particularly strident in their opposition to the upgraded tax file number, reflecting strong sentiment in that State about the issue.
The article goes even further and we read:
The national president of the Young Liberals, Mr Cam Tinley-
who was a Senate candidate in the last election-
said the `grassroots of the party are fed up with members masquerading as Liberals at their preselections and then supporting left-wing policy in the safety of the party room'.
`I will be urging Young Liberals around the country to use their preselection votes to dump those who supported the Bill,' he said.

Of course, there is widespread dissension and great concern in the Opposition about this legislation. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) suggested in his contribution that the Opposition has excised the obligation for taxpayers to be required to quote their number. He saw this as a great achievement. If taxpayers listening to this debate wonder what has been achieved for them by the honourable member for Kooyong, I can tell them. They will be able to do something that was not an offence under the legislation. As a result of the Opposition's productive efforts, the obligation no longer exists-not that it existed in the original legislation-for a taxpayer to disclose his tax file number. For that privilege, any interest or money he may receive will be taxed at a rate of 49c in the dollar, plus the Medicare levy. I think a substantial victory has been achieved for those people who will be wondering what has been done for them!

The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) continued to talk about what a big taxing government this Government was and how in fact this legislation would add to the tax burden-a rather spurious argument, I am sure all would agree. Of course, any government is going to be the biggest taxing government this year, just as next year's government, of whatever complexion it is, will be the biggest taxing government then. That argument is very facile. It amazes me as I sit in this place year after year to hear it used again and again.

This legislation provides for the use of the tax file number to identify taxpayers and, as such, will provide an increased integrity for the system. It will mean greater efficiency for the collection of taxation so that every taxpayer in the country can understand that the system has integrity and that everybody is paying his fair share. The specifics of the Bill are supported. Indeed, honourable members on the other side have been saying in this debate that it is fair that every taxpayer should pay his fair share. Their concern is about the intrusive nature of the tax file number system and what it might mean. How intrusive is this? I have no objection to my tax file number being known. Indeed, for the information of anybody who is listening, it is 621 826 602. Perhaps I should now fear that, that information having been disclosed, I will be subject to all sorts of unusual and bizarre scrutiny. Of course, I do not think that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just lost your privacy.

—I may have lost my privacy, as the Minister suggested, but I certainly do not believe that that is the case. If we are to talk about civil liberties and individual liberties, the argument which has been most strongly projected by members of the Opposition, it amazes me that two hours ago in this place they were arguing that in camera evidence produced for a standing committee of the Parliament should be released to the public. One minute they are debating whether the privacy legislation is strong enough and the next minute they are saying that in camera evidence given by witnesses to a committee should be released. I find it unbelievable.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who talk about civil liberties and individual liberties often quote the philosopher John Stuart Mill. More than a century ago he found it impossible to defend the notion of individual liberty. He suggested that, except for the right to private thought-I think that is without question-there is no civil liberty. As soon as a private thought is expressed, it acquires the potential to injure others and therefore may be unacceptable in an ethical sense. The conclusion that he came to was that government intervention is often justified, that just as often as it is justified it is improperly evoked and that sometimes it is improperly condemned. I think that is a very valid conclusion. The sorts of decisions that we in this place are making all the time relate to individual liberties. Legislators throughout this country are making decisions as to the public good and whether the public good is advanced by those decisions and whether individual rights and liberties are interfered with. All sorts of legislation is passed in this place and others in respect of those issues.

In Victoria, legislation that said people had to wear seat belts was at the cutting edge of road safety legislation in the world. That legislation relates to how one should use one's seat belt when sitting in a car. Education programs have been shown to have an effect on people's wearing seat belts, but nothing has been more effective than that legislation and its enforcement. It is very often inconvenient for people, but we pass and accept legislation which infringes our individual rights as we drive along. Yet we hear bleatings and concerns in places such as this that we should not have similar considerations in the area of taxation.

We pass legislation which says that people coming into Australia through Customs can be searched. While such legislation is inconvenient and some of us may disagree with the way it is enacted, we accept the intrusion as a cost of living in our society and for the protection that is provided by such a search. I doubt very much that the giving away of one's tax file number is a mammoth intrusion. If it means that all those people who are paying their fair share will pay less-and clearly the sums would illustrate that large sums of taxation revenue are avoided by people who are engaged in tax avoidance practices-there is a benefit for them in this legislation. Certainly, there will be a plus in the future.

We have discussed privacy legislation in this debate. A very meaningful and measured contribution was made by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), who, it is acknowledged, has been responsible for some significant improvements in that legislation. It is important to understand that there is a great deal more to be done in the area of privacy. None of the measures in this Bill touches upon the private sector. I dare say that most members of this House and the vast majority of the people of Australia have a credit card which they use for identification and financial purposes. When they obtained that credit card a great deal of information would have been provided by them over which we have no control and over which they have no control and in relation to which there is perhaps a necessity for a greater enforcement of privacy legislation in this country.

The provisions of this Bill involve general government information and the tax file number. A number of guidelines are laid down relating to complaints, investigations, conclusions and the storage, collection and recording of information about the tax file number and general government information. I think that within that legislation we have the embryo form of substantial privacy legislation which may in the future go a great deal further. While we accept the right to privacy, we in this place have continually to balance the right to privacy against considerations which are important for the social goodwill and for the fair and equitable collection of taxation. Indeed, that is what this measure is about.

The honourable member for Kooyong gave us the normal story. We have heard it all before. He says, `We do not have a substantial policy with respect to economic management; we plan to spend less but we are not going to tell you where we will cut expenditure; we want to loosen monetary policy and we will drop interest rates as a result; we will give you big tax cuts but we do not want you to spend the money because demand is a bit too strong, so you'll have to save more; and we are going to fight inflation as well. We do not have an incomes policy but we know that incomes should be increased. However, every time a case comes before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission we will oppose any wage rise'. Unfortunately, all of those things do not mix.

It is only this Government that has put some credibility into taxation policy. It is this Government that lowered the rates. In spite of what the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) said, we would still be left with a rate of 60c in the dollar if the coalition were in government. In spite of what the honourable member said, it is harsher penalties and lower rates that have improved compliance with taxation laws. This Government has closed many of the loopholes. One has only to look at the capital gains tax, which equates capital gains income with employment income. We have only to look at the fringe benefits tax and the entertainment tax introduced by this Government, which have improved the progressiveness and the equity of taxation measures. For two or three years in the old building we listened time and time again to the former member for Denison saying that the restaurant industry would collapse if we introduced an entertainment tax, yet year after year we see increasing employment and increasing efficiency in that area.

In the corporate sector, by lowering the tax rates, by having tougher enforcement and fewer concessions and by moving the double taxation on dividends, income and genuine profits are encouraged, which was not the case under the previous system. I wish to quote from a magazine which is not, I might say, a purveyor of socialist philosophy by any stretch of the imagination-that is, Australian Business. In the 2 November edition John Gilmour, under the heading `It pains one to praise the World's Best Treasurer too much, but credit where credit is due', wrote:
Successive governments-particularly those tired Tories who postured as supporters of free enterprise-created a tax monster that penalised profit but encouraged speculation.
Further, he said:
It pains this page-
he was talking about his column-
to give too much credit to the World's Best Treasurer.
He said that with tongue in cheek. We all understand that. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, understands it. He continued:
But the Keating taxation reforms have won . . .

They have eliminated double taxation on company dividends, enabling small companies to plough profits back into their enterprises without penalty. They have ended the preference for speculation by placing capital profits on a similar footing to trading gains. They have indicated a sympathy for business by providing companies with the best tax rate available. They have created a climate for enterprise.

This Government is about economic growth and enterprise. We have encouraged income and discouraged speculation. If one looks at fiscal policy and asks the Opposition what it intends to do, one finds that in the last Budget total outlays increased by 4.1 per cent in nominal terms. That represents a fall of some 2 per cent. If one adds that to the figures for the previous years-1986-87 and 1987-88-one finds a fall in outlays of 5 per cent over those three years. It is the first time in 30 years that we have had three years of outlay falls. Indeed, outlay expenditure is now down to the sort of percentage level that we saw in the early 1970s. There has been a significant decrease in outlays and a significant contribution to fiscal policy by this Government. However, when we ask the Opposition what it would do we find that it would do nothing.

When we talk about wages policy time and time again the Opposition says, `We believe we should oppose wage increases'; yet in the same breath it bleats about the fact that net disposable income of some workers has fallen. In an ideal world I am sure that we could produce the panacea that we seek, but when it comes to handling the levers and making the decisions, this Government has had to grapple with those questions. This tax legislation is a further step on the way to making the tax system equitable. It is necessary for us to do so. One has only to look at the results of the recent tax amnesty to see that a large number of people are not complying with the law as it is. The amnesty was determined after census statistics were compared with groups lodging tax returns. It was estimated that some 360,000 taxpayers had not, for various reasons, declared their income in past years. As the amnesty draws to a close, we find that some 290,000 new tax files have been found. Many of those taxpayers will receive refunds, but a large percentage of them have outstanding taxation debts. That will be a further source of income for the Australian Taxation Office and a further source of equity for those people in the community who have, over a long period, been paying their fair share. It is just a further example of the fact that we must be ever vigilant in the area of taxation. Yet at the same time the Opposition denigrates and criticises the Australian Commissioner of Taxation who, as a public servant, is doing his job, following the law, trying to be vigilant and trying to determine and collect a fair share of the taxation revenue. I find the Opposition's action the utmost in hypocrisy.

The tax file number system is not something new. It has been with us for 52 years. The enforcement of the tax file system-the strengthening of the tax file system-which will be the outcome of the passing of this legislation and the privacy legislation that goes with it, is something that is well overdue. It will mean that ordinary taxpayers will pay their fair share and will receive their fair benefits. It will increase compliance. One has only to look at the figures which have been produced in a table which is before me, which suggest that in some countries the hidden economy amounts to as much as 50 per cent, to know that there is a great need for increasing the compliance with and the integrity of the taxation system. This legislation has my utmost support. I am sure that once it becomes law we will see an even greater integrity in the system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The members of the Australian Labor Party who are speaking today in favour of the tax file number are those who were most fervently in favour of the Australia Card. Those people are using the speeches that were used on the occasion of the introduction of the Australia Card and are claiming the same things for the Government's proposals to collect more taxation. The Australian community and the Opposition rejected the Australia Card proposal. At that time we said that we would support a discrete proposal within the taxation system which protected privacy. Today we have before us the Government's proposals that meet, broadly, the Opposition's principles. I must say that they were amended substantially by the Opposition. It is only through the activity of the Opposition regarding the tax file numbering system that we are to pass legislation which, to a fair degree, reflects the principles laid down by the Opposition at the time the Australia Card was introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members put the proposition forcefully to the Australian community that the Australia Card was the only system whereby we could have a safe taxation collection process. The Australian people rejected that strongly. The Australia Card Bill was rejected because it did not have adequate safeguards for privacy. It was opposed not only by the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card which examined the proposals but also by many supporters of the Australian Labor Party. In addition, a large number of non-partisan groups emerged in the community to fight the legislation. Former Senator Ryan and the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) finally conceded that there could be concerns with fraudulent use of the card. This is this brilliant Government's second best effort. Even so, these brilliant proposals have had to be heavily amended and then accepted by the Government. The privacy provisions were grossly inadequate. Those guys in Caucus accepted a proposal to allow the taxation system, under the tax file number, to rip for six months before there were any privacy provisions or any protection whatsoever. They accepted and agreed to that. The protections for the Australian community were grossly inadequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —If not non-existent.

—As my colleague says, if not non-existent. Not only were the provisions of introduction inadequate but also the guidelines that were necessary for the person who was supposed to protect the privacy of the Australian community were also non-existent. They were not even proposed to be tabled at the time of the introduction of the legislation. I pay tribute to the shadow Attorney-General-the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N. A. Brown)-for his careful enthusiasm in pursuing this matter and the results that he was able to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: There are aspects of this legislation that are of concern. It will be interesting to see how they are achieved and how the implementation is achieved on the ground. The submission by the Australian Taxation Office to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was enough to concern anybody. Poor estimates and generalisations damaged the claims of that office to have changes made to improve the Australian tax file number system.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating the tax file numbers legislation. This afternoon we have had a limited number of Government members speaking in support of this measure. It is typical of this Government that it should use a number of strategies to squeeze more tax out of the Australian people. This is the second attempt of this sort that the Government has made. It tried to introduce the horrendous Australia Card, which was unanimously rejected by the Australian people. The Australian people would not contemplate such a measure. The Government backed off because it was fearful of the electoral consequences of the Australia Card.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes that everyone must pay his tax dues, no more and no less. After a number of changes were indicated by the Government, we agreed that there should be a tax file numbering system with proper privacy protections. A number of amendments proposed by the Government and the Opposition are before the House this evening. The Opposition has been concerned about a number of things, including the submission of the Australian Taxation Office to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. After much probing that submission indicated that the likely revenue gains to the Tax Office by 1994 would total $337m. Even with the use of the unique identifier, as proposed in the tax file numbering system, approximately 70 per cent of the interest which is currently untaxed will still be untaxed. The Australian Taxation Office admits this.

The Opposition is also concerned about the administration of the prescribed payments tax, which is a requirement for contractors and sub-contractors. It is a process whereby piles of paper are acquired by the Tax Office. This paper gathers dust in warehouses and no reconciliations are done by the Australian Taxation Office to see whether people are paying the appropriate amount of tax under this system. The only reconciliations that are done under the prescribed payments system are the ones done in the Taxation Office when taxpayers are called in. We believe that there is a similarity between the tax file numbering process and the prescribed payments tax. Reconciliations will not be done but much paperwork will be foisted upon the Australian taxpayer.
What is the Government up to? What is its real agenda in all of these tax measures? The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said a number of things. In May 1983 he said:

There is a responsibility on every member of the Parliament and every member of the community to see that the opportunity opened up by the success of the Summit is not frittered away. The spirit of shared sacrifice and restraint and the determination to take the steps needed to achieve recovery must be carried into effect in all areas: In wages and industrial relations; in the policies of business throughout the economy; and through the policies of government. I commend this vital national enterprise to each honourable member and the nation we represent.

That was five years ago. What has been achieved since then? The level of sacrifice in the Australian community has produced the highest taxing government in Australia's history. That regime has been administered under the bushranger from Bankstown.

Let us look at how the average Australian is faring under that sacrifice promised by the Prime Minister in 1983. At the moment the average tax rate is 26.9 per cent, compared with 22.9 per cent five years ago. The amount of tax paid per week by the average Australian five years ago was $85 compared with $140.50 now. The single income family paid tax of $65 per week five years ago and it is now paying $119 per week. Five years ago bank interest rates were 12 1/2 per cent; they are now pushing 15 per cent. Average repayments on homes five years ago were $350 a month compared with $666 a month now. This is coming out of the pockets of the average Australian. This is the sacrifice the Prime Minister spoke about five years ago. The people are really sacrificing.

The real disposable income of an Australian family with two dependent children was $23,419 five years ago. In July 1988 it was $21,139. There has been a real fall in disposable income during the period of sacrifice under the Hawke Government. That sacrifice was established at the summit called by the Prime Minister. The net tax payable five years ago by a family with a dependent spouse and two dependent children was $2,998. It is now $6,206. There is the sacrifice. Again, it is a case of sacrifice and more sacrifice. The average Commonwealth outlay per year since the Hawke Government has been in office has been $68.5 billion. Under the Fraser Government it was $37 billion. That represents nearly a doubling in outlays by the Government in that five year period.

All of this has been promised for the sake of forthcoming tax cuts-the promises of the last Budget; the expectations of the Australian Council of Trade Unions; the desperation of the Australian community suffering with smaller disposable incomes and high interest rates. The Government has said that the tax file number must be a critical part of that. The Opposition has said that the Government can have its way, can have a tax file number with proper privacy provisions, and we will see what sorts of tax cuts we can expect. Can the Government deliver? Will it be able to provide the tax cuts? There appear to be some doubts at this stage in the minds of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and others in the Government. There was an expectation created in the last Budget because the Treasurer promised that he was setting the stage for major personal income tax cuts-not just tax cuts, but major personal tax cuts. Those were the words used by the Treasurer in the last Budget.

What is the Australian community looking at now? It is looking at the sacrifice, the restraint, the new taxes, the tax file number, and the effort of the Australia Card. What are we going to see? Let me remind the House of some of the new taxes. We have had the assets test-a brilliant invention for pensioners-and all the difficulties of getting that system to work and the stress and trauma caused by it. We have had the capital gains tax. I would like to inform the House that in my electorate I have first time home buyers with blocks of land which are now too expensive to build on. They have been forced to sell that land and to downgrade their expectations to land in other suburbs or to lower priced blocks of land on which to build their first house. They are being forced to pay capital gains tax on that first block of land. Great effort! This Government with its high interest rates and high taxes is so equitable to everybody!

What about the substantiation process that opens up the avenue of reverse onus of proof for the Australian Taxation Office? What about the fringe benefits tax? What about, of course, the make-the-rules-as-you-go process and the test-them-in-the-court-if-you-have-the-funds attitude of the Australian Taxation Office? The Government is saying, `Trust us and we will turn the corner'. The corner never comes. That is the problem. We never seem to turn the corner. The latest publicity strategy of the Government to ingratiate itself with the Australian community will be to congratulate it for its restraint and sacrifice. Those are the proposals. There will be positive attitudes of congratulations of the Australian community for sacrificing to the degree it has. The corner never comes.

The deferral of tax cuts and the delay in the new incomes test proposed by the Government are just examples of the way that it can change its promises and break its promises. It is very interesting to track back the record and to read from a speech in 1981:

What a price the Australian community has had to pay for the implementation of such a bankrupt strategy: the costs inherent in the potential goods and services which have been foregone as a result of production levels being consistently depressed below capacity; the economic, social and psychological costs of persistent and massive unemployment; the emergence of shortages of skilled labour and the need to rely increasingly on immigrant skills; and the erosion of the living standards of the average wage earner. In relation to this last point, it is worth highlighting the fact that, as a result of an increased tax burden, higher health costs, rising interest rates, and continued high inflation, the typical family on average earnings is at present $8 a week worse off in terms of spending power compared with the situation in 1975-76.

Those were the words of the Prime Minister in 1981. He could be describing the failures of his Government. Of course, the only difference is that that real fall in disposable income for the average Aussie family is not $8 a week but $56 a week now. That is what the Government has cost the average Australian family in higher health charges, fewer job opportunities, higher interest rates, and a high taxation regime. Those words of the Prime Minister in 1981 are coming back to haunt him. He accused a moderate government, with lower interest rates, lower taxation levels and higher disposable incomes, of destroying the opportunity for the average Aussie. What has happened to date? There is more tax, a corner that never comes, and a Treasurer that said he had set the stage for major personal income tax cuts. The Treasurer himself has spoken many times of restraint. He has forced restraint on all sorts of people, including pensioners, whose pension increases he delayed. He has talked about that, but he is now backing away from his commitment to major cuts in personal taxation. We are discussing the tax file numbering process tonight that is to supply extra funds. Let us see whether it delivers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the terrible circumstances outlined by the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), one would think that Australia was almost in a depression and that Australians were so much worse off. He forgot to mention that since 1983, when this Government was elected, 1.2 million more Australians have jobs than when those opposite left government. Of course, Mr Acting Speaker, as you would be well aware, those extra jobs have come about because ordinary wage and salary earners, through the unions and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), have exercised wage restraint. That has not been easy for the union officials concerned. It has not been easy for the rank and file trade unionists, who have had great difficulty in making ends meet when purchasing their groceries at the supermarkets. They know that the fact they have exercised restraint through their union councils and through the decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission means that today 1.2 million more Australians have jobs compared to 1983. The figures cited by the honourable member for Mitchell perhaps suggest that people living in my electorate, for example, have suffered wage restraint. That is true. However, there are more people in my electorate today who have jobs than there were in 1983. That is something which he totally overlooked.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mitchell also suggested that this Government was responsible for the decline in living standards and that, if only Australians would elect the Opposition to government, suddenly everything would be fixed up. Of course, one thing he did not mention was the Opposition's attitude to wages. The Opposition, through the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and its other spokesmen on incomes policy, has opposed every wage increase for ordinary wage and salary earners for the last 10 years. The Opposition does not say that John Elliott and other executives should have their remuneration restrained. The Opposition believes that, because these people are part of the private enterprise system, in order to create the right incentives for them to make profits they should earn millions of dollars a year. But the Opposition has opposed every application for wage increases for the last 10 years.

The Opposition says that we are responsible for a decline in living standards. Yet every time this Government knocks out an agreement with the ACTU for a moderate wage increase the Opposition says that wage earners should get nothing; they do not deserve any increase; and that they should not have had any wage increases for the last 10 years. What would the living standards of ordinary Australians have been if honourable members opposite had been successful in having no wage increases paid to ordinary Australians over the last 10 years? I can tell them that the real disposable incomes of ordinary Australians would have fallen by a lot more.

The other comment made by the honourable member for Mitchell was that pensioners have been singled out for special treatment by the Government. I am getting a bit sick and tired of members of the Opposition suggesting that they are the answer to the difficult circumstances in which some pensioners live. I remind any pensioner who is listening to this broadcast tonight, or any pensioner who has the opportunity of being in the public gallery tonight, that in 1975, when the Whitlam Government lost office, pensions stood at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. That was when Malcolm Fraser was elected. When Malcolm Fraser, lip quivering, lost office in 1983, pensions had fallen from 25 per cent of average weekly earnings to only 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings. That is a real decline in disposable income for pensioners. Since this Government was elected, pensions as a percentage of average weekly earnings have risen from 22.7 per cent when Fraser left office, to 24.5 per cent today-within a whisker of 25 per cent, which is our long term target for the level of pensions. That is something which I know many pensioners understand because they remember what it was like under the Liberals-the 50c a week increase which was given to them by Bill McMahon and the other Liberal Prime Ministers. They know what the Liberal record is.

I turn now to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill which is before us tonight. Of course this legislation provides for the introduction of a tax file number system, something for which those of us on this side of the House have been campaigning for more than three years now. When the campaign started we were fighting for the Australia Card, which was something which we believed would have enabled us not only to fight tax avoidance and tax evasion, but also to cut down on social security fraud and to prevent illegal immigrants from misusing the services which are available to people living in Australia. Members of the Opposition had a great win! They were able to defeat the Australia Card due to the fact that regulations could be disallowed by a vote of the Senate-a great victory for members of the Opposition, but not a great victory for the ordinary Australian taxpayers who today are paying more tax because those social security cheats are still out there cheating and the illegal immigrants still have not been found.

But I have to say one thing about members of the Opposition: I commend them for the fact that they have been prepared, in a spirit of compromise, to reach agreement with the Government to introduce the tax file number system. The tax file number system will allow this Government to crack down on those people who are not paying their fair share of income tax. It is long overdue. Of course, we are all aware of the so-called black economy where people are able to work under false names and, in some cases, pay no tax and, in other cases, pay less tax than they should. Unfortunately, there are some areas of the economy where it is very common for people to work under false names and not pay their fair share of tax. We should remember that every time one of those people does not pay a dollar of tax which he or she should, ordinary wage and salary earners have to pay an extra dollar to make up for the dollar which that tax cheat has not paid.

I wish to outline to the House a few press clippings which I have recently collected on the question of tax avoidance. These, of course, refer not only to the introduction of the tax file number system, but also to the attitude of the Australian Taxation Office to those high income earners, those working in the black economy, and also to companies. The first clipping is from the Sydney Morning Herald of 13 September. It is headed, `Blitz on cheats, warns tax chief', and states:
The Tax Office is to examine luxury lifestyle assets such as boats, racehorses, expensive cars and flats as part of a special crackdown on tax evasion by the rich.

The Tax Office will also target the building, cleaning, clothing, road transport, market gardening, fruit picking and shearing industries for investigation when the tax amnesty expires at the end of October.
The article goes on:

A small initial audit program last year had brought to book 25 barristers who were now being pursued for an average of $60,000 each in extra taxes and penalties. This audit has found 1,500 tax evaders, which would mean $6.9 million in revenue.

I repeat: $6.9m from 1,500 taxpayers-people in that very high bracket who have been avoiding paying their fair share of tax. I am right behind the Commissioner of Taxation in chasing a fair share of tax out of those people. The article continues:
Mr Boucher-
the Tax Commissioner-
said the Chatswood tax office had recently uncovered 'major rorts' in the cleaning industry in the North Shore area.
When one employer asked his staff to produce identification, 427 of them quit on the spot.
From that one exercise, 3,648 tax cheats-an average of 693 cheats per firm-will be brought to justice, Mr Boucher said.
It was not just employees who were evading their tax responsibilities.

Employers not only helped employees by arranging false bank accounts for them, a number were themselves padding payrolls and claiming deductions for wages paid to fictitious employees and, of course, pocketing the money without declaring it in their own tax returns.

We have discovered that some cleaning firms are employing some ethnic people lured with the promise of immediate work, and most times new identities. These firms usually pay them below award wages under fictitious names.
I am afraid to say that often when these people try to leave or change the arrangements they are blackmailed by their bosses, who threaten them with exposure and deportation.
Mr Boucher said on one occasion a tax officer, investigating a major cleaning business, tried to interview a Spanish cleaner working in the men's toilets, but the man said he did not understand.

When the tax officer started to speak Spanish, according to Mr Boucher, the cleaner was so surprised that he fell into the urinal with his hands on his head. The cleaner did speak good English and was working under a false name.

The Tax Office in the North Shore area has certainly found that in the cleaning industry and the hotel and the club industries there are large numbers of people working under false names. I believe that the Tax Office does have a responsibility to track down those people who are working under false names to make sure that they pay their fair share of tax. As I said before, every time someone in the cleaning industry does not pay a dollar of tax because he or she is not following the rules, ordinary wage and salary earners have to pay one extra dollar to make up for that dollar.

Two other articles which I wish to quote on this issue of taxation concern some comments made by Mr Boucher that he was prepared to take whatever action is necessary to make sure that companies pay their fair share of tax. This article is again from the Sydney Morning Herald. It is headed `Keating hits at business tax rorts', and states:
The Treasurer launched a scathing attack yesterday on business leaders for taking an attitude to tax which was `conceptually squalid', `astounding' and displaying `a lurk mentality'.
Mr Keating said he had told the Tax Office to `come down like a ton of bricks' on companies which were `rorting' the system.

The Government has given Australia a decent tax system for the first time ever, and it is not now going to be polluted by an attempt by lesser people to intimidate the Tax Commissioner in the carrying out of his statutory responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it the Leader of the Opposition?

—I welcome the interjection from the honourable member for Macarthur. Yes, in fact, it was the Leader of the Opposition. I will quote from a report in the Canberra Times of 23 September of comments made by the Leader of the Opposition. It is headed, `Howard criticises Tax Office head'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, stepped up his attack on the Taxation Office yesterday, claiming that some small-business people had been threatened with `jackboot raids' by tax officials.

He also sharply criticised Taxation Commissioner Mr Trevor Boucher, accusing him of using belligerent language and adopting a threatening pose which threatened to break down any trust between the business community and the Tax Office.

If the Tax Commissioner can make sure that people working in the black economy and people who are not doing the right thing are made to pay a fair share of tax, I certainly do not have any problems at all with the Tax Commissioner adopting a belligerent pose when he is dealing with some businesses which are taking part in the sorts of rorts which I have mentioned tonight.

As I said before, I welcome the fact that the Opposition is supporting the tax file number system. We all know that in their heart of hearts, the majority of those opposite would have been quite happy to introduce the Australia Card if they had been in government. In fact, the shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), was on record at the start of the Australia Card debate as having made comments in his own electorate that the Australia Card would have been a great idea. Certainly one of the National Party members, perhaps the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), suggested that thumb prints would have been a good addition to the Australia Card. The point I simply make is that the introduction of the tax file number system will allow the Tax Office to catch those who are working under false names and who have bank accounts, again under false names, and are not declaring interest which has been earned.

I think it is important that we recognise that in the legislation there is protection for the elderly. Having an electorate with more age pensioners than any other electorate in Australia, I have to say that I studied this part of the legislation very carefully. In fact, any person who receives an age pension or a similar entitlement from the Department of Veterans' Affairs will not be required to have a tax file number and be involved in this sort of scheme. This is something to be welcomed because many elderly people would simply be confused by the introduction of a new form of identification system such as the tax file number. This compromise in the legislation will work well.

As I said, I support the legislation. I commend the Opposition for agreeing to the Government's proposals in the spirit of compromise. Some honourable members opposite have suggested that they have had a great victory because the tax file number will be optional whereas we were going to make it compulsory. In a sense it is optional. But it is optional on the condition that people are prepared to pay tax of 49c in the dollar. I would not exactly call that optional. I support the legislation before the House and I commend the Government and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for introducing it at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Government's proposal to implement an upgraded tax file number comes at a time when the Government's credibility on the issue of the protection of individual rights is at an all time low. The Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill follows the Government's attempt to push through its identification card proposal, which constituted the most significant erosion of individual rights and liberties ever undertaken by an Australian Government. In the face of unparalleled community opposition, the Government nevertheless intended to press on with the implementation of the ID card. The nation was saved only when we found a fatal flaw in the legislation introducing the ID card.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not come to this debate with clean hands. The ID card was proposed at a time of rampant welfare fraud caused by the Government's administrative inefficiency. At that stage, the Government was running an open door welfare policy which encouraged fraud and the flouting of the proper eligibility criteria for benefits. Instead of trying to clean up its slack administration, the Government attempted to divert attention from it by introducing the ID card legislation. Having lost that round, it then had to focus on the real problem which, of course, was its administration.

While there has been some tightening up of the administration of the eligibility criteria for benefits, the Government still has not done enough. Only yesterday the Auditor-General's report into the Department of Social Security criticised the failure of the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service to follow rigorously the administration procedures set down for the application of the work test criteria for unemployment benefit. I know that the Department has been unbelievably slow in following up cases in which people on unemployment benefit are offered work and then voluntarily give it up, in many cases after only a few hours at work. Yet those people still remain on benefit. In nearly all cases they are voluntarily unemployed and should be taken off the benefit. I urge the Government to clean up its act and ensure that only those who meet the relevant eligibility criteria for welfare benefits obtain the benefits.

It is not only against this background of Labor's attempt to introduce the all intrusive ID card and its acknowledged administrative inefficiency that we have been asked to consider this extension of the tax file numbering system; it also comes at a time when the nation is suffering from the most massive tax grab ever. Never before have we seen so many new taxes introduced-capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, entertainment tax, the Medicare levy, the new sales taxes imposed on beer, wine, flavoured milk, computer software, orange juice and so on. New taxes have been imposed on Australia Post and Telecom Australia. Taxes have now been automatically indexed and many concessions to taxpayers have been removed. After five years of Labor the result is that personal income tax collections are up 107 per cent, company tax collections are up 136 per cent, and sales tax collections are up 147 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't let us catch the tax cheats.

—What an extraordinary interjection. That is why the taxes have doubled or trebled in the last five years. That is the talent that we have on the Government benches. We have had all these increases in taxation from the biggest taxing Treasurer this nation has ever seen. Little wonder that when he introduced this tax file number Bill and asked us to trust him, we did not. We do not believe him and we do not trust him. This is why the tax file number Bill and the Privacy Bill have been subjected to the most intense scrutiny from the Opposition and why the Bills have come to this chamber with so many amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the history we see that the Government attempted to introduce an ID card and failed; we see welfare fraud because of slack administration. The Government tried to divert attention from this to the ID card; it failed in that. It has attempted to tighten up welfare fraud but still has not done enough; it has increased taxes at a faster rate than ever before in this country; and now it wants to introduce a tax file number proposal. I will briefly recall the evolution of the tax file number proposal. I think that the House will then understand our suspicion of the Government and the Australian Taxation Office in this issue.

When the Government proposed the ID card, it was as a result of pressure from the Opposition that a joint select committee was established to review that proposal. That committee reported and, as is now well known, the majority of that committee opposed the Government's proposal. I quote from page 147 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card under a section headed `Conclusions and Recommendations':

4.52 These conclusions and recommendations are supported by a majority of the Committee comprising Mr James Porter, MP (Deputy Chairman), Senator Janine Haines, Senator Christopher Puplick, Mr Charles Blunt, MP and Mr John Saunderson, MP.
Honourable members will see that the majority of the Committee was made up of representatives from all parties; that is, Labor, Liberal, National and Democrats. It went on:

4.53 Having considered the Government's proposal for a national identification system, as well as alternatives such as the use of photographic cards and the extension of the use of the current tax file system, the majority of the Committee rejects all proposals for the issuing of identity cards, with or without a photograph.

The House will recall that the Government did not accept the report of that Joint Select Committee. It was only as a result of public pressure and a flaw in the Bill that the Government backed off. That Committee recommended an extension of the tax file numbering system. Page 148 of the report states:

4.57 The majority of the Committee unequivocally rejects the Government proposal for an ID system. It proposes the following outline for the extension and upgrading of the tax file number system . . .

A number of actions to be taken in extending the existing tax file numbering system are then outlined. The idea for an extension of the use of the tax file numbering system struck me during evidence which was given to that Joint Select Committee from the Australian Taxation Office. It was when we were discussing the difficulties that the Tax Office had in matching the flow of information provided to it from companies, banks and other financial institutions that I realised that if the tax file number was attached to the individual records that were provided to the Tax Office, it would be better able to match that information flowing to it with taxpayers' income tax returns. In response to questions which I asked on 24 February 1986, the Tax Office wrote to the Committee and said:

Tax officials who gave evidence before the Joint Select Committee on 24 February 1986 were asked by Mr J. R. Porter MP whether further information could be supplied in relation to three matters. The third involved a consideration of the scale of net revenue gains which would accrue if taxation file numbers were used in lieu of the Australia Card.
It went on to state under the heading `Tax File Number Revenue Gains':

At one end of the scale, if we followed the Australia Card identification requirements before allocating tax file numbers (and purified existing records on that basis), we would expect to achieve similar revenue gains to those under the Australia Card option without a photograph-with similar staff and equipment costs.

In other words, the Tax Office was saying that if we had exactly the same proof of identity procedure and the issue of a tax file number to every Australian citizen or resident, then we would garner about the same revenue. I remind the House that the revenue estimated under the Australia Card proposal for undeclared interest, for example, in a couple of years time would be $283m. So it was saying that we could get the same revenue by using the extended tax file numbering system, using the same procedure as the Australia Card to issue the number and by issuing everyone with such a tax file number. The Office went on to say:
At the other end of the scale, the use of the existing tax file number with its very low integrity would produce relatively little extra revenue.

Having regard to the existing level of reporting and checking for interest and dividend payments, the addition of a tax file number could be expected to improve our ability to process and match the information received with tax returns lodged.
That is just the point we were making. It said:
However, this would not seriously affect those evaders who use false names or invalid file numbers. The increased revenue gain is estimated at between $6 million and $9 million.

So the Tax Office was saying that an extension of the tax file numbering system to prescribed investments, on the basis of the issue of existing tax file numbers, would raise only an extra $6m to $9m. On the one hand we were told that if we had the Australia Card proof of identity for the issue of the tax file number, we would gain $283m, but if we just continued with the existing tax file numbering system and required those numbers to be annexed to all interest bearing deposits and so on, we would get only $6m to $9m.

The Australian Taxation Office was then pressed further, because we believed that they were rather pessimistic revenue outcomes. It was clear that the Australian Taxation Office was pushing the Australia Card down our throats as fast as it could, and it was trying to put us off an extended tax file numbering system. The issue was pursued nevertheless, and further information was provided to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. It is indicated at pages 290 and 291 of our report that it was possible, but the Tax Office kept impressing on us the difficulty of extending the tax file numbering system. Spread throughout its responses to us were comments such as, `This, of course, is a daunting task'; `It is our strong preference that a file number be allocated to all persons'; and `It would, of course, be unmanageable if a significant number of people were to wait just before the date for use of a file number to apply for the issue of a number'. It continued to raise these objections to an extension of the tax file numbering system, said it would really only work if we extended it to everyone in the nation and that if we did that we would get $238m.

But the Australia Card was rolled and the Government has now considered that the only option is to accept the original recommendation of the Australia Card Committee. The really surprising thing is that the revenue estimated to be collected is very near that which was estimated to be collected from the Australia Card. But we do not have the tax file number being extended to everyone in the community. We do not have new tax file numbers being issued to everyone who has already got one, although there will be a purification process. We have a large number of exemptions under the new system and we have a very restricted use of the tax file numbering system to areas where information is already being provided to the Tax Office from banks and companies paying dividends and the like. It is those authorities that will have to attach a tax file number-in other words a very limited use of the tax file number. What is the estimated revenue? The Australian Taxation Office told the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which is looking at the tax file number proposal, that it expected extra revenue mainly from undeclared interest in bank accounts would be $204m. That is only just less than the amount expected to be obtained by the introduction of the Australia Card, only a little less than that expected to be obtained, from the estimates given to us by the Australian Taxation Office, from the extension of the tax file number system to everyone in Australia-for all the uses under the Australia Card proposal.

It is extraordinary that at long last we have an honest answer from the Tax Office, after it did everything it could to put us off and after telling us during the Australia Card debate that the extension of the tax file numbering system was nowhere near as good as the Australia Card. The revenue projections we now have are nearly the same as with the Australia Card. Clearly the role of the Australian Taxation Office, in endeavouring to push the Government line on an Australia Card, and in now being backed into a corner with the Government and having to support the tax file numbering system, does not please me one bit. I would prefer the Tax Office to give to the Australian people and their representatives-this Parliament and the committees appointed by it-honest information and estimates based on the best evidence available to it. We do not want politically biased evidence being provided to this Parliament or to the people of Australia from the Tax Office. We want the facts. We have had a long history of incompetence in the Tax Office, highlighted by a number of reports which have indicated the inefficiencies and the need for an improvement in its administrative arrangements, which we sought to assist in remedying by improving the ability of the Tax Office to match the flow of information to it. Thus, I find it disgraceful, as a member of a parliamentary committee of inquiry, to have been put off by the Tax Office by low revenue estimates at the time when the Australia Card was still in the offing, and now to be encouraged by much higher estimates when the tax file numbering system is the only option.

I am glad the Government has been forced to accept the recommendations by me and others to improve the ability of the Tax Office to match the flow of information to it from banks and other financial institutions with income tax returns by the addition of a tax file number. That really is the extent of this legislation. We are saying to employers, banks, other financial institutions and companies, `When you supply information to the ATO, do not just provide the name and address; give the tax file number which will be provided by your employees or clients'. I do not see a problem with that as long as we guard against any unreasonable extension of this legislation. The last thing we want is a de facto ID card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) talked about the ID card and the fact that it was defeated because of a technicality. He tried to draw an analogy between the ID card legislation and this present legislation, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill. Of course, the fact is that they are not analogous. There are many differences between the two Bills and, frankly, in my view, the ID card legislation was not the sort of legislation that everybody should have been against, anyway, because in fact we now have the system of identification which the Australia Card legislation would have set in place. In any event, the honourable member for Barker said that this Government had doubled and trebled taxation. He did not tell us, of course, that under this Government the top marginal tax rate has come down from 60 per cent to 49 per cent. He ought to go back to school and learn arithmetic, because in my book a reduction from 60 per cent to 49 per cent certainly does not amount to a doubling or trebling of the tax rate. I also say to him that, if he considers that there is a lack of talent on this side of the House, he had better look at himself, because he is the one who has been relegated to the back bench. At least some of us have moved from the back bench and are going towards the front. (Quorum formed) I was getting a bit concerned. I do not know what I said that upset honourable members opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the Bill. One of the most notable achievements of this Government has been its determination to stop the insidious effects of the tax avoidance industry. Until this Government was elected, it was common knowledge that if one had enough money to buy the best of legal advice and was able to get the best Queen's Counsel from Sydney and Melbourne-that is where they normally come from-it was only a question of setting up an elaborate tax avoidance scheme and one could get around paying legitimate taxation. The Government's introduction of such measures as the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the assets test has gone a long way towards ensuring a fairer tax system. We all remember the cries from the Opposition-in many cases the friends of the tax avoidance industry-that these measures would not be accepted by the public. But, of course, not only has the general public fully accepted these measures but also there is absolutely no doubt-I repeat: no doubt-that, in the unlikely event that honourable members opposite would be elected as a government, they would retain the same measures that we have instigated. We had the guts to put them into place. Honourable members opposite would not have had the guts to do it because they would have upset some of their friends in the tax avoidance industry.

For far too long the bulk of the tax burden has rested on the shoulders of honest people. Pay as you earn taxpayers have never had the opportunity of avoiding tax. Others have decided that it was only correct that they should pay their fair share and have not involved themselves in questionable taxation practices. On the other hand, there are many unscrupulous people in the community who will go to any lengths to ensure that they pay little or no tax. In the main, these people use such devious means as false names, the non-declaration of income, or the failure even to lodge tax returns. This legislation will go a long way towards stamping out these practices by increasing the efficiency of the Australian Taxation Office's income matching system. I fail to see how anyone can legitimately object to this legislation. And whilst I notice that the Opposition has finally, and probably most grudgingly, agreed not to oppose the legislation, I find it incredible that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), had to fight tooth and nail to get the coalition to agree not to oppose it. It is obvious that there are still many honourable members opposite-we just heard from the honourable member for Barker; he was obviously one of those who were against it-who are still prepared openly to support tax avoiders. I find that quite sad. In fact, if today's disgraceful performance at Question Time is any indication, it seems that there are many frustrated Opposition members who are not all that happy about the fact that they were rolled in their own party room.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again.

—Yes, again. The Tax Office's income matching program at the moment relies on names and addresses to match details contained in taxpayers' returns. Of course, the upgraded tax file number system will make it much easier for the Tax Commissioner to know exactly what is happening and to be able, through the Tax Office computers, to match income returns with such things as interest notifications from banks, et cetera. By providing tax file numbers rather than names and addresses for income matching, this legislation will substantially improve the efficiency and the effectiveness of the Tax Commissioner's income matching procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing new in this procedure. It has been used by the Tax Office since 1936. The extended use by the Tax Office, however, will simply improve the chances of detecting tax cheats and will apply equally to individuals, trusts, partnerships and companies. The present income matching system, because of the lack of information available to the Office, is resulting in some 30 per cent of income reports received by the Tax Office not being matched at all. This legislation will ensure that each taxpayer is declaring all income and paying the correct amount of tax. This is not an attempt by the Government to introduce an alternative to the ID card system, but rather a genuine attempt to put yet another nail in the coffin of tax avoiders. Slowly but surely we will get them all, difficult as that may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite so.

—As the honourable member for Fisher says, quite so. As long as we are in government, we will do something about getting the tax cheats. It is estimated that over the next 10 years some $2.2 billion of revenue will be returned as a result of this legislation. This shows just how large the problem is with tax avoiders and with people who are prepared to cheat the tax system at every available opportunity. Whilst I believe that this legislation will go a long way towards catching those dishonest people who take particular pride in avoiding tax, I believe that it will be virtually impossible to cast a net wide enough to catch everyone who is defrauding the system. Of course, I refer here to the cash economy. I think we are all aware of the assiduous nature of those who involve themselves in the cash economy. They think they are being very clever and smart in avoiding paying tax. But let them be warned that, while this Government is in power, all reasonable measures will be taken to stamp out this most unsavoury practice. This legislation goes at least some way to trying to address that problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The recent tax amnesty, which resulted in tens of thousands of people coming forward and lodging returns, is evidence of the fact that in the past some members of the community have scoffed at their obligations in this area. Indeed, it is common knowledge in the community, particularly in the small business community, that some small business proprietors keep two sets of books, one for the Taxation Office and another that the accountant keeps under his drawer, or that they keep under their drawer, to be used to explain to a prospective purchaser what the business is really worth. We have heard that time and time again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Terry Lewis.

—Yes. As I say, it is common knowledge that that is in fact the case. These books are used to establish the real value of a business-particularly, as I say, small businesses such as take away food shops, fruit shops, and so on. Proprietors always seem to be able to say, `Look, it is worth $100,000. The figures show that it is worth only $20,000 but, believe me, it is worth $100,000'.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst no accurate figures can be attributed to loss of income from the tax revenue in this area, I am sure that any estimate of loss would have to be in the hundreds of millions and perhaps even billions of dollars over a short period. What annoys me the most about these willing participants in the cash economy is that, by defrauding the Tax Office, they are not so much being smart and clever but are forcing the honest citizen into paying much more than would normally be the case. I have no doubt that, if everyone paid the correct amount of tax, the burden on honest taxpayers could be substantially reduced. Again, while no accurate assessment is possible, there is little doubt that tax rates could be almost halved if everyone was honest in his dealings with the Tax Office.
