The Australian newspaper editorial of 15 October 1988 makes the following very good points:
It is no secret to either the average Australian taxpayer or the Tax Commissioner that a large number of Australians fail to pay their fair share of tax.

The so-called `black economy' is rife. Few tradesmen-be they plumbers, electricians, builders, mechanics or gardeners-will not offer a discount for a cash payment. Likewise professionals such as dentists, accountants, architects and-
heaven forbid!-

even lawyers will offer trusted clients very favour-able rates should they agree to pay in discreet bundles of now untraceable cash. And, of course, criminals such as drug dealers rarely deal in anything but cash.

There is also a disturbing number of Australians who are not averse to helping themselves rather lavishly from the public purse through either bogus or multiple claims for either unemployment benefits or various pension payments.
The editorial goes on to say:
Australian taxpayers have been waiting far too long for their promised tax cuts. This legislation should enable Mr Keating to gather enough in his coffers to actually fulfil his promises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three hundred million dollars?

—It will be a lot more than that over a period. A number of respected editorials have applauded the upgraded tax file number system. A number of columnists have done so as well. Claude Forell wrote the following in the Melbourne Age of 19 October 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: That is my tax-file number and I don't much care who knows it. Why should I? If I had the same number on my Medicare card, passport and driver's licence, I might even remember it.

I see no need to conceal my identity or pretend to be someone else. My tax is paid up. I have not been moonlighting. My modest savings are not invested under false names. I am not cheating social security.
My credit is good. No debt collectors are chasing me. I am not a maintenance defaulter. I am not hiding from the police or bailiffs. It is my telephone number I would rather keep private.

Why should any law-abiding citizens or honest taxpayers get into a fuss about the Federal Government's upgraded tax-file number scheme? To them, the collective benefits will far outweigh any minor individual inconvenience.
He goes on to say:

The tax-file number system is not intended to increase the total tax burden but to ensure that it is more equitably borne by catching or deterring some of those who have contrived to evade their fair share.

It is possible to quibble about the estimated yield and costs. But experience has shown that tightening of the tax rules and making their application more effective tends to net more in revenue than the Government ventures to estimate.
Towards the end of his article he says:

In a modern computerised and credit-sodden society such as ours, government and businesses have already accumulated a vast volume of personal data about almost everyone. As citizens, we have already lost the choice of being nonentities.
The extended use of tax-file numbers will not give the Tax Office any more information than it is entitled by established law to know, and this knowledge will not be shared with any other agency.
Honest citizens have nothing to fear. They have much to gain if those engaged in tax rorts are made to pay their dues.

The measures introduced by the Government, of which the privacy legislation is part, will ensure that the Tax Commissioner at least has a vehicle available to him to be able to strengthen the income matching procedures so as to catch the tax cheats out there in the community. It is not the whole answer, but at least it will go a long way to doing something about this insidious problem of tax avoidance. I commend the Bills to the House. I am very happy that at least the Opposition, even under pressure, has come along and been prepared to support the legislation. I hope that the Australian Democrats do the same in the Senate so that the support is unanimous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make just a few remarks on this important piece of legislation in the context of my role as shadow Minister for small business. I know that out in the community it is the small business people who are, above all, the most worried about this piece of legislation. As the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) illustrated in the speech that he has just made and as I will be explaining during the course of my speech, they have good reason to worry because of the attitudes of many people on the other side of the House. The honourable member for Bowman spent a good deal of time levelling accusations at the small business community, saying that they were tax cheats.
—Only the crooks.

—And crooks, apparently. This is the sort of standard that the small business community has had to accept from the Australian Labor Party. It is not surprising that, when important pieces of legislation like this are introduced, the small business community does not trust the Labor Party. The honourable member for Bowman interjected that small business people are crooks. That really explains why small business is so deeply concerned about this Government. This Government is antipathetic to small business and we have had that evidence in just the last two or three minutes in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the tax file number system has been massively controversial. It has been massively controversial because of the breakdown in trust, the breakdown in good relations, between the Government and the Australian Taxation Office on the one hand and the small business community on the other hand. The small business community sees the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Commissioner of Taxation as a threat to its livelihood, as people who are antipathetic to what is without any doubt the locomotive of the Australian economy-small business.

There are three basic aspects to the difficulties that small business has, and has increasingly, with the Labor Government and the Tax Commissioner. The first, which is by no means the responsibility of the Tax Commissioner, is the enormous tax burden which has fallen on the small business community over the last 5 1/2 years. We have seen increases in personal income tax for the average small business; we have seen the imposition of a whole raft of new taxes-the fringe benefits tax, the non-cash fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and so the list goes on-and we have seen small business ignored when the Government reduces the company tax rate and takes away accelerated depreciation provisions. Such changes do not benefit the small business community. It does not benefit from cuts in the company tax rate. The growth in the taxation burden on the small business community-it has been a very rapid growth-understandably creates a feeling or antipathy between that locomotive of the Australian economy and the Government.

Secondly, the small business community, I think with some justification, feels singled out and harassed by both the Australian Taxation Office and the Government. There was the disgraceful instance earlier this year when the offices of the Australian Small Business Association were raided by officers from the Australian Taxation Office and the membership lists of the Small Business Association were taken away. Legal, yes, but harassment it certainly was. It is that sort of thing which breaks down the relationship of trust that should exist between the Government and the Taxation Office on the one hand and the small business community on the other.

There is a constant suggestion from the Government and from the Taxation Office that small business is guilty, that small business is responsible for all the tax rorts and all the tax cheating that takes place in Australia today. We have just heard it from the honourable member for Bowman. Again and again the Government attacks small business as being the manufacturer of tax cheating schemes. We know that tax cheating is going on in the community. Frankly, it probably always will in every democratic society, regrettable though that may be. I would certainly never condone it-I have far too much respect for the rule of law to do that-but where it has happened there is no reason to believe that small business is somehow culpable and that everybody else should get away scot-free. It is the continual harassment of small business that creates the distrust which makes the taxation system all the more difficult to operate.

The third reason why the trust that should exist between government and the small business community has broken down is that many people in the small business community are individualists who feel very strongly about something that we on this side feel very strongly about-their civil liberties. It does not happen for us to be a glib phrase that `civil liberties do not matter very much'. For us it is not something that a few bureaucrats can sneer at, saying that civil liberties do not matter very much as long as we have lots of rules and regulations.

For people in the small business community and people who have been brought up on a healthy diet of liberty as, fortunately, most people in this country have-under Liberal governments-many events in the last 5 1/2 years have given them good reason to fear the breakdown of civil liberties. We had a most unpleasant debate about the identity card, with all the implications that had for people's civil liberties. The fact that the identity card legislation was introduced and advocated by the Government, the fact that a government wanted to impose an identity card on the whole of this nation, understandably accelerated that climate of distrust. There has been the Bill of Rights issue, in the wake of which came the identity card. That, too, created a feeling of distrust-of Big Brother standing over people and telling them what to do, what to think and how to behave.

Even if such considerations do not matter much to the Government or to people such as the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), who thinks that individual liberty is a bourgeois concept, they matter to ordinary people, and particularly to individualists in the small business community. When on top they see this quite random exercise of the powers of the Australian Taxation Office, following the harassment of small business meted out by the Australian Taxation Office, it is not surprising that they are suspicious of a proposal such as a tax file number. One cannot blame them for at least being suspicious. There has been a breakdown in trust between the small business community, which is the locomotive of this economy, and the Government and the Australian Taxation Office. That should worry members of this House, and, above all, the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasurer. I am sorry that it does not worry them, because I believe they feel rather gleeful about what they are doing to the small business community.

So we are now to have the tax file number system, a scheme that scrapes past the test of acceptability because of the introduction of Opposition amendments. Nobody deserves more credit than does the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), the shadow Attorney-General, for the excellent job he has done, as has the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). Inevitably, the small business community will argue that at face value the tax file number scheme is the son of the identity card, but because of our amendments Opposition members can say with confidence that the scheme is certainly not the son of the identity card. In the first place there is no obligation on taxpayers to quote their tax file number. If they do not quote that number, they will pay the highest marginal rate but qualify for a refund at the end of the tax year. That more than anything counters the argument that somehow this is a measure that is related to the pernicious identity card that Labor tried to introduce last year. It is worth noting that it is an offence for an authorised person to require the tax file number to be quoted, and it is also an offence for an unauthorised person to request the tax file number. Again, if this were an identity card or a substitute for an identity card, the system would not work if it included those provisions. Also worth noting is the fact that financial institutions and employers do not have to require the tax file number.

Many people in the community will not need a tax file number at all. That point is worth mentioning in the context of the argument whether this system is a substitute for the identity card. The 2,500,000 pensioners will not need a tax file number, nor will children under 16 years of age, and the list goes on. The tax file number will not be needed for loan accounts, such as for mortgages. It will not be needed for non-interest bearing accounts and existing interest bearing accounts where the rate of interest is less than $120 a year. People in that category include about 70 per cent of all account holders with building societies and credit unions. Investments in items such as real estate will not require the furnishing of a tax file number. At the end of the day an enormous number of categories of financial transactions will not require in any way a tax file number. In such instances the number will simply be irrelevant. It could not be used to collate information on somebody's finances or reused by other departments in the exchange of information about individuals.

As I have mentioned earlier, what the Opposition has done in terms of strengthening the privacy legislation and the privacy guidelines will provide very significant protection to people who are concerned about the possible abuse of the tax file number. The point should be made that, according to the guidelines that the Government has produced and the Opposition has agreed to, the tax file number is not to be used as a national identification system by whatever means. Tax file number recipients shall not act in an unauthorised manner to use tax file number information as a means of matching personal information about a person. It is worth mentioning that guideline as well because it is extremely relevant.

The Opposition has made a whole series of amendments to the Privacy Bill to strengthen it. When one looked at the original Bill one had every reason to be suspicious. For example, why was it that the Government's original Bill provided that the Privacy Commissioner `may' issue guidelines on the collection, storage, use and security of the tax file number information, but did not have to do so? It is extraordinary that the draft legislation contained the word `may'. We sought to amend that and the Government accepted our amendment. The word `may' has been replaced by the word `shall'. That is an extremely important change that the Opposition has made to this legislation.

Originally in the Government's draft Privacy Bill no guidelines or rules were set down for tax file number information. Goodness knows why they were not contained in the legislation. Goodness knows what the Government had in mind by not including those guidelines or rules. The fact is that those guidelines have been specifically put in by the Opposition and they have been accepted by the Government. I think that a very good job has been done by those on this side of the House-in particular the shadow Attorney-General and the shadow Treasurer-in ensuring that we have a proper piece of legislation which protects the privacy of individuals, which ensures that it is not an identity card system in disguise and which, at the end of the day, may turn out to be a piece of legislation which is cost effective. But that remains to be seen.

The Australian Taxation Office and the Treasurer boast that the measure will raise $2.25 billion over a 10-year period; that its introduction will cost $279.5m and that it will raise about $337m per annum. That remains to be seen. Those estimates sound terribly specific. However, when the Australian Taxation Office was asked in a Senate committee to give details of how it came to those figures, it found it extremely difficult to do so. Frankly, the details were never provided. It remains to be seen how cost effective the measure will be. If one takes the word of the Taxation Office at face value-I would not suggest that one should do that with the Treasurer-one would have to say that it will be cost effective. However, let us wait and see.

At the end of the day let me say this: the small business community will remain concerned about this legislation, not because with the Opposition's amendments it is in itself an insidious piece of legislation which will destroy the civil liberties of ordinary Australians, but because its confidence in the Australian Taxation Office, its confidence in the Labor Government and its confidence, if you like, in the system has gone. It has lost that confidence. It does not trust the Tax Office and the Government. That is a very unhealthy state of affairs in this country because, as I keep repeating, the small business sector is the locomotive of the Australian economy. If the Government, through the Tax Office, the discretion of the Tax Commissioner or legislation introduced by the Labor Government, intends to harass the small business community, this country will be a very unhappy economic climate-an even more unhappy economic climate than it has today.

This is an opportunity for the Government and the Tax Office to make a new start, to try to treat the small business community with a bit more respect, instead of marching around the country accusing, by implication, the small business community of being rorters and tax cheats and of being guilty before any evidence has actually been assembled against it. It is a very bad thing. It is very bad for government and for business. I hope that at the end of the day the Government will begin to learn the lesson that it must work in cooperation with the small business community and not continue to harass it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I consider it a privilege to be present in the House tonight as a member of the Government which has introduced the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill 1988 and the Privacy Bill 1988 and to have the opportunity to follow the comments made by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I intend to pick up some of the things that he said. I believe that in 1983, when the Hawke Labor Government was elected to office, a number of tasks were expected of it by the Australian community. Those tasks included the task of bringing Australians back together again, restoring employment, balancing the books and opening up Australia to the real world. The honourable member for Mayo mentioned that it is necessary for people to have confidence in the tax system and in the Government's administration of it. It is my belief that in March 1983 a very strong component of the vote of confidence which saw the Hawke Labor Government elected was a plea that the tax system be cleaned up and that confidence in it be restored. This legislation is a component-I believe it is a major component-of what has been an ongoing tax reform. It is one of the final and major pieces of tax reform to be put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mayo in his contribution went on with the usual cant about small business. I have very close contact with large numbers of small business proprietors in my electorate. They have seen a couple of things happen. They have seen confidence restored in the economy and they have seen the rorts by the big fellows taken out. Most importantly, they have seen the removal of the double taxation of dividends for incorporated businesses. One of the very significant benefits that they know and understand-even though the honourable member for Mayo may not-is the real effect of the removal of division 7a tax and, in effect, the removal of double taxation. They have an incentive to retain profits within their businesses and use those profits to reduce their debt, increase their equity and invest in productive business ventures. Honourable members opposite should not continue the cant about the small business community. I say to them that the small business community is voting Labor. While they continue to make those sorts of speeches there is no prospect of the small business community turning to them.

I feel for honourable members opposite. I read with some interest today's press reports of their Party meeting yesterday to discuss this legislation. It has always been clear to me that their hearts are not in it. Their hearts are not in a decent tax system-a system which makes people accountable for their profits. Their hearts have never been in it. Honourable members opposite set the show on the road when they set up the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. They hoped that it would do over the painters and dockers. Where did it finish up? It finished up in a bottom drawer in the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. Where were members of the Opposition on those issues-the bottom of the harbour issues and all those other things? They were soft, because they were interested in a tax system which was soft around the edges, a tax system which was not enforced and was not complied with.

Over the last five years we have seen a number of major reforms. Almost every one of those reforms was vehemently opposed by members of the Opposition-none more so than reforms such as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, increased powers to the Tax Commissioner to enable effective auditing of corporate activities, the shift of the self-audit system, and so on. All these measures were opposed because in the end it meant that the groups the Opposition listens to and represents were the ones who were most at the target.

Yesterday in the party room the tax file number did not go to the vote, as I understand it. My best advice is that no-one wanted to seriously test it because of the question of the leadership. I can understand that. If the Opposition members were going to vote against their leader it would have been better not to have a vote. The fact is that their hearts are not in it. They have been forced to the watering trough on the tax file number. The reason for that is that they know they have run the privacy cant as far as they can. They know that, had they opposed this legislation, they were going to be roundly drubbed in the community as soft on tax cheats, soft on people who consider it their civil liberty to rort the system and rip it off others who are fair, honest and decent taxpayers. Members of the Opposition knew they were going to be labelled as soft, as they knew they would not be able to wriggle out of it, so they stuck with it. This is very good. It is delightful to see that the Opposition has come to the party on this legislation, albeit in the softest possible way.

Let us look at the tax file number legislation. There has been a lot of discussion by the Opposition about the question of civil liberties and the massive gain it has had in winning amendments from the Government. The fact is that the Government considers the tax file number legislation a very important tool for the Tax Commissioner in carrying out his functions in a modern, computerised era. Something that may not be broadly known around the place is that each year all the major financial institutions send to the Tax Office a return which shows the interest payments that have been made to the holders of accounts. But what is not on that return is a tax file number. So the Tax Office has no capacity to match up the returns from the myriad of institutions with the information that is supplied on their own files-unless it does a person by person check, a random check, which at the moment is done manually. The tax file number will enable computer matching of those returns. That will throw out the accounts that are in false names, the accounts that have not been declared, and so on.

No-one can come into this Parliament and bring forward any sort of legitimate complaint about giving the Tax Commissioner the ability to use modern, computerised techniques to improve the efficiency and fairness of his system. That was the situation the Opposition was faced with. If it was going to block this legislation, if it was not going to agree to it, albeit with amendments, it would have denied the Tax Commissioner an everyday, ordinary tool available in other countries and completely consistent with the move to computerise the administration of the system. Such an argument would not have held up, and members of the Opposition know it would not have held up. So whether their heart is in it or not-and I say their heart is not in it-the fact is that they are now saddled with it and the Tax Commissioner now has the capacity to do his job properly.

That brings me to another aspect of the legislation. I mentioned that the Opposition's heart is not in all of this. We are seeing at the moment a concerted attack by members of the Opposition on the role that the Tax Commissioner is playing in the community at the moment. What is the Tax Commissioner doing that is causing so much distress? He is going out and doing his job. We appointed him to administer the tax system; we appointed him to audit and examine properly what is going on, and now we have introduced a substantiation system and in the process of doing so we have asked the Tax Commissioner to ensure that these provisions are properly examined and measured. What do we find? Because he is doing his job he now faces these concerted attacks. They will not hold up. They will not stick in the ordinary community.

It is a great pleasure to speak on these Bills tonight and to support the introduction of the tax file numbering system which will give a tool to the Tax Commissioner which he should have been given a decade ago. Somebody, some administration, including the previous Government during its time in office, should have been prepared years ago to accept that the Tax Commissioner needed this ability to use computer matching techniques. But he was not given that ability, it was denied, and it has been denied over recent years and months by a consistent approach to block it. However, we have now reached the point where the legislation apparently will pass, and that is welcomed. The legislation is very much overdue. It is something that the Tax Commissioner and the tax system should have had available a decade ago. It is belated but it now means that the Australian Taxation Office will have available a much simpler method of ensuring compliance, and every Australian, especially Australians who believe the system, should be fair and apply to all wage and salary earners, will welcome the passing of this legislation tonight. I support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I express my appreciation to honourable members for participating in the debate on what I think is a fairly important measure in the history of the Australian taxation system. The tax file numbering system has been proposed to utilise, as my colleague the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) said, the technology of computers to match information with the tax files of taxpayers so that the tax system can work more effectively without resort to manual matching, which has been very much the order of the day to this point in time. The information provided in the tax file numbering system will deal with salaries and wages, the unemployment benefit, interest income, dividend income, unit trust distributions and, where there is an interest component, solicitors' trust accounts. In covering such a range of income it is entirely reasonable to assume that our revenue estimates, which amount to $2.2 billion over the next 10 years but in some of the earlier years around $330m a year, are on the conservative side, given the way in which other changes to the tax system have produced increments to revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole purpose of this measure, amongst other measures, is to improve the integrity of the taxation system in general; to improve its efficiency and to improve its effectiveness. Since 1983, when the Government came to office, we have taken steps to make the tax system better-to better serve the national interest and to better serve the revenue demands of the Commonwealth and its expenditure. I think the change in that integrity is there for all to see.

In the period in which tax reform has been undertaken, the Government has introduced a number of major structural changes to the tax system. The fringe benefits provisions taxed all benefits in kind, many of which were untaxed. In other words, the Government has taxed income taken as benefits, which in the main was formerly untaxed. It has also taxed income taken in the form of capital gains. Under the discretionary provisions in the former section 26 (a) much income went untaxed. The Government established a substantiation system so that deductions were subject to substantiation by taxpayers and could not be declared and treated as deductions without that substantiation. Deductions for entertainment expenses were abolished because of the difficulty of substantiating the purpose for which the expenditure had been incurred. I mention also the prescribed payments system, which we both established and extended during our period in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were wrong on negative gearing.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition talks about negative gearing. We were not wrong with negative gearing. We took negative gearing off after the capital gains tax had been introduced. One might argue that it could have come off earlier, but the fact is that where we provide a deduction of expenses incurred in the pursuit of income, when that income is taxed it is now taxed as a capital gain. All of those actions have changed the face of the Australian taxation system, so our revenue estimates for the period effectively have been doubled. In 1987-88 we expected $530m from the fringe benefits tax and we produced $881; from capital gains we expected $5m and we produced $400m; we expected $330m from the abolition of entertainment deductions and we produced $330m; we expected $105m from the substantiation provisions and we produced $350m; and we expected the prescribed payments system to produce $45m and we had an outcome of $45m. So the total outcome for those measures was in fact double the estimate that we had originally factored in.

SPEECH.PARA: That means that the tax system is working more fairly and more progressively. The Government has been interested in increasing the effective progression of the tax system, but in so doing we have broadened the tax base and cut rates. In cutting rates we have seen a higher level of compliance with the tax system and that higher level of compliance means, per se, that there is more effective progression in the system. We have a nominally flatter scale but we have a more effectively progressive scale. While the progression might not seem as steep as was apparent with the nominal progression of the former scale, with the top marginal rate of 60 per cent, the fact is that it is more effectively progressive now. That is demonstrated by the revenue yield it is now producing.

I think that all Australians can feel proud and satisfied by the fact that the tax system is much better, much cleaner, much fairer and more decent. In other words, many more people are paying their fair share of tax, thus relieving the burden on many others. This is the classic point about the high marginal rates of tax particularly. When some people avoid their tax, someone else carries the burden of the income tax system. It spills into higher rates of tax as the income base becomes narrower. What we have sought to do is to broaden the income base and, in broadening it, to reduce the severity and slope of that nominally progressive scale. That means that we have had more progression. I suppose one could argue that if we had a marginal rate of 100 per cent, the level of compliance would be very greatly diminished. If we had a marginal rate of zero per cent one would get 100 per cent compliance and wherever one reduces marginal rates between zero and wherever the rate scale is-wherever there is a movement between zero and 100 per cent-one would get an increase in compliance. Therefore, we have a natural inclusive compliance.

We noticed in the last tax year that refunds were down by 25 to 30 per cent. In other words, at the end of the year when people were normally claiming deductions which were then subject to refunds, there was a 25 to 30 per cent reduction in those claims simply because people were more prepared to comply with the tax system than in previous years. These are all important changes which have also helped the morale of the Australian Taxation Office. A government cannot really say to a tax administration, `Go out and get the revenue, except for those people who take their income as capital or in kind as fringe benefits and those who claim deductions without substantiating them'. By removing the conceptual holes from the tax law we are now providing a decent base in tax law which is then subject to administration and can be administered by the Tax Office. We have lifted the Tax Office's resources-we have increased its staff by 40 per cent since 1983, lifted its program and system resources and given it the tools to develop a decent revenue service. When I say `decent', I mean one of international quality and international standing. The tax file number is such a tool. In other words, we are giving to the tax administration something which it can really use and which is really valuable to it.

All of that means that we have a tax system now which has much greater integrity than probably at any time in the history of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which began in 1936. I know that practitioners in the tax industry, if I can use that expression, understand that the system has more integrity, that it is more effective and that it is more efficient than it once was.

We are very pleased that the measure does have bipartisan support. From the time that I first gave an indication that we would develop a tax file numbering system and introduce the Bill-which occurred during the May statement of this year-there was a positive response from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the shadow Treasurer (Mr Peacock), and also from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). The Opposition, from time to time, has had its doubts about this measure. We have tried to meet legitimate concerns-the ones which they raised I think were legitimate-and I have had a number of discussions about the matter with the shadow Treasurer. We have been able to settle most of the issues which they thought were a problem, particularly in relation to bank accounts and the freezing of accounts. We have moved to a withholding system in place of the former proposed measure. More recently we indicated yesterday we would accept amendments to give people the option of having to provide their tax file number or to have tax withheld on income in the categories that I mentioned earlier. They were proposed by the Opposition and I was pleased to accept those on behalf of the Government.

I am very pleased that the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), was able to meet the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and reach a point of agreement about the privacy legislation which is part and parcel of this measure. Indeed, this Act will not be proclaimed without triggering the privacy legislation and vice versa. Thus, the privacy provisions which the Opposition regards as important and which, right from the start, we regarded as important-that is, establishing new offences punishable by substantial penalties for breaches of the privacy code within the Bill-are reasonable safeguards on a system which is intended not to have any inherent capacity to disturb the privacy of people, but essentially to serve to run the tax system, as the tax file number system does now.

I think it must be understood that we have a tax file number system now. It is just that we cannot use that number for revenue information matching in the way in which we will be able to use it with this particular facility; that is, with a common number between the payment of income, be it wages or salaries, unemployment benefits, interests or dividends, and the tax file number of the taxpayer.

This is, I think, one of the legitimate tools that the tax administration of this country needs. We could probably well have had it many years ago; but better late than never. It will produce its revenue harvest. I think some honourable members challenge the estimates. I do not think that there is much validity in the challenge. I think that they are conservative estimates. On the basis of our experience-that is, the revenue yield from the measures that I mentioned a few minutes ago-it is likely that we will do better in terms of the revenue from this measure than we are even suggesting with these estimates.

So it is both a valuable and important change and it is important that tax changes of this variety that go to the heart of the administration of the system are ones which enjoy the bipartisan support of parties in the Parliament, and this does. The Government is pleased about that. We are glad to have the Opposition on board for these changes. Again, my thanks to my colleagues opposite, those who participated in getting support for the system within the Opposition parties.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Many of the amendments are as a result of the consultation that has taken place between the Government and the Opposition, as I mentioned a couple of moments ago, on this important piece of legislation. As I said earlier, I thank Opposition members for their participation in this process.

The amendments the Government has agreed to accept are designed to guarantee that the tax file numbering system is completely voluntary. They ensure that taxpayers will in all circumstances retain the right to elect to have tax withheld at source rather than quote their tax file number. The Government has always recognised that this is an important element in the set of privacy safeguards which attaches to the tax file number system and these amendments will enshrine that principle in the legislation.

Further, Mr Chairman, the Government agrees with the Opposition that the tax file number legislation should not commence before the privacy legislation. Accordingly we are moving an amendment to the tax file number legislation to ensure that it will commence on the same day as the privacy legislation that the Opposition generally supports.

As I announced in my second reading speech to introduce this Bill, the Government is moving an amendment to ensure that people receiving any part of an age, invalid or other pension from the Department of Social Security or service pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs will be exempt from the need to quote a tax file number to operate bank or similar accounts, buy shares, or have dealings with other financial institutions.

A person in receipt of any part of an eligible pension, benefit or allowance will be taken to have quoted a tax file number to a financial institution or other investment body upon the lodgment of a declaration with the investment body. The exemption will not extend to people in receipt of sickness or unemployment benefits as there can be no reasonable expectation that the recipient will remain on the benefit permanently.

Further to this announced amendment, the Government also proposes an amendment to the Bill to exempt people in receipt of any part of a qualifying pension or benefit from the need to quote a tax file number to an employer. The Bill presently exempts pensioners from having to quote a tax file number to the relevant department in respect of the payment of a qualifying pension or benefit. The amendment now proposed will extend that exemption to ensure that pensioners will not be required to quote a tax file number in connection with any non-pension or benefit employment income.

Loans made to government bodies and bodies corporate are included in the investment provisions of the Bill and, as a result, tax file numbers are required to be quoted by the lender to the borrower who is required to submit annual reports of the amount of interest paid to the lender in respect of the loan and to report the tax file number of the lender. As presently worded, these obligations would also apply to cases where a financial institution makes a loan, such as a mortgage or overdraft, to a corporate or government customer. As such reporting is outside the objectives of the tax file number proposal, an amendment is also moved to exclude from the investment categories for which tax file number quotation will be required, loans made to corporations or government bodies by financial institutions. In this way, financial institutions will not be required to quote their tax file number when making loans to their corporate or Government customers.

Two minor amendments are proposed in respect of annual investment income reports. The first will ensure that dividend and interest reports as required under the current regulations will continue to be required until the new requirements come into force. The second will make it clear that, as expressed to be the intention in the explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill, annual reports in respect of investment income are first required in respect of investment income derived in the financial year ending 30 June 1992.

Minor amendments are also moved to some penalties proposed in the Bill. Under regulations contained in the Bill, investment bodies that fail to comply with their reporting obligations will be subject to a penalty of $2,000. The effect of amendments now being moved by the Government will bring the sanctions for a failure to comply with the reporting requirements within the scope of the existing provisions of the Taxation Administration Act. Those provisions, which apply generally in relation to circumstances where a person fails to comply with requirements of a taxation law, incorporate increased penalties for repeat offences.

Broadly, for a first offence the penalty is an amount not exceeding $2,000 and for second or subsequent offences the maximum penalty increases to $4,000. In the most serious cases there is the option under existing provisions for a third or subsequent offence to attract a penalty not exceeding $5,000 and/or 12 months imprisonment.

As I said earlier, the Government deferred for some weeks the second reading debate on this Bill to give the Opposition time to talk with us on this Bill and the related privacy legislation. As a result, it became obvious that the commencement date of 1 November 1988 contained in the Bill for the first phase of the tax file number system could not be achieved. Accordingly, an amendment of the Bill is moved to enable this commencement day to be set by proclamation. Finally, some minor drafting measures are being made to ensure the original intention of the Bill.

Again, I thank all honourable members for participating in the debate, including members on this side of the chamber. I thank honourable members on both sides of the chamber who participated in the various committees of review of the measure-there are now about four or five, so the measure has had a lot of scrutiny-for their support, for their interest in the measure and for their intelligent inquiry into the measure. Again, I thank my colleagues opposite for their support for the changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking earlier about a number of these Bills and concentrating my remarks on the Telecommunications Amendment Bill 1988. I would like to make a number of points. The Opposition has a constant knee jerk reaction towards privatisation. It really does not have a feeling for or an understanding of the trading enterprises under discussion. It tends to overlook what has occurred on the Government side. I am pretty proud, as are all Government members, that there has been a thorough ongoing review of every trading enterprise, be it the Commonwealth Bank, Australian Airlines, Aussat Pty Ltd or Telecom Australia. I believe that no government has had a better understanding of its trading enterprises and the things that need to be done. Some of these Bills reflect the tremendous amount of research and review that went into this process. Unfortunately, I do not believe that the same could be said by the Opposition when it was in government. In fact, I believe that it has done very little in terms of ensuring the long term survival and competitiveness of these organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: I also mentioned previously remarks in another place by Senator Alston when he labelled the three-man committee that I was pleased to chair as the `Telecom Preservation Society'. I would like to take this opportunity to publicly place on record my appreciation for the work done by my two colleagues, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) and the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). We worked closely together as a three-man committee with the interdepartmental committee that had been set up to review Telecom, Australia Post, Aussat and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC). I believe that the May statement reflects a lot of that hard work, and a lot of the decisions that came out of it can be sourced back to that committee working closely at the coalface with public servants.

I think it is fair to point out to the House that this is a unique process which, as I have said, has led to significant reform and has worked well, and I think it is one which both the Government and the Opposition would do well to consider for any further tasks. Indeed, I am pleased to say that one of the unfinished matters that we had-the development of the International Development Association-is now progressing quite well.

I would also like to place on public record the role of Jane Smith, the private secretary of the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, who sat through all the meetings and all the briefings that we had, and certainly attended to all the people who came to see us. Jane played an invaluable part in the whole process.

Unfortunately, whenever the Opposition says a kind word about some of these trading authorities it never really extends it to the staff. I also want to place on record the tremendous contribution that is played by many thousands of staff who work tirelessly and consistently for the organisations that are the subject of this cognate debate-the postal services, Aussat, Telecom, the Australian National Railways and OTC. I believe that they are all making an outstanding contribution. Indeed, with some of the changes proposed in these Bills and in further Bills, I believe that they will have an enhanced role and an opportunity to make an even greater contribution.

In this review process I would also like to publicly place on record the role of the trade unions concerned in the review-people such as the Federal Secretary and officers of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union and the Electrical Trades Union of Australia. They always vigorously represented the best interests of their members and I think it is fair to say that they were not always entirely happy with the outcomes, but on balance, in a process of give and take, I believe that they have supported the changes. As I have said, they lost no opportunity to present vigorously the views of their members and to press for necessary changes.

I think one of the interesting contrasts is the way in which this Government goes about changes, as opposed to the Opposition. In terms of seeking fundamental, important change for the survival of these corporations, this Government engages in widespread consultations with industry, with business and with the trade unions and, having collected all those views and all those inputs, brings down its reform package. Contrast that with the Opposition tactic of bludgeoning through any changes. I think the New South Wales Greiner Government is a good example of that.

I support the changes that are in all these Bills, and especially the important change in the Telecommunications Amendment Bill with the introduction of a new board and the new role that that board will have. I think it is fair to say that the chief executive or the managing director, as the case may be, of an enterprise not only has responsibility for implementing the day to day running of the organisation, but by and large determines the policy and the strategy as well. This has been recognised and is certainly part of the amending Bill. The new board will clearly have responsibility for strategy and for long term policy, and the chief executive will have responsibility for its day to day operations. Incidentally, the chief executive's salary will now be free from consideration by the Remuneration Tribunal, but any new aspiring chief executive who is hoping to be appointed will have to stand international competition, in other words, the job is going to be advertised internationally. I think that is an important change and I hope it will secure the best quality chief executives available to the corporations, in this case to Telecom, but these remarks also apply to Australia Post.

These Bills also contain provisions for changes in working conditions. But of course these have to be negotiated between the new boards and the relevant unions. The provisions of these Bills will not be proclaimed until such time as satisfactory negotiations have taken place and all parties have reached agreement. These are important Bills. I hope the House will support them. They represent the first stage of Bills that will be dealt with successively by the House that introduced the important government business enterprise reforms announced in the May statement, which I strongly support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to support the comments of the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), who made a very powerful speech on the subject of the conversion of government commercial operations to public companies. At a time when governments around the world are selling their business enterprises, this Government is doing the very opposite. It is undertaking some organisational changes to entrench them in the public sector. We support some of the managerial reforms and efficiency measures, such as converting the organisations into public companies, yet only to the extent that it makes these enterprises eventually easier to be privatised. Tinkering at the edges does not address the capital funding requirements of these enterprises, for no matter how successful and how profitable government enterprises are, ultimately to keep pace with the private sector and to maintain the market share, large calls will have to be made on the taxpayer shareholders. This is where the logic of running government business enterprises can come very unstuck.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, the 1988 annual report of the Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (OTC) forecasts that by 1998, in 10 years' time, the company will require an additional $2 billion in terms of capital expenditure, and of this amount, 70 per cent can be funded internally, that is before taxation. Where does the remaining $600m come from? Either the taxpayer is slugged or, as is the recent practice of Commonwealth enterprises, it borrows large sums of money from overseas. I note specifically that both the OTC and the Australian National Line (ANL) are to be incorporated under the Companies Act. Although this smokescreen provides the impression that the newly formed entity will be bound in all respects by the companies legislation, the very opposite is the case. Government bodies may generally cooperate with the spirit of the law. They are, however, in no way subject to it. Furthermore, companies which take part in joint venture arrangements with government corporations are afforded similar protection.

Despite the rhetoric of the Government and the flavour of the second reading speech, which suggests that these bodies strike out into the world of commerce, it needs to be remembered that they go very much as privileged players-market players who are protected by law, with their financial destination underwritten by the government, and in the case of both OTC and ANL operating without any real competition. As an example of this, Qantas Airways Ltd can acquire another airline and breach the takeover code without prosecution. Similarly, companies participating in joint ventures with government enterprises that breach the Companies Code are also afforded the same protection. This points to the fact that the Government should not be involved in business. I wish to enforce that point as it applies generally to the comments I made today about the Rothwells affair. In this case, section 291 allows the Commonwealth Attorney-General to launch an investigation. My media release of 2 November states:
These are the dangers of involving Government in doing business. Regrettably, State Governments (including Victoria and W.A.) are some of the worst culprits.

In both cases the State governments have involved themselves in commercial enterprises which have turned out to be very doubtful operations. In the case of Victoria, the Victorian Economic Development Corporation floundered and had to be absorbed into another area. If it were subject to the rigours of company law outside Crown shield, it would be subject to prosecution. The same thing applies to the activities of the Western Australian Government, where joint takeover offers were made which were outside the law, but because one was subject to Crown shield nothing occurred. The media release further states:
These experiences make it crystal clear-no matter how tantalising a private sector deal may appear-Government must remain the referee, not the player.
Mr Moore said that if the States insist upon entangling themselves in business deals, they should not be allowed to claim Crown shield.
My advice to the States is to stay out of the private sector altogether. Taxpayers dollars must not be used on risky propositions.
Using taxpayers' money in ways in which even the most reckless venture capitalist wouldn't contemplate is despicable.
The public deserves to know if Rothwells is solvent, if their bookkeeping is in order and if there has been any other breach of the code.
Allegations of issuing a false prospectus, that debts which fell due have not been met, that provisions for bad and doubtful debts have been understated must all be answered.

I say this for a very simple reason that the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) no doubt would understand. When the proposition was put forward that a rescue operation for Rothwells take place, the underwriters and the sub-underwriters were gathered on the basis of a State Government guarantee. Any person here who has been subject to an underwriting agreement would know that before one signs an underwriting or sub-underwriting agreement one calls upon the person offering the deal to offer the acceptor of the contract evidence that the accounts are in order. That is common practice. I presume that these events occurred because the people involved in the deal were prominent citizens who were well practised in the art of sub-underwriting. Part of that deal was a State government guarantee. That would have been the most valuable contribution to any sub-underwriting agreement. It would not have mattered what was in the accounts in reality; it was the State Government guarantee on which they would have put up their money.

Time goes by, and those people have contributed to the capital of Rothwells. I refer to today's Australian Financial Review and the shareholdings that were taken up then and the shareholdings that were listed at the close of trading a couple of days ago, according to the Financial Review. Very few have reduced their shareholdings. They are still, in the main, there. The Western Australian Government is now saying that there is no State Government guarantee outstanding. What has happened? I claim that a false prospectus has been issued by the Western Australian Government, because all of a sudden these people who contributed towards Rothwells under the underwriting agreement, without any doubt on the basis of the State Government guarantee, put up the money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you substantiate that claim?
—The honourable member should read this morning's Financial Review.
—No, from your own knowledge.

—Working on my own knowledge of what happens in the financial world, I will stand by what I am saying. Any underwriting agreement that I have made as an underwriter or sub-underwriter-and I have done a lot of it-would--
—We are aware of your expertise, but that is a pretty wild statement.
—My expertise is a damn sight better than that of the honourable member for Capricornia.
—But it is just a hunch.
—Order! The Chair requests all members to direct their comments through the Chair.

—It is not a hunch. I am quite prepared to stand by what I have said in relation to what I have read in the newspapers. What has been said there is relatively common practice in relation to this matter. I am not privy to the accounts. I am not privy to the underwriting agreement. But I am prepared to bet that people would not have risked hundreds of millions of dollars in subscriptions to Rothwells other than on the basis of a State Government guarantee. Their money is still there. They still own the shares. But the State Government says that there is no longer a guarantee. These people are not fools. It is true that the State Governments says there is no guarantee, and it is true that there was a guarantee. I am saying now that, because of the changed circumstances, these guys are locked into this position in Rothwells on the basis of a false prospectus. I do not think there was a written prospectus as such, but certainly this has happened on the basis of a sub-underwriting agreement. Because of that, some very real questions have to be answered by those involved in this particular deal. Another prominent Australian ended up in gaol for precisely the same sort of deal.

SPEECH.PARA: Far too often, as the honourable member for Gippsland would know, we have seen examples of Crown shield being used by State instrumentalities to protect themselves from the law. I refer to the Kern Brothers situation in Queensland. Two wholly owned State Government instrumentalities owned a substantial shareholding in Kerns. Kerns was subject to a takeover by another body, and the State Government Insurance Office came in and bought that body up, making the State Government, in two hands, owner of nearly 30 per cent of the capital. Under the Companies Code, that requires a takeover offer. Because of the Crown shield, nothing happened. Let us deal with Victoria, where the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, comes from. Let us look at the wonderful performance of the Victorian Economic Development Corporation!

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you are getting political.

—Oh, Barry. I am shocked. Under that particular fiasco, actions taken by that Corporation put it outside the law, and no action was taken. In respect of Western Australia, I have just pointed to actions which were taken by the Western Australian Government in concert, in the place of Bond, in relation to Bell Resources, and what is happening in this case. And what has happened? Nothing. At Question Time today I asked the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in the national interest, to take an action under section 291 (2) of the Companies Code-and he ducked it. In giving his reason for ducking it he said, `It is not for me; it is for the States'. Only three weeks ago before he went on the cruise around South America he said, `Only we, the Federal Government, can do it. We must take it all over because only we can do it. It needs one body'. When the Attorney-General had the opportunity to exercise some power, what did he say?-`Not me; it's for the States'.
—What would you have done?
—It is not for me; I am not in government.
—But you are the one who is making the allegations.
—Order! The honourable member for Capricornia will remain silent.

—It is time we addressed ourselves to some of these problems and recognised the problems that beset the operations of companies and corporations in these large areas. The smaller investor in Australia has been written out of it. The larger investors, particularly the Western Australian players, have been allowed to walk all over the private investor. That is regrettable because the long term future of Australia requires that all investors get a fair go. So without the money of all Australian investors we will not get the capital commitment that is necessary to develop Australia. I have always been a strong believer in a market that is free, informed and competitive. I have never stood at any stage for what has gone on in what I regard as certain stock market plays which have been done by one or two players. There have been many examples of it. I have seen in the last few months probably some of the worst examples that relate to State government interference in the market-place which has not acted in the best interests of all concerned.
—I remember Bolte blocking Ansett.

—That is quite correct. The Ansett situation was another outrageous position. But that was not the only one. There have been a number of similar positions, as the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) has said. Because of that, I want to add my weight tonight to what the honourable member for Richmond said. It is not only high time that the Federal Government's trading corporations were made into corporations, as an interim step, as these Bills do, but also I want to see that step carried on and the trading corporations to be placed on the market and to become fully competitive in every respect.
—You would privatise everything?
—I did not say that at all.
—It is a valid question.

—It is a valid question but not a very intelligent one. We have made it quite clear on the list we have put out. Later this month I will be producing a booklet which will show Government members clearly how corporations should be privatised, marketed, and how the setting up should be gone about, and the list that can be handled in relation to it.
—Why haven't you got the booklet out now? It has taken you two years.

—Any dill would know that Australia has a relatively small capital market and that, because of that, it can only handle a certain number of floats within a year. If the Government wants to float the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and a few other instrumentalities in one year, it will probably take up the total savings within Australia in one hit. If the Government takes Australia's total savings at about $1 3/4 billion and floats the Commonwealth Bank and one other, it has the lot. The Government cannot do that without having an impact on the rest of the market.
—Ultimately you privatise everything. That is what you are saying.

—No, I am saying that we have publicised the list upon which we would act in the first term of a Parliament. After that, we would see what happened. We must free Australian taxpayers from the obligation of supplying billions towards our major enterprises. If the Australian major enterprises are not given that capital injection, the Government will find that they will fail. Already, as a consequence of the Government's inaction, the Commonwealth Bank is slipping from the big elephant to the small elephant. It just does not have the capital requirement. I can quote the chairman that the Government appointed, Mr Besley, who said in his annual report `We need capital'. What is the Government doing about it? Nothing. I can quote the Chairman of Qantas Airways Ltd, Jim Leslie: `We need privatisation'. Because of that, the Government has failed Qantas. If the Government does not contribute the capital towards the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas, those companies will not be able to meet the competition that will be in front of them in the years to come. They are not the only ones. Look at Australian Airlines. The honourable member for Gippsland, as a frequent traveller-even down the Amazon-would know that people have to catch planes, and those planes--
