TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard discussions in recent weeks about the visit to Australia of warships from around the world, the naval salute to our bicentennial birthday celebrations, the spectacular naval review on Sydney Harbour and, of course, the problems particularly in Melbourne. I would like to take honourable members back almost 25 years to another more important maritime incident-one that many people would prefer to forget and, regrettably, that includes members of the Government. I refer, of course, to the horrific collision between HMAS Melbourne and HMAS Voyager off the New South Wales coast on 10 February 1964.
—And they are still not even compensating them.

—That is quite right. Although the collision occurred nearly 25 years ago, we owe it to the 80 men who lost their lives, and more especially we owe it to the 400 survivors of Australia's worst peacetime disaster, to see that justice is done.

SPEECH.PARA: HMAS Voyager was sliced in two when struck by the bow of the aircraft-carrier Melbourne shortly before 9 o'clock on the evening of 10 February 1964. The Melbourne was carrying out night-time flying exercises with the Voyager in attendance. Two inquiries were held into the accident. The effects on the survivors were of little importance amidst the sensationalism and controversy that raged for years after. I am saddened to say that the Voyager disaster is still a story of injustice for the hundreds of crewmen who survived the horrors of that night.

Although the accident happened in peacetime, for the men on the Voyager their experience was no different from those who suffered in the theatres of war. Yet the survivors were not eligible for repatriation benefits. They were given to believe that they had no right to sue the Commonwealth for damages. Apparently this belief stemmed from a decision of the High Court of Australia in 1964 in which Mr Justice Windeyer stated:
The law does not enable a serving member of any of Her Majesty's forces to recover damages from a fellow member because acts done by him in the course of his duty were negligently done.

It was not until 1982 that the Full Court dispelled that notion with the view that there was no policy reason why serving servicemen should be deprived of the ordinary rights of common law which protect members of the community. It was said that the Commonwealth should be liable for a breach of duty of care owed by servicemen to each other. This decision prompted many men to seek compensation from the Commonwealth which initially did not seek to rely on the statute of limitations as a defence. So prior to 1985 some servicemen were able to recover damages from the Commonwealth.

But, it is on the public record that since November 1985 the heartless despicable action of the Commonwealth in relying on the limitation defence has denied justice to many survivors. In a recent decision of the Supreme Court of Victoria, Mr Justice O'Bryan made a pointed reference to the Commonwealth's actions. He said:
This ruling is most unfortunate and reflects poorly upon the conduct of the Commonwealth of Australia.

In our bicentennial year, this Government stands condemned for hiding its moral obligations behind a skirt of legal argument. For the sake of the cost of compensation, it has turned its back on ordinary Australians in need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about a union by-election which is occurring in New South Wales. I refer to the by-election in the professional division of the Public Service Association (PSA). The PSA is made up of some 55,000 members. The professional division is one of four divisions and has 14 members on the 86-member council which controls the union. To quote the Sunday Telegraph of 23 October 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: The result will be important to the balance of power between the left and right wings within the union and could even hold the key to the election of the next ACTU president.

The article goes on to suggest that the extreme left-wing progressives would support John Halfpenny as the next President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). The by-election will determine the control of the unions. The right wing reform team has 34 members on the council and the extreme left wing progressive team has 38. The reform group successfully mounted a legal challenge to the election that occurred in July 1987 and in May this year Judge Bauer ordered a by-election in the professional division. The challenge concerned the health professionals, who should have been in another division, and had a much larger than normal voter turnout, only 10 per cent of which voted for the reform group. The reform group is concerned at the fact that within 12 months the union has been transformed from having a cash surplus of $1.5m to a deficit of half a million dollars. The reform group has demanded-not unreasonably-an independent audit of the union's finances. This has been repeatedly refused.

Unfortunately, feelings have run deep in this by-election and a leading reform member, Mr Jerry Ambroisine, has been assaulted by the progressive Assistant General-Secretary of the PSA, John Cahill. The assault has been reported to the police in New South Wales, but they have failed to take any action and are to be condemned. I deplore the use of violence and intimidation in such elections. The PSA is under attack from the Greiner Government, which has great antipathy for its members, whether they be professional or otherwise. The professional division will have the opportunity to decide who will control the union. I sincerely hope that it will carefully consider the leadership needs of the union and reject any rorting or rough-house tactics. I hope that its decision will provide the balanced leadership, the strategy and tactics required to meet the challenges ahead that are likely to occur under a conservative government which is determined to break union power and particularly to single out hardworking public servants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the House what has been described in the media as the outback miracle vaccinations. This particular operation, which took place in central Australia, resulted from some work that had been done following the isolation of a very serious virus amongst the Aboriginal people in some areas of central Australia. The meningitis virus was isolated last Monday week. Medical teams from Urapuntja Aboriginal Health Service at the settlement of Utopia, about 300 kilometres north east of Alice Springs, decided to do something about the virus. Using State health funding and funding from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs they combined in a two-day effort to cover an area of 1,600 square kilometres to vaccinate all the younger children in that area who are likely to be affected.

SPEECH.PARA: These teams of medical officers and Aboriginal assistants combined in a very fine effort, using four-wheel drive vehicles and travelling over some of the most difficult terrain in central Australia to make sure that this very dangerous virus was contained amongst the young Aboriginal people. I just want to draw that action to the attention of the House as being very commendable and very much in line with the Opposition policies to give a heavy emphasis to the great health needs of the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to advise the House of a project that is occurring in my electorate in the town of Euroa. I feel quite sure that the Opposition Whip, the honourable member for Indi, (Mr Ewen Cameron), will listen with interest in his office to what I am about to say because Euroa falls in what was formerly the Federal electorate of Indi and the honourable member and his family still live in Longwood which is adjacent to the town of Euroa. I know that the honourable gentleman still has a great interest in what occurs in that town. The project concerns the Euroa high school and involves the entire community of that town. As the result of a very small seeding grant, the school community-including teachers and parents, and members of the community not involved directly with the school-have constructed a mud brick building for music curricula purposes. The great value of this construction is that it has involved not only the students and the teachers but also the retired people of the town, who have come in to assist and offer their service to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: The building itself, I might add-having seen it-is a wonderful example of what rural towns can achieve through the community spirit they have. As I said, the building is made of mud bricks, all of which were made by the students at the school. Professional help from bricklayers and builders was obtained by the school in the construction and much of the fitting out was done by the pupils. Of particular note is the fact that surrounding the central part of the building, just under the roof line, is a mural made from stained glass windows. Those windows were constructed with the assistance of an artists-in-residence grant to the school. Mr Wallace, who lives in the area of Violet Town just north from Euroa, together with the students built the whole mural in lead glass. The mural involves a story in lead glass pictures.

The great value of the project was not just that the students became involved in the construction of the leadlight windows but that many of the parents who came to the school are now undertaking further instruction and are involved in hobby activities in leadlight glass. I congratulate Mr Wallace and all of the people involved in the leadlight glass project. I invite any honourable member who is travelling along the marvellous duplicated freeway which is the new Hume Highway, and which the Government is responsible for building, to divert from the highway to Euroa, because very shortly Euroa will be bypassed and the town will once again revert to a place which does not suffer the through traffic of articulated vehicles 24 hours a day, seven days a week. The town will benefit greatly from the work this Government has done on the Hume Highway. I am pleased that I will be there shortly on behalf of the responsible Minister to open that bypass.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been invited?

—Yes, I have been invited to open it and I will be very proud to do so. More importantly, this sort of project is an indication of what can be achieved through community effort in schools. I might add that the teachers see this not just as a straight-out building project but very much as a means of developing the knowledge and skills of students and of teaching the students how to learn. To me, that is the most valuable thing that this project has done. The development of knowledge and skills is achieved through the students themselves working with engineers and builders, actually handing up and passing things over, hammering in nails and, as I said, building the mud bricks. I commend the school, the principal, the teachers involved and the broader community, who have together built a very fine school building for music purposes at an extremely small cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I would have had the opportunity to make a statement about misrepresentation by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). I did the right thing by contacting him today in the gymnasium. I take this opportunity to point out some basic facts and correct the misconceptions apparently held by the confused member for Dobell on, perhaps, the animals liaison service and his outlandish statements surrounding my by-election campaign and the fact that I made a--
—Your election was outlandish.

—I hope it gets in Hansard, wimp. While out doorknocking, I was told by a concerned mother, now one of my constituents, that her teenage son was involved with drugs. Contrary to the wild assertion of the honourable member for Dobell that I had no proof, I was able to hand to the Adelaide Vice Squad not only the drugs but also the implements for the smoking of the same. They are called bongs, for the honourable member's information. I was also able to hand over some very good quality hash, which the Vice Squad was very keen to have.

SPEECH.PARA: A most derogatory statement followed from the Deputy Premier of South Australia, Don Hopgood, who accused me of deceit, saying there were no drugs in schools. Since then we have followed the matter up with two headmasters, who declared that a shopping centre in Adelaide, in the north-eastern part of my electorate, was a centre for drug dealers. We have followed that up with two recent statements. I applaud, as I did in Adelaide, the Labor Albert Park member of parliament, Mr Hamilton, who called for the expulsion from schools of young drug dealers who are still operating. There was another statement in last week's News under the headline `Drugs rife in schools'. Last night the honourable member for Dobell said:

When the police came across the person who was believed to have spoken to the honourable member for Adelaide, she said that she did not in fact make the allegations claimed by the honourable member for Adelaide.

The fact is that the honourable member for Dobell and his cronies in the Bannon Government spoke to the wrong woman. I thought that they would have realised their error when the lady denied all knowledge of the affair-but no, they were convinced that I had manufactured it all. There was television proof and the drug squad followed up those inquiries.

I followed the matter through with three things. We physically handed over the evidence to the police; we convened a drug forum in the electorate in Enfield which drew a packed house of concerned adults, and I have thrown my support behind the life education learning for life drug program, which has been mentioned by a couple of my coalition colleagues, and in relation to which the Treasurer promised to dredge up a response.

I turn to my statement in the House last night when I spoke of the thousands of petitions that had been filed in the electorate of Hawker and certainly the electorate of Adelaide concerning several key issues. Today I filed over 250 such petitions in my name, including 73 from people living in the electorate of Hawker. Leaving the conventions of the House and as an act of goodwill, I shall not continue to berate the honourable member for Hawker for her omissions. I tried to contact her, but thought that it would be imprudent to bust in on a conversation in the non-members bar this evening to explain my actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been in both the gym and the bar tonight?
—Both of them, and I had to track down the honourable member for Hawker in the bar.
—Order! It is improper to make those sort of allegations about members. The honourable member should withdraw.
—I withdraw. I went in there to--
—Order! The honourable member will continue with his speech.

—The Labor Government has scant concern for pensioners, retirees and veterans as indicated by its plan to renege on its responsibilities in handing over the repatriation general hospital system to the States at a time when the old diggers need it most. I seek leave to table a calculation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated by the Government's attempt to plunder the nest eggs of the elderly by extending the pension incomes test to market-linked investments, it has been a concern of pensioners and of concerned people in my electorate--
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) mentioned a subject in which I am very interested, the life education centres throughout the whole of Australia. The coalition parties do not have a mortgage on support for such centres. It is not only the coalition which has made representations for the tax deductibility of mobile caravan units. Government members will be continuing to follow up that matter, because it is a good program. I shall not deal in detail with that program tonight, but I wish to deal with the subject of smoking. As a person who smoked for many years and who has only recently given away those dreaded cigarettes-I sometimes have the odd cigar-I can say that it is probably one of the worst habits that anybody could possibly have, and there is no doubt about that. It is a drug which is probably as hard to give up as is alcohol-a substance which I do not imbibe very often at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Mr Tom Burns, who is a State member in my electorate, recently handed me 50 letters from students of about 11 or 12 years of age in grade 6 at the Wynnum North Primary School, all pleading with the State and Federal governments to do something about cigarette advertising and stopping this very harmful habit at the time when it most counts; that is in relation to young children. A letter was sent by the teacher from grade 6, Ms Barbara Hart, to Mr Burns saying that the students had had a health lesson in which the dangers of smoking were pointed out. She asked a couple of students in her class to write letters of complaint. As it turned out, 50 students decided to write. In view of the seriousness of what smoking can cause, I have selected four or five of the better letters and I will read them to the House. One states:
Dear Sir,

We have decided that too many people are having heart attacks from smoking and now too many teenagers are starting to smoke. The teenagers don't know what's happening to them until they get older or they have an x-ray on their lungs. Would you please stop people under 16 from buying cigarettes? If police see a cigarette shop owner sell them please have them fined $100 dollars like in Victoria. Please stop cigarette companies putting up cigarette signs and raise the smoking prices. Your Sincerely, Troy Addley.
Another letter reads:
Dear Sir,

Hello my name in Genaine. We've been talking about smoking in health lessons and I am very worried about teenagers smoking. Did you know in 1983, 16500 Australians died due to cigarette smoking and 40% of heavy smokers will die before reaching 65, compared with only 15% of non-smokers. Smoking KILLS-
that word is underlined-
so please try to stop some smoking ads on T.V., sports events and in the magazines. If you can do something do it please.
Your sincerely, Genaine Colebourne.
Another reads:
Dear Sir,

I'm worried about the health risks for children of all ages from smoking. I think smokes should be demolished for good because too many people are dying from lung cancer. We should not let our community let this go on. I agree with everyone else that the smoking ads and cigarette sports sponsorship should be banned. The price of smokes should be put up so teenagers can't buy cigarettes. Please try your best to stop the smoking advertisements.
Another says:
Dear Sir,

I'm concerned about my future. About 20000 people die every year from disease caused by smoking. Adults who smoke 20 cigarettes a day pour one cup of tar into lungs each year. I think they should ban advertising. It seems as though the smoking companies don't care about our future.
Yours sincerely,
Kellie Bain.

It is good to see that at least those things are being taught in school. I call upon the Queensland Government to do something about stopping shop owners from selling cigarettes to under-age children. I think it should follow Victoria's lead and fine them at least $100 for selling cigarettes to under-age kids. I say to all children: do not smoke. I speak from experience when I say that respiratory problems come from smoking and, by gee, have I got some respiratory problems at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only the most uninterested members of this House would not now be well acquainted with the crisis afflicting the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). Only the most irresponsible would not wish to redress the situation, a situation which has seen the morale of CSIRO plummet and its effectiveness as the principal research institute in this country severely reduced. Yet honourable members may be interested to know that there is at least one occupant of the Government benches-a senior Minister-who regards CSIRO as something approaching a leech on the public purse.
—Walsh?

—The honourable member for Mayo suggests the Minister for Finance. No doubt when consideration is given to internal memos within the Department of Finance he and his Department regard CSIRO as not worthy of sufficient public funds to continue its research efforts. However, I refer specifically to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) who, we understand from press reports, clashed bitterly with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) during a Centre Left faction meeting earlier this week.
—How can you rely on a press report? Can you vouch for it?

—The Minister asks whether we rely on a press report. Does he deny that the Education Minister described CSIRO as having made no real effort to obtain private finance for research? Does he deny that he alleged that CSIRO should put less emphasis on rural research? Does he deny that the Minister said that only second-rate people complained about a lack of research funds because first-rate researchers are always able to get funds? Does the Minister deny that he spoke in such general terms?

SPEECH.PARA: I invite the Minister to extend the adjournment debate this evening to address those press reports. It is within his power, Mr Acting Speaker, as you well know, to extend the adjournment debate to answer these points. He could take five or 10 minutes-however long it takes-to reply to the alleged clash with the Education Minister. I give credit to the Minister. Of course, we would expect him to take issue with any Minister who sought to downgrade the CSIRO so viciously as did the Education Minister, following in the tracks of his fellow Centre Left colleague, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh).

We are told from press reports that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business replied, somewhat angrily, that it was not easy to obtain private money for research in the Australian economy because a large part of industry was dominated by companies owned overseas. Of course, research is done by the parent companies in countries overseas. That is true. That is one of our major problems in attracting industry support. It is not the only one. The fact that agriculture and mining provide 80 per cent of our export income means that it is unrealistic to expect, for instance, a high level of private industry investment by agricultural industries. Elders IXL Ltd, which rivals the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd as the largest company in Australia, spends next to nothing on research. Of course, beer is beer and agriculture is agriculture, so why would Elders think that it was of any real profit to invest heavily in research and development?

Moreover, I suspect that the Minister-I await his clarification of the situation-did not reply to the Education Minister by alleging that the investment climate for private industry is most unsatisfactory, with high interest rates, a high inflation rate, a rigid labour market and a very inflexible oncost system. Why would industry, particularly the manufacturing industry, invest very heavily when it knows that at the end of the day it is not worth investing in the finished product? Realistically, investment from private industry largely must come from the high technology and manufacturing industries.

I challenge the Minister to reply to further press reports to the effect that, at the full Ministry meeting on Monday of this week, science was listed on the agenda, along with care for the aged and housing, as a priority for Government attention. In other words, does the Minister agree that he has been successful in adding science to the list of problems for the Government to address? If that is the case, maybe there is light at the end of the tunnel. I ask the Minister to reply.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—I notice that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) has failed to jump to get the call to follow me. Maybe in two minutes time he will extend the adjournment debate. Will the Minister fail to take this opportunity to reassure the science community-in particular the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)-that he is fighting for its interests against the ignorant assessments of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins)? Will he encourage it in its endeavours to place science on the political agenda by saying that he has finally got the Cabinet to admit that it is a political problem? I hope that the Minister can take the credit for doing so. I, more than anyone, would congratulate him if he were able to assure us that our efforts are beginning to bear fruit. Why will the Minister not respond? These are legitimate questions being put by the Opposition, on behalf of a very concerned constituency, which affect the well-being and standard of living of all Australians. The Minister is a coward. He is running away from his ministerial responsibilities.
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw that remark.
—Mr Acting Speaker, if the Minister does not answer the question, he is clearly a coward.
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw. If the Minister does not have the courage of his convictions publicly to address the concerns of the Opposition, quite frankly, he should resign. I am bitterly disappointed by the Minister's attitude. Before now I had a higher regard for him. Quite simply, he is washing his hands of the whole problem. He simply does not care sufficiently to answer the Opposition's questions. He should tell us whether the education Minister joins the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) in his attack on the science community and the CSIRO.
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until 10 a.m. tomorrow.
